Member for Oxley
Ms HANSON
(Oxley)
(7.36 p.m.)
—It appears some in our parliament are confused. National Party Senator Ronald Boswell today launched an absurd attack on me where he tried to associate me with just about everyone except Jack the Ripper. I can understand why Ronald is so hot under the collar, but it has nothing to do with anything he said in his irrelevant tirade of silliness. It is all about the fact that rural and regional voters are deserting the National Party in droves.
What the Nationals should be doing is splitting from the Liberals so they can have their own voice instead of being caught up and dominated by the Liberal agenda. The Liberals have no interest in the constituents of the Nationals—in fact, many of their left‐wing members and senators are more comfortable with Labor Party views and see the National Party as their true enemies.
The National Party should stand on their own two feet and start representing the people who elected them. Rural and regional voters are turning to me for hope. The Nationals can only expect to lose more and more support as they continue to allow themselves to be placed under the Liberal Party's thumb. Perhaps next time Ronald wants to have a go at me, he will say what is really wrong—
Mr Griffin
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: it is correct practice in this House to refer to members of the other chamber by their correct title.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
—The honourable member for Oxley will, of course, refer to other members of the chamber by their correct title.
Ms HANSON
—He will say what is really worrying him instead of the silliness we saw today. Maybe Senator Boswell will even find some backbone and speak and act on behalf of the people out in the country instead of just being the Liberal Party's puppet.
As our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has escaped the issue of rising unemployment by leaving the country, his parting attack on me is evidence that he does not understand the priorities in Australia. I speak of jobs and all Mr Howard can do is speak of me. The Prime Minister's preoccupation with wanting to somehow associate me with the foreign extremists may be of great concern to the Australian people.
When is Mr Howard going to do something to create jobs? For that matter, when has Mr Howard ever been successful at creating even one job? Has Mr Howard ever been in business? Has Mr Howard ever actually employed someone himself and been responsible for producing the income to keep that person employed, or is Mr Howard just a career politician with no real or recent experience of Australia outside politics?
Jobs, Prime Minister Howard, not fleeing overseas to speak of me. Jobs, Prime Minister Howard, not jetting to London for the cricket. Jobs, Prime Minister Howard, not watching the baseball in New York. Prime Minister, when next you speak of me and imply that I am a racist, remember I am here in Australia
and I am trying to help my fellow Australians while you swan around the world on a trip of a questionable nature that looks like an excuse for a sports tour. Prime Minister, I doubt the Australian people see you as much of a sport.
While you are overseas in foreign lands speaking of me and having deserted Australia's unemployed, perhaps you should start to think about getting your priorities in order and whether you are a citizen of Australia or a citizen of the world. If you cannot get these things right, then step down before you and your policies put even more Australians out of work. Be the leader you were elected to be and lead Australia from Australia or get out now and give someone else a go.
In the future perhaps members and senators could say what they mean instead of what they want reported. Perhaps members and senators could learn to deal with the issues. Also it is very nice to hear from all you gentlemen and ladies. It is nice to know that you are here representing the best interests of all your constituents and the people of Australia. The main issue here is let us get employment and jobs for Australians first and foremost.
Western Australian Trades and Labour Council
Mr RANDALL
(Swan)
(7.41 p.m.)
—The Western Australian Trades and Labour Council and its leader Tony Cooke are gearing up for another round of industrial strife in WA under the guise of acting on behalf of its union members. Tony Cooke, how about representing all of your union members—not just your powerful mates, but the small individuals that have called your office often in the last few weeks for help and you have not even bothered to return their calls?
The specific case to which I refer is as follows. Two school teachers, Cheryl Soggee and Colleen Reed, were unfairly dismissed from Culunga school last year. These teachers were members of the Independent Schools Salaried Officers Association, ISSOA. On the request of and on behalf of these teachers, the ISSOA lodged an appeal of unfair dismissal
to the WA Industrial Relations Commission, the WAIRC.
This was done without informing the teachers that they could lodge an appeal under their own names. Culunga school held a reconciliation conference with the WAIRC without the teachers knowledge or presence. Subsequently, the two teachers were informed of the meeting and were told that they should accept the decisions arrived at in their absence.
The two aggrieved teachers elected not to accept the proposed arrangements and preferred to take the matter to trial. At a later meeting with Ivan Sands, Theresa Howe of the association‐cum‐union and Cheryl Soggee, the union said they would not proceed to trial because they did not believe the case was winnable. The union also stated that, if they lost, Cheryl would be unemployable. In other words, they were using scare tactics on her.
Cheryl elected to take her chance. Ivan Sands of the union said, `The ISSOA doesn't fight on principles. We will not take the matter to trial. Therefore, take it or leave it.' Cheryl Soggee informed the ISSOA that she would engage a private lawyer at her own expense, to which they replied, `Do what you want.' Mark Diamond, a private lawyer, was given the case of their unfair dismissal appeal and this was subsequently won before the WAIRC on behalf of Cheryl and Colleen.
Cheryl and Colleen are now waiting to appeal—not the decision but the amount of compensation awarded, which was only eight weeks. Ivan Sands, on behalf of the ISSOA has now refused their request to sign a form 7 which again will see this matter handed to the private legal representation that is being retained by Cheryl and Colleen.
Ivan Sands has also refused to return the phone calls of these teachers. Eventually when he returned their calls, he stated his intention not to cooperate with the teachers. He also knew that, by taking so much time, the 21‐day appeal period had virtually expired. He refused to put his decision in writing and said he was going home early. But when they rang some time later, he was still there. He had not gone home at all.
Tony Cooke, the so-called representative of the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council, has also refused to return numerous phone calls from these teachers asking for help. This sad case begs a few questions of this unrepresentative union, the ISSOA. Does the ISSOA only represent people whose cases in its opinion it can win? Does it not represent members with difficult cases?
If this is the case, I send a general warning to all ISSOA members that their union is unrepresentative and not worth belonging to. Other ISSOA members must ask themselves why they pay union fees like Colleen and Cheryl when the union chooses not to represent them or even let some private systems be used. The ISSOA dishonestly claimed credit in the
West Australian
newspaper on 30 April for Cheryl and Colleen's win in the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission.
Do Ivan Sands and the ISSOA and Tony Cooke and the TCL only represent their noisy union mates, like those from the so-called tent embassy, at the expense of ignoring the other battling and fee paying members like Colleen and Cheryl or is it up to coalition members like me who have to help the little people because their unions will not? I think it is a disgusting situation that these people are not being represented by their union. They need their help to get this appeal through the Industrial Relations Commission of Western Australia, and they have been blocked by the people who purport to represent them.
Bringing Them Home
Mr DARGAVEL
(Fraser)
(7.46 p.m.)
—I am going to read from the report
Bringing them home
from the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait and Islander Children from Their Families. `Confidential evidence 10, Queensland' reads:
They were very cruel to us, very cruel. I've done things in that home that I don't think prisoners in a jail would do today . . . I remember once, I must have been 8 or 9, and I was locked in the old morgue. The adults who worked there would tell us of the things that happened in there, so you can imagine what I went through. I screamed all night, but no one came to get me.
`Confidential evidence 8, New South Wales' reads:
I've seen girls naked, strapped to chairs and whipped. We've all been through the locking up period, locked in dark rooms. I had a problem of fainting when I was growing up and I got belted every time I fainted and this is belted, not just on the hands or nothing. I've seen my sister dragged by the hair into those block rooms and belted because she's trying to protect me . . . How could this be for my own good? Please tell me.
The question posed by that evidence begs an answer. It begs an answer from this government. It is an answer which this government, in my view, is yet to provide.
In the limited time remaining, I would like to go to some other evidence provided. `Confidential evidence 689' reads:
Because [my mother] wasn't educated, the white people were allowed to come in and do whatever they wanted to do—all she did was sign papers. Quite possibly, she didn't even know what she signed . . . The biggest hurt, I think, was having my mum chase the welfare car—I'll always remember it—we were looking out the window and mum was running behind us and singing out for us. They locked us in the police cell up here and mum was walking up and down outside the police station and crying and screaming out for us. There was 10 of us.
Finally, evidence from the same witness, `Confidential evidence 689, New South Wales', reads:
Most of us went to Crown St. Hospital. That's where my son was born, and then we went back to the hostel with the baby. Once we were there, we had the Welfare coming in, asking you what you was going to do—telling you most of the time that your parents didn't want you, the father of the baby didn't want you . . . they said to me they couldn't find anyone that wanted me, and they couldn't find anywhere for me, like a live‐in job where I could take the baby. And then they said the only one they could find that was willing to take me was my eldest sister, who I'd never seen since I was a little girl—she'd gone before us: she went away with some white people that were supposed to take her away for a good education—and they said she was the only one who was willing to take me, but she didn't want the baby. So they brought the papers in and told me to sign and that was it.
The dispossession and the destruction of the family relations evidenced by this report
Bringing them home
requires a substantial and a heartfelt response on behalf of the nation. This is not about feeling personal guilt for the actions of others of past generations and
perhaps of people still present. This is about recording a national regret for an obvious wrong perpetrated on the part of our community.
Corangamite Electorate: Students
Mr McARTHUR
(Corangamite)
(7.50 p.m.)
—Tonight we have a large number of primary school children, who are from my electorate of Corangamite, from the schools of Meredith, Lethbridge, Batesford and Shelford, and Anakie in the seat of Corio. They have made the trip to Canberra to see the federal parliament in action, to witness first-hand the deliberations of the elected representatives of Australia.
Recently I visited a group of students at the Meredith school to talk about the parliament, Australia's democracy and the system of government. We conducted a mock parliament and the two sides debated a very important issue. We learned about the procedure of the parliament at the school.
Yesterday the students came here to the parliament to see the parliament in action. Mr Speaker, they saw you in action in your role as the Speaker of this parliament, trying to keep order in the parliament and maintain a sense of decorum, keeping the stridently held views of both sides and keeping a sense of balance.
However, they saw the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) given a one-hour suspension because he was not behaving as well as he might have done. The member for Corio once worked for Senator Button and championed lower tariffs and free trade, but he has now become a champion of no tariff cuts. What a change he has undertaken! So the member for Corio was given a little suspension just at the half‐time break, which is his usual style. He had a friend with him as well, the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He also had a suspension.
I commend you, Mr Speaker, for your impartial deliberation on that occasion and again today. I am sorry my students were not here to see you in action again in the impar tial way in which you deliberate here in the parliament.
Back in Meredith we had a mock parliament, and the Speaker on that occasion was myself, as the member for Corangamite. I had similar difficulties with the students because they showed similar tendencies as members in this parliament in expressing their views, putting them forward strongly. They showed a couple of points of order and had to be pulled into line by the acting speaker on that occasion.
As they saw here earlier in the evening, this parliament is an expression of views throughout the nation and the philosophic differences that people on both sides express and put in a very strong and robust manner. As I often say to the students around my electorate, that is very much better than the armed conflict which takes place in other nations around the world.
At election time, Australians have a chance to put their point of view in their electorates through the ballot box. At the Meredith school we conducted a ballot so that the students could fully understand the significance of a secret ballot. I must say I am personally supportive of the compulsory voting procedures that Australians have undertaken because it means that everyone participates in the democracy, unlike the situation in American where President Clinton was elected by a little over 25 per cent of the electorate .
Back in Meredith, Lethbridge, Bannockburn and the other areas represented by the schools here tonight from the electorate of Corangamite, conditions have been very tough. Seasonal conditions have been poor and the local beef producers are suffering poor cattle prices because of the high grain prices in America. Wool growers are recovering, and the wool price has now reached 700c as sheep numbers recover. Hopefully, that industry will be better off in the near future.
Despite the hardship experienced by those two industries in my electorate, the farmers have been working hard under the landcare arrangements to contain the serrated tussock, a noxious weed which could have a devastating impact in the Corio electorate. I concede that the member for Corio has some serrated tussock in some parts of his electorate. That
is a weed that needs to be removed—maybe like the member for Corio at some future date. Also in the electorate of Corangamite, in the Meredith area, we have a tree planting program. Trees are being planted by farmers and by people in other industries to deal with the problems of salinity and soil degradation. I commend those farmers who have embarked on this new tree planting program.
Finally, I hope that the students from the Meredith school have enjoyed their trip to Canberra and have enjoyed seeing the parliament in action in all its competitive arrangements.
(Time expired)
Mr SPEAKER
—Does the honourable member for Corio require a right of reply or should I call your colleague?
Mr O'Connor
—I seek your indulgence for a moment. I was going to draw your attention to the fact that the member for Corangamite was not addressing his remarks through the chair and that he could have been disciplined as I was. But of course he has completed his speech, and I take the points that he has made.
Bringing them home
Mr McCLELLAND
(Barton)
(7.55 p.m.)
—I also would like to refer to an extract from the report
Bringing them home
, both to draw a further matter to the attention of the House and to honour the work of Sir Ronald Wilson and the others involved in the preparation of the report. This is a report about `William'. It is confidential evidence 553. William said:
I can remember this utility with a coffin on top with flowers. As a little boy I saw it get driven away knowing there was something inside that coffin that belonged to me. I think I was about six years old at the time.
That was William's mother. He speaks of being taken away from his auntie and uncle. He said:
As a little kid I can't remember what was going on really, because I was a child and I thought I was going on a trip with the other brothers. I just had excitement for going on a trip. That's all I can think of at the time.
He speaks of being taken to St Francis orphanage and then being taken to the home of a woman known as `Mrs R.' He says that the welfare officer led him and his brother into
Mrs R's home. Mrs R, with the welfare officer, showed them a large and well‐furnished room. However, he gives the account that after the welfare officer left they were taken outside to a caravan and that became their home. He said:
I was sleeping in the caravan. I was only a little boy then. In the middle of the night somebody came to the caravan and raped me. That person raped me and raped me. I could feel the pain going through me. I cried and cried and they stuffed my head in the pillow. And I had nobody to talk to. It wasn't the only night it happened.
Oh God, it seemed like night after night. It seemed like nobody cared. I don't know how long it went on for, but night after night I'd see the bogey man. I never saw the person. I do not know who that person was.
Then William gives evidence of being taken away from that family. He said:
They shifted us again and that was into town again. And then they put us in with this bloke . . . They've got the records of what he did to me. That man abused me. He made us do dirty things that we never wanted to do. Where was the counselling? Were was the help I needed? They knew about it. The guy went to court. He went to court but they did nothing for me, nothing. They sent us off to the Child Psychology Unit. I remember the child psychologist saying, `He's an Aboriginal kid, he'll never improve.
William gives an account of some behavioural problems that he has, the effect of alcohol and marijuana abuse and the problems he now has communicating with his children. The story is of itself obviously very moving, and there are a number of other moving stories in the report.
The accepted analysis is that it is now the case that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) can certainly give an apology on behalf of the nation in this House. Indeed, he could give an apology outside this House, appropriately worded, without it being an admission for the purpose of legal proceedings and damages. I think that in light of these facts that have been given to the government of the day it is a matter of honour. It is incumbent on the
government to apologise and express the profound regret of the nation for what has occurred.
Essentially, the government has two choices: it can deal with the issue of compensation administratively or it can let the process take place in the courts. There is no doubt—in my view—that this report constitutes a material fact which will overcome any time limitation problems that otherwise may have existed.
In my view, litigants would have within 12 months of the handing down of this report or becoming aware of its contents to commence proceedings. If proceedings are commenced, as they most certainly will be, without administrative compensation, there is every prospect that damages will far outweigh any administrative remedy. Those damages will go to the select few who have the resources to commence proceedings. In addition to the higher damages burden that the government will suffer in those proceedings, the government will, of course, suffer an additional burden of legal fees, which will be at least 20 per cent of the cost.
(Time expired)
Mr SPEAKER
—Order! It being 8 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until 9.30 a.m. tomorrow.
House adjourned at 8 p.m.

Wednesday, 18 June 1997
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
(Mr Nehl)
took the chair at 9.45 a.m.
WOOL INTERNATIONAL AMENDMENT BILL 1997
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by
Mr Anderson
:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Mr O'KEEFE
(Burke)
(9.45 a.m.)
—As we have indicated in other forums, the opposition is comfortable in supporting the progress of the Wool International Amendment Bill 1997 through the parliament. The bill provides for Wool International to dispose of the wool stockpile in the manner which has been envisaged for some years now with the restructure which began under the former government and which is being carried on at the moment. Because of the improved fortunes of the wool market and the management of the stockpile in the past few years, there is even a bit of a bonus over what was anticipated there, because there will apparently be a dividend and we will be seeing the retirement of the debt. The target date remains at December 1998 and we anticipate that Wool International will be wound up in 2001.
The time is now here for us, as politicians and members of parliament who have had a longstanding involvement for many decades in the management of the marketing of the wool industry, to begin asking questions about the future role of government across a whole range of agricultural marketing areas where we have seen so much restructuring in the past 15 years, with many industries now taking complete responsibility for the marketing of their products. In many ways, the government's role is reduced to passing legislation that enforces levies that provide for payments for research and development efforts and for marketing efforts in some areas.
I am not sure that I am entirely comfortable with this as a longstanding direction, you might be pleased to hear me say, Mr Deputy Speaker. Right across the Australian economy, I see various industries taking responsibility for these efforts, yet I cannot help but conclude that Australia's research and development effort is still abysmally low by world standards. Our scientific effort, in many ways, is lower than it should be. Of course, I could make the obvious political points that one could make in a forum like this, that the current government's cuts to the budget in these areas send all the wrong signals to the Australian economy.
But the interesting paradox in all this is that—totally because of government involvement in the management of these industries—there is, in agriculture in particular, and emerging in fisheries as well, a very strong commitment to the use of science and research to better advance the product, in order to keep ahead of the trends that we are continually having to battle against in world markets. Maybe that is because this industry has been exposed to the international market for longer than many other industries in Australia have been, or maybe it is because government has had a significant role in the management of industry. They may be the reasons. I do not necessarily say that that has been wrong, but there are some areas of it that we are withdrawing from completely, with a question mark over whether we really ought to be doing so.
What I am signalling here—and it is a luxury that we in opposition have at the moment—is that at our level there is a blank page rethink going on about what is the next step forward. What is the most appropriate structure for the wool industry, or any other industry, particularly one that is bulking up into a large commodity? Is it a single desk structure? At least two industries, the wheat industry and the sugar industry, place great store by that—the sugar industry moving towards it, and the wheat industry protecting it. In many ways, what we now know as Wool International—certainly for the export effort—has been a single desk marketing system. Is that the way to go? Other industries in agriculture that are moving into export development are asking themselves these very questions and we are seeing quite significant arguments among the players about whether they want to be part of a bulked‐up, single desk type structure, or whether they want to go it alone and have their own marketing strategies for their own particular products.
For Australia's international interests—and, therefore, our national interest—I think that government has a responsibility to take an overriding role in quality assurance. To perform successfully as an exporting nation Australia must regard quality assurance as being of great significance. I am not just talking about the quality of the product itself, but the quality of the whole performance of the delivery of the Australian product: the way it is produced, marketed, and transported—everything to do with the way we present ourselves in international trade. Whether it is the clearing house model, or whether it is remaining with single desk structures where government must have some kind of supervisory role in the way we present ourselves internationally, or whether we start encouraging some of these bulked‐up industries, such as wool and wheat, to look at some sort of cooperative structure with the breaking down of the bulk into particular target areas, remains to be seen.
A couple of weeks ago I addressed the Wool Council of Australia's annual meeting at Geelong—and I thank the Wool Council for having so quickly made an opportunity for me to have my first dialogue with the industry, having recently moved into this portfolio. I was quite fascinated by the address given to that forum by Mr Henry Grunzke, who is president of the International Wool Textile Organisation, and I could not help thinking that what Henry was saying was actually quite consistent with these little reservations or question marks that I have over my own thinking.
He was, in effect, saying that, albeit the wool price is improving slightly at the moment, it is off the back of some particular trends in marketing cycles, including the running down of stockpiles in some of the purchasing nations. But his overall message was that it is going to get tougher. The competition from other commodities and other textile fabrics is going to get tougher, not easier. It is not as if the world is suddenly moving back to some great re‐enchantment with wool. Wool itself is going to have to find yet more ways of making itself an easier product to deal with for the world, and a better product for the world to deal with. That means blends with other textiles or synthetics. A very interesting case being talked about widely is the experiment with cotton to produce a new denim fabric. This may hold real opportunities for us.
But, in the middle of all that presentation, I think Henry Grunzke was really saying that if Australia wants to just produce a bulk commodity and get a bulk commodity price, there is not much real long‐term joy in that for wool growers. I listened to the debate at the Wool Council about, for instance, preparing wool in environmentally acceptable bales that can be both recycled and re‐used, and can guarantee the cleanliness of the fibre product in those bales.
They are more expensive than existing bales. With a recycling life, they would probably work out to be more efficient and more economic for the industry.
Several delegates from the floor immediately asked the question: who is to bear this cost? Is the cost to be borne by the producer who sticks it in the bale or is it going to be in the price that they receive for their end product? The message Mr Grunzke was giving was: `I do not think you can expect the purchaser to pay for it.' That immediately created a response amongst the delegates: `How can you expect the producer to pay for it, when his returns are so low now?' And I thought, `This has got a sense of inevitability about it. If he does not present his product in a bale the way the world wants it, they will just buy it somewhere else.'
Inevitably, that kind of improved presentation of the product is going to be a cost borne by the producer or by the industry in Australia, if it wants to stay viable, if others are producing or supplying their product in that form. What Mr Grunzke was really saying was that there are two ways to go about this. One of the suggestions was that maybe we are too bulked up; maybe in having all the export effort going into the stockpile, and with all the difficulties of then trying to break it down into particular areas, we are losing a value‐add margin. Yet at the same time he was saying that, internationally, it is impossible to deal with a few producers, a few growers, who might produce a few hundred or a few thousand bales of a particular fabric or a particular fibre content. He was really saying that they are looking to deal with blocks that can produce year‐round supply, but maybe of 100,000, 200,000 or 300,000 bales—in other words, some kind of cooperative structure.
In my thinking I have a question mark—as I am signalling—over whether the move to the total free market, hoping that our agricultural producers can get in touch with their end customer much better and hoping that they will get it right, is too much of a risk for Australia. But I am well aware that leaving international marketing bulked up into large single desks that are not responsive, or not responsive enough, to the changes taking place in both the content of material and the blending of synthetics, leaves us exposed to bulk prices at the bottom end. That is not consistent with the value adding theme that this nation has to work with.
Today, and in every forum I speak in, I will continue to place myself directly in opposition to the comments of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, who earlier this year said that he saw Australia's future being in improving our performance in the production and supply of export raw materials. He made the comment that he did not see much future in value adding for this nation.
I saw a comment from the deputy president of Canegrowers in Queensland yesterday that government is now turning the bush into ghost towns. Every instinct I have, every lesson I have learned in my time in this parliament, tells me that the decline in our country towns and country regions, this whole concern nationally about this drift away from country towns, can only be reversed with two trends. One is government reinvesting in the people and community services that government has been pulling out of these towns in recent years. But that will only happen on the back of private sector investment in these areas as well, in what I choose to call value adding as close as possible to the source of production.
In the brief time available to me, I will tell a tale that sums this up. In the last couple of years, a wool tops plant has been built in Melton, in my electorate. Mr Kim from Korea has invested in this fabulous new plant. It has created about 40 or 50 new jobs, which is terrific for my electorate. I had a serious discussion with Mr Kim about why he chose this area.
Melton is on the western outskirts of Melbourne, about 40 kilometres from the CBD, right near the new infrastructure that we invested in, such as the standard gauge rail, the waterfront, the airport—the whole box and dice. There was competition from many areas, as everyone wanted Mr Kim to invest in their area. I asked him why he chose Melton. He gave a number of reasons. He said that it was not far from the product, because the wool stores are all around the west of Melbourne. A very well‐trained and reliable work force was available. A university campus was right next door, and he wanted that for his children. A golf course was also nearby, so that made it a very attractive work environment for him—a hell of a lot better than he could get in Seoul in Korea.
However, the telling point was that he said that, if he had come and looked himself seven years earlier—that would have been in about 1986 or 1987—he would have invested then. I asked, `Why didn't you?' He said that it was because the Australian Wool Board, as it was then called, told him not to invest here. It told him that the difficulties of doing business in Australia were a discouragement. It quoted the waterfront, the labour market—the usual stuff the conservatives traipse out—and it urged him to make his investment in Seoul and to continue to import bales of wool.
Now he has had a look for himself instead of relying on that advice, and he has done it. He is rapt in the performance, and so am I. But what are we doing to ourselves by giving that sort of message? The very people who ought to be reversing the drift away from regional Australia are actually saying, `Don't invest here.' That may have been an isolated case. Let us hope it was a very isolated case. Let us hope the image has changed in the last decade. Certainly, I have put an enormous amount of effort into that region around the west and north of Melbourne to try to change that image for exactly that reason.
The parliament must focus on how to reverse this drift. What is the future role of government in this area? Is it fostering a clearing house model, or fostering large single desks, or fostering cooperative models, where the producer can be bulked up enough to meet the task? I am very impressed with what I have seen, for instance, at the Bega Cheese Cooperative. It has managed to survive as a cooperative structure of 100 or so dairy producers in a highly competitive market against multinational organisations which are competing in that industry.
Maybe there is something in that. As we successfully make the transition from the old Wool Board and the old stockpile through to Wool International and the process where growers are now taking total responsibility and government is moving out from under them, this is the time to think about what the role of government should be in ensuring that we get the maximum value added, particularly out of these industries which have become used to marketing in large volumes to export markets that are getting tougher and tougher, with finer and finer margins.
Finally, I want to comment about something that happened yesterday, which I could not help chuckling about. Yesterday in question time I asked the Deputy Prime Minister, the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), a question. I like Mr Fischer. I have always found him to be a lovely chap and a fellow I enjoy working with. So it quite surprised me when he got up and started off his answer by saying to me that he thought I was having a very difficult time as the new shadow minister for primary industries, and that this had been `demonstrated by his pathetic performance at Geelong at the Wool Council meeting.'
We all say these things in politics, I suppose, but I thought, `Gee, Tim, that is a bit out of character for you. You don't normally, certainly not towards me anyway, start off in that frame of mind.' I thought I would place on the record—just to help the Deputy Prime Minister in
his assessment—a lovely letter that I received yesterday from the Wool Council. It virtually arrived in my office as the Deputy Prime Minister was making his comments. The letter states:
On behalf of all the members and the staff, I wish to thank you for your excellent address at our recent conference.
They go on to talk about the way we might have a strong link between the council, the opposition and ourselves, which is a very sensible strategy for the Wool Council to be maintaining. I understand that fully. I hope that Tim will be a little more gentle with me in his comments in future.
As I have said, we are very comfortable with this particular piece of legislation and the process which it is unfolding. I have used this opportunity this morning to signal that, certainly in our position in opposition, our role at the moment is not just that of opposing the government. We also see ourselves as a future government. We see ourselves as having to come forward with ideas for the future. I am also signalling this question of the importance of agriculture as a key industry in the Australian economy. It is not an industry that you can go out and say, `Agriculture is special and Australia has got to have answers for agriculture because it is special.'
Certainly within my party, and within our people, whatever case we make for Australia's need to have a steel industry in the future, whatever case we make about the textile industry or the car industry, it is equally so that this whole issue of rural and regional social infrastructure, and the running down of our country towns, is totally dependent on a strong national investment in agriculture and value adding as close as possible to a source of production. I think the key questions that we will be focusing on in the next 12 months or so, as we prepare what will go to the Australian people in this policy area, will be the extent to which government has not done enough, or has to do more, or has begun opting out, rightly or wrongly. I thank the House for the chance to make those few observations and signal that we will be supporting this legislation.
Mr CAMPBELL
(Kalgoorlie)
(10.09 a.m.)
—In 1970, I was one of those people advocating the establishment of the Wool Corporation, a single desk seller, for which I have said a thousand mea culpas. However, while the price was set, somewhat below the cost of production, it probably did not do a lot of harm. It was not until the Wool Corporation decided it would become a price setter under David Asimus that the real damage was made visible. There is no doubt in my mind that David Asimus has done enough damage to be given the Order of Australia, like Andrew Peacock.
I am not a committed free marketeer or a committed single desk seller; I think it depends very much on the commodity. But in respect of wool, the only future for wool growers must lie in a free market. It must lie in a close liaison between wool producers and wool end users—not in making them the enemy, as the wool industry has tried to do in the past.
I am glad that this bill, the Wool International Amendment Bill 1997, provides for the dissolution of Wool International. It was a hangover from the old Wool Corporation and it is something that should be swept away. Any growers, in my view, who reinvest their money in any entity associated with Wool International deserve what they get. I would urge every one of them to use their market to repatriate debt or to some other useful purpose.
It has got to be realised that, as we produce it in Australia, greasy wool is an agricultural commodity and agricultural commodities throughout the world are subject to downward pressure in price. What we need to do is to value add. Top making is an industrial product—it
is an industrial fibre. If all our wool was sold as top making in Australia, wool would be Australia's number one export again. Its size belies its importance and it would be far more important because it would employ a lot of people, and it would employ people in country towns. It would employ far more people, for instance, than the mining industry does.
However, I believe our growers should be looking to go beyond top making, at least to the spinning stage. I see no reason why we cannot be competitive in Australia with a single white yarn. If it is so that we are not competitive there—and bear in mind that, up to the spinning stage, wool is capital intensive, not labour intensive—I suggest our growers should look to liaisons with countries that can provide a cheaper source of spinning but retain ownership of that product. I would suggest that India, which has invested heavily in wool technology, might be a place to look. Certainly I think that having an association of growers keeping control of their product to the yarn stage, where they sell directly to knitters and worsted makers, would give a far greater return to growers than it does today. It would also give more stability.
There was very little variation or drop in the price of wool yarn. We saw the price of greasy wool go below the cost of production. In fact, even top making was sold below the cost of production. But it was not so with yarn. I believe it would give a lot more security to our growers and it would also provide them with a great increase in their income.
There is a lot of hype about quality control and it is used, in my view, as one way of blaming the victim. It can tell growers that the drop in prices is partly their own problem. I believe it is nonsense. As a regular visitor to China, I have visited Chinese wool mills on many occasions. The Chinese repeatedly told me that they have no problem with the quality of Australian wool. They do, however, have big problems with the quality of wool from elsewhere.
This brings me to a comment that was made by the previous speaker, that wool is facing enormous competition from other fibres. Yes, there is competition from other fibres, but the wool we sell today, the fine merino wool, accounts for about five per cent of the fibre market. The main competition for our wool is other wool; it is not synthetic fibres. While I am all in favour of looking at value adding—at blends and all those innovations—it must be remembered that the main competition for our wool is other wool.
I can remember that, when I was in the Labor Party, it took me 12 months to get to the caucus a resolution to ban the export of Australian genetic material. It took me three attempts. At last, I succeeded. The next week, the minister, then Collins, marched back into the caucus room and overturned that without any discussion with caucus. The truth was that most people in the caucus did not understand the industry, and certainly Collins never understood the industry. But that was overturned. It appears that people such as the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) had his ear. The member for Corangamite represents that raft of small studs across Australia that see some quick money to be made in selling off our genetic heritage—150 years of our endeavour—for the quick quid overseas.
I might add that in my endeavours to have a ban on the export of Australian genetic material I had the wholehearted support of the big studs and the overwhelming support of Australian farmers. I even went to New Zealand to canvass New Zealand growers and I assured them that, in spite of the closer economic arrangements, if they did not agree to put a ban on the sale of genetic material then we would ban them.
The wool industry in New Zealand said to me, `Look, we only export it because you do. We would stop tomorrow.' I spoke to one of the biggest exporters and he said, `I would love
to stop because I know the damage it is doing. I only do it because you are doing it in Australia.' I think there is a greater understanding of the problem in New Zealand where they do have a small but very good fine merino wool industry.
However, it was not to be. I believe that any government that genuinely has an interest in the Australian wool industry should move quickly to put a total ban on the export of Australian genetic material, and that is about the only area where I want to see any government involvement in the wool industry.
The other area that we need to look at is on-farm wool production. One of the main sources of contamination in wool comes from the exhaustive testing we do which tends to punch polypropylene fibres into the wool where they become mixed, and because the fibres do not take dye they show up in the final product. There are things we could do here. We could certainly look at producing a binding twine that takes dye for baled hay, which is one of the other big sources of pollution, and I am sure that we could do something about making a wool pack that would accept dye, or better still, doing away with wool packs in the shearing shed altogether.
A company called Australian Topmaking Services was set up in Parkes as a custom top maker but the company is now under the control of Elders so I do not know what direction it will take. That top making plant has become the best in the world. It has leapfrogged the French in terms of productivity and it produces a top quality product.
The establishment of that company in Parkes was the brainchild of John Todhunter, a man who was enormously abused by the wool industry in Australia and by the vested interests in the wool industry. He was one of the great lateral thinkers of the wool industry and he made an enormous contribution. He also designed an on‐farm bulk baler which was very similar to those used in the cotton industry where the whole clip was put into large containers, pressed with a very simple pressing mechanism and then taken directly to the top maker, thereby doing away with the cost of baling.
That was very beneficial. When I finished wool classing, the instructor said to us as we got our certificates, `Every one of you will now go out and overclass the clip,' which every one of us did, `but unless you can increase your market share in the United States, the biggest fibre users in the world, there won't be a wool industry in 25 years.' That was 35 years ago.
There was some substance to what he said. The Wool Corporation spent $2 billion in the United States trying to increase the percentage of wool used in the United States, but with absolutely negligible success. The reason was that while $2 billion is an enormous amount of money to Australian wool producers, it is an infinitesimal amount of money when you spread it across American television. It simply did not go anywhere. The idea should have been to target certain areas and grow an interest in wool out from the areas that were most suitable for its application.
It is interesting to contrast the approach of the Australian wool industry in this respect with that of one of the big Italian mills. That mill sent Mr Todhunter to America with a month's pay and said, `After that you are on your own.' He established that firm in the United States and it is now one of the big consumers, and he did it without $2 billion of Australian taxpayers' money. I think it was a great mistake to spend those billions. It was a great cost to the Australian taxpayer. We still have to attract that market, and I believe we can because of the unique qualities of our wool. I look forward to an increase in that market.
We should also not overlook the importance of Europe for, while China is our biggest single consumer, it is Europe that still sets the style and the standard and so we must maintain our close contact with the wool industry in Europe. It is true that the centre of gravity has probably moved from Bradford to somewhere around northern Italy, France and Germany, but it is Europe still where style is set and it is an area where we must have constant communication.
There are people in Australia who need some credit for the work they have done. Jim Maple‐Brown is without peer. He has played an enormous part in trying to put some sense into the Australian wool industry. I believe that, if anyone deserves an Order of Australia, it should be Jim Maple‐Brown. I believe that the work that Mr Maple‐Brown is doing will continue to show great benefits for Australia.
I have mentioned Jonathan Todhunter. Other growers, Jim and Susie Clarke from Hamilton, in Victoria, recently had their shed burnt down. At the height of the depression in wool, they have built a shed especially designed with an approach to reduce the handling in the woolshed.
The truth is that, when you are making tops, a top maker can disguise the quality of the wool enormously. One of the problems we have had in some part is unscrupulous top makers that have put a lot of very short fibre into their product. They can twist it up in the middle of the yarn and it will not show until it is knitted up, and it comes out as little balls on woollen clothes. Quality tops are an art as much as a science. I believe that, if we concentrate on quality, we can have an ongoing substantial market in the sale of tops.
Of course, if you are producing tops, freight becomes a much less significant factor. You are not transporting grease or dirt. You are transporting a commodity that will stand airfreight and, for those mills that are operating on a basis of keeping their stockpile down, it is a very good method of getting their fibre.
You also have to look at other options. The CSIRO in Australia developed a technique for treating wool so that they could give a 1,000‐year guarantee on its freedom from rot and insect infestation. It then made an ideal product for insulation. I believe that there is a market worldwide for woollen insulation, but it is not for Australian wool. We are not selling wool. Wool is a generic commodity. We are selling merino and we should never lose sight of that.
If China were to put a lot of the rough wool it produces into the insulation market, this would make a bigger gap in the Chinese market so that they could consume our wool. They are big wool producers. They only want our wool to make their wool saleable. As soon as they have self‐sufficiency in that area—a self‐sufficiency which I do not think they will get—they will simply stop buying our wool. No‐one buys from us because they like us. They buy from us because we have what they want.
I believe that we should be encouraging that technique, even if we buy that cheap wool out of China, which we would get for cash very cheaply. We could process it and sell wool batts. There is not a government in the world today who would put fibreglass wool insulation into its buildings, for fear of later legal ramifications. For an example, Electricite de France in Europe very successfully stopped the development of nuclear energy in Germany by funding the Greens. There was no doubt that this happened. This was admitted to me over a couple of bottles of red wine in France. They were very pleased with their efforts and so they should have been. The Greens were not an entity in France and Electricite de France is now the world's premier producer of nuclear powered electricity, which, of course, puts them in very good stead with all this hocus‐pocus nonsense about the greenhouse gases that we have allowed ourselves to be subjected to.
I would just add in passing that that is an idea that has no basis in science whatsoever, an idea that has been promulgated by scientists looking, in many cases, just to get loan grants. There is no evidence at all to suggest there is any correlation between greenhouse gases from industry and world warming. In fact, it is an arrogance of man: if you test ice squalls in the Antarctic you will find levels of CO2 far exceeding anything that we have made with our puny efforts. I might add that volcanic activity and the burning of forests also make the products of industry look pretty puny. Nonetheless, by their advocacy and use of nuclear energy, they have put themselves in a much better position than we have.
I believe there is a great future for wool. I believe that future will be with wool growers, either individually or in combination, supplying the product direct to the industry to the specifications required by the industry. This may, in fact, require that shearing happens at shorter intervals than 12 months. It may be that the desired length of fibre can be obtained in 10 months. If that is the case, that is what will have to happen. But I believe the future of the industry lies much more in direct and close liaison between wool growers and end users to supply what the customer needs. I do not think wool growers need to be intimidated by a lot of the nonsense that is spoken.
I say again that I am glad to see the opportunity to sweep away Wool International and I believe that the free market in wool is one area where the free market can be seen to work. That is not the case in every area, and I certainly reserve my judgment in respect to grain, because I do not believe the market is free in grain anyway; it is cartelled. But, in the area of wool, I think we are going in the right direction here. I must say that, following a speech by the now minister at Dubbo, I thought that we would not see this, but it is in the bill that growers can take all their money out. As I say, if they leave any money in any grower organisation involved in world marketing, then they deserve what they get.
I might add that, when the Garnaut report came out—and the Garnaut report was a very flawed document—I went to Dubbo at the behest of the Labor Party, basically because they had no‐one else to go. I made a speech to the assembled crowd at Dubbo and said to them that I thought it was a flawed document. After all, this man Garnaut was the one who gave us
Australia and the Northeast Asian ascendancy
, a book which has attracted the minds of both Liberal and Labor Party members, and a book so important that I thought I must read it. It was a bit like reading the Mabo act; it was like reading porridge. Certainly, in its turgid prose, I did not see the future in the glowing terms that Garnaut saw it, and I believe that history will vindicate me and not Mr Garnaut.
I think the Garnaut document was very flawed. It was a terrible time for wool producers, and they are not yet out of the maze. I believe that the future is looking brighter and that, if we can get the interplay of free enterprise and initiative of people in enterprise—initiative that was actually stifled under the Wool Corporation—we can see better days ahead.
Mr ANDERSON
(Gwydir—
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)
(10.28 a.m.)
—in reply—I do indeed thank people who have contributed to the debate on the Wool International Amendment Bill 1997 and the very important Australian wool industry. It is an industry which has, indeed, seen some extraordinarily difficult times over recent years. In fact, for some six years now the majority of growers have lost money.
At least until very recently, nine in 10 of Australia's wool growers were believed to be losing in terms of the overall performance of their businesses. No‐one in this place would wish that appalling prospect on what is a very important sector of the Australian economy. It is a
very important part of our social, as well as economic, fabric and there are many parts of the country which are really not suited to anything except wool production. Their communities are as badly damaged as growers and their businesses are, in those circumstances.
It is, of course, tremendously encouraging to see the current lift in prices. The eastern market indicator at the moment is in the order of 720c, or thereabouts. We hope that the emerging new markets will lead to increasing demand at the retail level over time, and there have been some very worthwhile developments in this regard in recent months.
In full fairness to the opposition and their role in setting it up, it was a great delight for the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) and I, for example, to be able to carry forward the deal under which we export wool tops and, if you like, expertise to Mexico without tariffs getting in the way. Our wool is value added there into garments for re‐export, again without tariffs under NAFTA, the North American Free Trade Agreement, into that very lucrative North American market. That is a trade which, from humble beginnings, is growing very rapidly and offers real prospects for the future.
The loss of the Russian outlet for wool, which did so much damage in the late 1980s and early 1990s, is likely to be increasingly offset by the improving prospects for exports to India. Recently the Indian minister for textiles, who is in fact a cabinet minister—we do not have a minister, let alone a cabinet minister, for textiles in this country, but in India the minister for textiles is responsible for activities which provide a livelihood for 60 million Indians—spent a couple of days here. Again, Minister Fischer and I, and many officers from the department and other departments, spent a lot of time with the minister. He was as good as his word: we saw in the last budget announcements of substantial reductions in tariffs pertaining to Australian wool exports to that country. That, too, offers a real prospect that India will become a substitute market, over time, for Russia. They are even more bullish on their estimates of the amount of wool they are likely to be taking over the coming years than our more optimistic forecasters are in this country. So that is good news.
We recently met with the Chinese Vice‐Premier. I would be reluctant to attempt to extrapolate figures and actual numbers out of the broad commitments that he made. It is fair to say that, as they seek WTO accession—and we have indicated that we will strongly support that but that support will be more easily offered by us if they continue to offer us better access on wool—he made it plain that they understand that and that they are very committed indeed to ensuring that we go forwards, rather than either stall or, worse, go backwards in relation to our wool access into China. Those things I think are very encouraging.
In general terms, the government has been very cognisant indeed of the problems confronting the wool industry. I am not a wool grower, but all my forebears have been—I do not know whether I am allowed to talk about my rural activities, in terms of the chances of conflict of interest and so forth, but those are the historical facts of the matter. I know a lot of wool growers. I know how important they are to the economy in general and to their rural communities in particular, and it is of vital importance that we see the industry recover.
Fifteen months ago I found a somewhat divided and dissolute industry, very disheartened and understandably demoralised. I formed the view very early on that whilst there were many things that we could do in a practical sense to help and to aid and abet recovery—opening up more markets being an obvious one—the maximisation of the potential of the industry would depend very heavily upon establishing a sense of unity, purpose and common direction, and ending the division within the industry. So we went through the process of two ministerial
round tables here in Canberra where I pulled together the industry's leadership from right across the globe, from its many facets—because it is a many faceted industry—and we worked through some very vexed issues.
The previous speaker spoke at great length about the Garnaut report and the fixed release schedule. While in opposition I supported the fixed release schedule. In an example of the sort of cooperation that perhaps the honourable members opposite would agree are too infrequently acknowledged in the broader community, the then minister Simon Crean and I were able to work through that whole very difficult period in a constructive way in what I believe was in the best interests of the wool industry. We put in place a rigid fixed release schedule at a time when wool prices, in terms of the eastern market indicator, were below 400c. As I recall, they had been as low as about 380‐odd and the industry was in a diabolical state, wondering whether it had a future.
It had very little idea of what to do with the enormous stockpile and the debt hanging over it, and there was a sort of siege mentality prevailing at the time. The industry desperately needed some certainty and some guidelines that were new and would hold, and so we moved down that road of setting up Wool International and of establishing a board for it. It was eventually to be corporatised but, in the meantime, it had responsibility for reducing the wool stockpile on a very tight quantity reduction program in place of the previous arrangement which had been a debt reduction program—a very dangerous instrument for industry at that very difficult time of its career.
The reality is that although it became very unpopular, the fixed released schedule gave the industry the certainty and the direction that it needed at a critical time in its history. There is no doubt in my mind—no doubt at all—that it was the right thing to do at the time and I do not resile from that for a moment.
The fact is that under that fixed release schedule we really started to wind back in a disciplined, concrete way that the market came to understand and respect, to the point where today the stockpile is greatly reduced and the debt has come down from something like $2.8 billion to something of the order of $700 million.
Let me backtrack for a moment. Through the round table process, in conjunction with the government, the industry was able to work through in a constructive way a more sensible regime, given the progress that had been made by then for the handling of the stockpile. In a rational way we opened up the disposal schedule so that only a minimum requirement needs to be met on a quarterly basis, and a great deal more can be sold on a quarterly basis according to the prevailing market at the time. As a result of that, industry has now very appropriately shifted its focus away from management issues relating to the stockpile onto the much more important main game for the future of increasing demand. As I have outlined, I think that progress has been made there in terms of opening up new market opportunities, but we are also able to focus on the very important question of promotion.
Promotion is designed to do two things. It will lock in such premiums as we can extract for wool over other fibres. You simply cannot turn a bob and produce wool at anything like the prices you can for alternative fibres such as cotton. It is an economic impossibility. You need a very real premium for a premium quality product. You have got to lock in such premiums as you are able to secure but then, given that those premiums have been, and remain, inadequate, you have got to seek ways to convince customers that it is worth paying a higher price for a higher quality product with the unique qualities that wool offers.
There are some major objectives to be reached there and some major challenges. We know, for example, that five years ago under‐35s in Western countries had very little understanding of the qualities of wool or the desirability of the product. When asked, they said that they thought of it as a `natural' product, but it was expensive, hard to look after, short‐lived and not particularly fashionable.
We now know five years on that under 40‐year‐olds have the same perception problem. Of course, if we keep going at that rate, in another five years it will be under 45‐year‐olds and in 10 years it will be under 50‐year‐olds, and we will all be gone. We have got to turn those perceptions around. We have got to get younger people, particularly for example in Europe, switched onto the desirability of wool as a product.
Last year I went to Paris. I hasten to add that I do not go there very regularly. I went there exclusively for the wool industry's benefit and I hope we achieved something. They took us to a mid‐range store where young people buy their clothing. I was intrigued that in Paris—considered the height of fashion—I noticed with some horror that those appalling lime greens and burnt oranges that were around in the 1970s are apparently about to re‐emerge—or they were in Paris at the end of last year.
Mr Sawford
—Try the fifties.
Mr ANDERSON
—I was not around in the fifties. One hopes for the best but the important point is that they seem to be targeting an appropriate group of younger, fashion‐conscious Europeans in an attempt to draw them back in, and I thought that was very encouraging.
To come back to what is before us, the government has sought to work with the industry against a philosophical commitment to empower the industry to take control of its own destiny again, and to get out of the way where we hinder rather than help. It has been very important to draw the industry into a regime where it is conscious of the need to provide its own leadership, its own direction, post the collapse of the floor price, and post—as we are now increasingly `post'—the massive government involvement that was necessary in the winding back of the stockpile and in the statutory arrangements that pertain to that process.
In fact, we have had a lot of legislation before the House as we have sought to progress that and, of course, what we are talking about today carries all of that further. It essentially indicates the timetable for the winding up of Wool International—the winding down of the size of the board, starting from the end of this year and, over time, by the year 2001, winding it up altogether.
Originally the Crean legislation proposed that Wool International could be corporatised on its way to being privatised and handed back to the industry as its own marketing body and so forth. Over time, we have come to the realisation that there are more appropriate ways to proceed. Many members of the coalition have very strong views on that. What we have ended up with is an approach which says that it will be disbanded. The only surviving entity may be an entity that at this stage is loosely known as `Global Wool', a joint venture between Elders, Wesfarmers Dalgety, Wool International or, if you like, an offshoot of Wool International. It would be a trading and marketing company which growers would have the option of investing in, and I stress `option'. There would be no compulsion at all if Global Wool were to proceed; it would be entirely voluntary. Growers would have the option of investing in it if they so choose, or not investing in it if they did not want to be part of that joint venture.
It needs to be noted that, in contrast to what we thought would be the case in 1993 with a huge debt—as it was then—an enormous stockpile to be digested and very low wool prices, no‐one held out any real prospect that in the end there would be substantial equity for growers out of the whole exercise. But we now know differently. Although there is still a reasonable amount of wool to digest, on current indications, there will be considerable equity to be returned to the growers. We have announced that it will be several hundreds of millions of dollars.
Some growers will get a pretty nice cheque out of it and I say that is more power to them for the blood, sweat and tears of the last few years. It is a small return when you set it against the sorts of losses that they have experienced. I know it is very welcome and everywhere I go wool growers tell me how relieved they are and how much they look forward to it. The entitlement to that equity will flow through, starting with the first tranche of $81 million this year, and that specifically will be returns on section 51, the sale of non‐wool assets.
I have not got much time but I have given a bit of a broad overview of where I see the industry going and this legislation does provide growers who have paid wool tax between July 1993 and 1996 with entitlements to the equity of Wool International. In due course, they will receive the cash distributions of the surplus. Wool tax payers will be given unit holdings on the basis of a unit for every dollar of wool tax paid, and the units will be able to be traded at values the market applies to them from time to time. The Wool International register of these entitlements will be finalised in September.
In terms of the interim and final payments of Wool International assets to wool tax payers, I am very pleased, as I have just indicated, that it will be about $81 million, which is more than the originally estimated $75 million. It is to be distributed equitably later this year—in fact, by December. There will be further payments in several tranches—probably two or three—over the next few years. And, as I said a moment ago, that is very pleasing indeed.
In terms of the comment I made a moment ago about Global Wool, the legislation allows for the setting up of a growers investment trust, a special purposes investment vehicle—I will not spell out what that acronym is! Prior to that proceeding, I stress that Global Wool, as a concept, will need ACCC approval and then my approval before it can proceed, and Wool International will, in the meantime, have a cap on further expenditure on the feasibility study and the establishment of the trust of $1 million through to 30 June 1998.
Wool International will also be allowed to establish, through a public tender process, a loan facility by a financial institution for the benefit of wool growers with entitlements to the equity of Wool International. They will be required to complete the tender process by 31 December 1997, thus giving equity holders more choice in the use of their equity in a way that suits their individual needs. There is a reasonable expectation that this arrangement will produce more advantageous terms than would otherwise be available to wool taxpayers negotiating loan arrangements with lenders individually. Growers will be absolutely free to negotiate their own loan arrangements if they so choose.
In summary, I have touched on the phasing‐out of the functions of Wool International and the reduction in the board size. I have been very impressed by the industry's willingness to work very hard—and I pay tribute to the hardworking executive members of the Wool Council of Australia who are with us here today—as we have sought to work through the very real problems that the industry has faced in recent times.
The virtually unanimous support for the monumental changes to be implemented through this act shows the striking success, in my view, of that process, which I would like to think was kicked off by the wool round‐table arrangements, where the industry recognised not only that it was possible to work together, but that there were real benefits in doing so.
It was an enormous delight to me last year, during my very brief trip through Europe—Rome, Milan, Paris and Brussels—in talking to the wool industry, to our customers in that part of the world, to hear repeatedly that they again trust the Australian government after the enormous damage that was done by the promises of a certain previous minister—promises that were immutable, with cast‐iron guarantees, that proved not to be worth the paper they were written on.
Our overseas customers are looking forward to working in harmony with the Australian industry in the future. They still have major concerns about the issue of wool contamination—which I am not going to do anything more than touch on here today. Quality control, however, is obviously a major issue for the industry still to address as part of the effective promotion of the industry. In short, we have a long way to go before the industry is in clover again, so to speak, but we have made great progress. I thank the industry for its determined efforts to pull together.
(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
INTERNATIONAL MONETARY AGREEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1997
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by
Mrs Moylan
:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Mr WILLIS
(Gellibrand)
(10.49 a.m.)
—The International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill amends the International Monetary Agreements Act to allow Australia to comply with the IMF's new arrangements to borrow, which is to be a new line of credit provided by a group of countries to the International Monetary Fund, which the IMF would be able to draw on in the case of a financial emergency in one or more of its member countries to assist that country or those countries. The opposition does not oppose this legislation; indeed, it strongly supports it.
I will go into the background of this measure for a little while. Firstly, it goes back to the Mexican crisis in December 1994, when private capital flooded out of that country as confidence in it suddenly evaporated following a string of high current account deficits—around eight per cent of GDP, as I recall—and led to reconsideration of the current international arrangements to respond to such a crisis.
The IMF provided substantial financial assistance to Mexico from its own resources, about $A24½ billion—by far the largest amount ever provided to a single member—and further amounts were provided bilaterally, especially by the United States. The need for such large financial resources to be provided for a relatively small economy led to considerable rethinking about the capacity of the IMF to respond to a future possible crisis, especially to a larger economy than that of Mexico.
The existing formal mechanism for supplementing IMF resources in such a situation was termed the `general arrangements to borrow', a line of credit provided through the G10, which comprises the G7 countries of the US, UK, Germany, France, Italy, Canada and Japan, plus four smaller European countries—Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland. That gives you 11 countries but it is still called the G10.
This general arrangement to borrow was established in 1961 when, under the then system of fixed parity exchange rates, the US dollar and the pound sterling were frequently under strain. The breakdown of the fixed parity system reduced the need for general arrangements to borrow, which has not been called upon since 1978. Nevertheless, it has remained in existence and, indeed, was extended in 1983 following the Latin American debt crisis of that time.
The next step along the way, following the resolution of the Mexican crisis with the financial assistance coming from the IMF and other ad hoc arrangements, was that the G7, at its meeting in Halifax, Canada, in June 1995, called for a doubling of the amount currently available under the general arrangements to borrow by the G10 and other countries with the capacity to support the system. So they were looking for others to assist the G10 in providing this kind of support mechanism at a time of international financial crisis for one or more countries.
The issue then became how to expand the GAB facility by bringing other countries into it. The simplest way was to expand the membership of the G10 so that, instead of having 11 members, it would have quite a few more. However, this was opposed by the smaller members of the G10 which were concerned that their privileged association with the G7 through this forum would be reduced. The role of the G10, of course, goes beyond the general arrangements to borrow—it acts as a caucus in the International Monetary Fund, in the OECD and also in the Bank of International Settlements. These smaller countries did not want other countries such as Australia to join the group. Accordingly, various other options were developed which would allow other countries outside the G10 to participate through separate arrangements parallel to the GAB, or through the establish of a new facility in addition to the GAB.
The problem with all these proposals, as initially developed, was that they would treat the non‐G10 countries as subordinate to the G10—that is, with the same responsibilities but a lesser role in decision making. Australia rightly regarded this as wrong in principle and, in discussion on the IMF board in 1995, we made it clear that in our view all participants in any facility should be treated on an equal basis.
Then in October 1995, at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund‐World Bank in Washington, I, as the Australian Treasurer at that time, made it clear that Australia would be prepared to participate in an expansion of the general arrangements to borrow, but only on three conditions. They were: firstly, that all participants should have the same rights and responsibilities—that is, there should be no second‐class citizens; secondly, that contributions should be based on the relative economic standing of participants; and, thirdly, that the new participants should participate fully in the activation arrangements and voting rights should be determined by the shares of the commitments. Later in 1995, the G10 developed a proposal to expand the GAB, but it did not adhere to Australia's three principles of participation. Australia, along with various other potential additional participant countries, made it clear that we did not accept the G10 proposal or, at least in the case of some countries, had strong reservations about it.
The next step along the way was in April 1996 when, at the APEC finance ministers meeting, Australia proposed the establishment of a new set of borrowing arrangements—that is, separate from the general arrangements to borrow—which would meet each of the three principles of participation that I had spelt out in the previous October. This became the basis of agreement and, by May of 1996, potential participant countries in this new arrangement had broadly agreed on how it would operate. Later in 1996, the detail was finalised and it was strongly supported at the IMF executive board level in January 1997.
The details of the new arrangements to borrow are that it will make available to the IMF an amount of up to $34 billion special drawing rights or $A61 billion, which compares to special drawing rights of $17 billion or $A30‐odd million under the general arrangements to borrow. This meets the requirement of the G10 that the facility be doubled in size. In respect of that overall amount, Australia's share will be $810 million special drawing rights or $A1.5 billion or thereabouts.
This new arrangement will not replace the general arrangements to borrow—it will be alongside them—but it will be the facility of first and principle recourse in the event of a need to provide supplementary finance to the IMF. The participants in the new arrangements to borrow, apart from the G10, are Australia, Austria, Denmark, Finland, Hong Kong, Republic of Korea, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Malaysia, Norway, Saudi Arabia—which had an associated arrangement with the GAB anyway—Spain, Singapore and Thailand. Thus, it is a markedly less Eurocentric group than the GAB, with a number of the dynamic east‐Asian economies represented as well as ourselves, Kuwait and some other Europeans, in addition, of course, to the G10.
It is, accordingly, a much stronger and more durable arrangement than the GAB, with 13 more countries involved—a total facility worth twice the credit available to the IMF under the GAB. It, therefore, represents a major strengthening of the international monetary system which, in a world where vast amounts of private capital wash around the world everyday and which can suddenly take flight in a devastating way, this is a great reassurance in the durability of the system.
Nevertheless, it is no guarantee that countries which do not adhere to sound economic policies will be free from concern.
