What the Mexico crisis demonstrated quite clearly was that, apart from the need for substantial financial resources to be available to a country facing capital flight, there is also an acute need to ensure that the economic policies in that country are such as to return the nation to economic stability. The crisis in Mexico only subdued after its policies were changed, policies which caused great pain to the Mexican people but without which they would not have resolved their financial crisis despite the massive IMF bail out.
There are two additional points that I wish to raise. Firstly, in the event that Australia was required to make a contribution to the IMF fund of this facility, we could be required to produce $1.5 billion in a small period of time, which is not a small sum. This will either have to be borrowed by the Commonwealth—and provision for that is contained in this bill—or, in the event of a budget surplus, repayment of our debt would presumably be reduced to that extent. It is comforting to note that this would not have implications for the budget balance as it would be treated as a financing transaction below the line, which accords with international accounting practice.
I would note, however, that, when I was Treasurer, the means of financing Australia's contribution that was then being contemplated by Treasury was for a line of credit from the
Reserve Bank of Australia to the IMF, not for it to be financed directly by the Commonwealth. This appears to be the way a number of countries have approached this issue, with Germany, Hong Kong, Sweden and Switzerland all represented in the new arrangements to borrow, not by their government, but by their central bank, which would seem to indicate that any call on those notions would be met directly by the central bank not the government. I would appreciate it if, in reply—if we are going to have one—the minister would advise the committee why it was that Treasury changed its mind on this issue and decided on government finance through the consolidated revenue fund rather than through the Reserve Bank.
Finally, this is one of those measures on which both sides of the House can feel some pleasure and, indeed, ownership of a successful outcome in which Australia has played a leading role. I would particularly like to congratulate the Treasury officials involved for their constructive, innovative contribution on this matter, which broke an international deadlock and provided the means of considerably improving the safety and security of the international monetary system.
Mr KATTER
(Kennedy)
(11.00 a.m.)
—The previous speaker alluded to the fact that this bill is before us as a result of what happened in Mexico. It is a very good investment of time to study what occurred in Mexico and what is occurring today in Mexico. For those of you who like listening to radio or tapes as you are driving along, I would strongly urge you to listen to Tom Fitzgerald's Boyer lectures of some years ago. Tom Fitzgerald was the
Sydney Morning Herald
economics editor, and in that very fine exposition, he assessed the Australian economy and where it was going. He passed a very, very harsh judgment upon us. Let me quote verbatim from the lecture. He said:
At no point of time in the future will the current account come into a state of balance. In fact, each year that we proceed, this country will go further and further in debt and have to carry the sins of the past which will be imposed upon the Australians of the future.
The current account deficit has been fluctuating up and down, but there is no doubt that we are talking about a baseline which most certainly, if it is not rising, is staying static. That being the case, the country with each preceding year, as Fitzgerald said in those lectures, will become worse and worse off. As the Australian debt rises, the interest and repayments on that debt keep building upon themselves and have an exponential effect.
We have come from a state where we had $23,000 million owing to foreign institutions. We now have a situation in Australia where around $200,000 million is owing to financial institutions. That is not getting better, but each day is getting worse, which brings me to the subject of the IMF. When you get really bad, the IMF steps in and starts dictating to you the policy that you carry out in your country.
The economies of Central and South America are often portrayed in the American media as if they were those of irresponsible Latin people who really could not run a country properly. I think a more fair assessment of Central and South America is the complete domination of those economies by the interests of the United States and the complete domination and submergence of their national interests to the national interests of those of the United States. With the United States now in a position that it is dictating policy to Mexico, it is very hard to see how that country can realise upon the potential of its citizens. If someone else is calling the tune in your country, then of course you are not in a very happy situation. Sovereignty is not a word that has much meaning to you.
Clearly, if we can go in a period of one decade from $23,000 million to $200,000 million, the situation is a very, very desperate one in this country today. In reflecting upon this, I must reflect upon the fact that we have a very narrow base of export earnings in this country—a very, very narrow base indeed. In fact, only eight items comprise 60 or 70 per cent of this nation's entire income—the big eight. Throw in the tourism industry and it is the big nine. Of those, four of them are agricultural products—cattle, wool, wheat and sugar.
The cattle numbers are down by 25 or 30 per cent on where they were a decade or so ago. Wool is down by some 30 or 40 per cent—depending upon which set of figures which you wish to rely on—and falling. In the cattle industry, one‐quarter of the trade within two years will be live cattle: instead of selling a beast for $1,500 per head, we will be selling it for only $300 per head, and the current account implications of that are very diabolical. We are growing wheat everywhere we can in Australia now, and so there is no chance of expansion in wheat.
When Thailand gets over the drought that they have been having, and when the restrictions upon Cuba are removed, the price of sugar is expected to fall through the floor. ABARE's predictions are very grim indeed for the sugar industry. The outlook in agriculture is diabolical indeed. The implications for the IMF and the current account for this country are very grim indeed.
Turning to mining, I was saying the other day that, under the level playing field idea, the big international mining companies will impose upon Australia the same wage levels that they have in South America and other countries which, for a number of reasons, we used to refer to as Third World countries. I said that the wage structure of such countries as Chile will be imposed upon the mining industry of Australia, and that CRA has mines in both of those countries, so why would it treat our miners better than it treats their miners?
I was very surprised to be rebutted by being told that the wages in Chile are very similar to the wages in Australia. These countries are leaping forward. They now have sophisticated staff to mine their mines over there. They enjoy, in spite of the remarks that I have just made, wage advantages over this country. Also, because of the enormous power of the multinational companies in Central and South America and in Africa—countries which are economically on their knees and which desperately need the mining revenue, and so are prepared to give the mining companies anything they want—such things as environmental considerations are not taken much notice of in Africa or South America; and that gives them tremendous advantages, cost wise, over us.
We are looking at copper, one of the big eight in Australia, falling straight through the floor because five massive overseas mines are coming on stream and we cannot possibly compete against them. Russia is opening up huge areas—and it must have far and away the most extensive mineral resources in the world; but, because of communism, it has not been able to competitively exploit those resources which, of course, it now can. So our mining industry, which has been the juggernaut of the Australian economy, is in a very grave situation indeed.
Finally, on tourism, at both the Gold Coast and Cairns we are getting figures of 20 and 30 per cent reductions in tourism for this year. In all three sectors of the economy that we rely upon, the outlook is diabolical indeed. If you think there is going to be a turnaround in the current account, I have got grim news for you, my friend—grim news indeed.
Having said all those things, I come back to the fact that there is no point in putting our heads in the sand. We have to face up to reality. If you are wanting to know what needs to be done to address the problems that are going to rapidly arise for Australia—with respect to
the IMF and the fact that we might be not a country that is called upon to put in money but one that has to ask for money and have terms dictated to us—we have to look at where the problems lie in the Australian economy.
Let us look at the most successful economy on earth—and this has a lot to do with other implications of the IMF proposals that are coming forward here. The most successful economy on earth, by far and away, is Japan. Its balance of payments—to be technical—was $130,000 million. To put that in perspective, ours was a deficit of nearly $20,000 million, whilst theirs was a surplus of $130,000 million. The United States had a deficit last year of $106,000 million. Japan has an enormously successful economy. What makes it so different from the other economies on earth?
One other statistic which I should refer to is that the average income of a person in Japan is $36,000; the average income of an American is $24,000. That is quite remarkable. I was very surprised at that figure, which the library provided to me, and I confirmed it from the United States and Japan. Why is Japan so enormously successful? I think the major answer to that is in interest rates. The average interest rate in Australia in 1995 were 7.7 per cent, the average interest rate in Japan was 1.2 per cent, and the average interest rate in the United States was six per cent.
Clearly, if business and development oriented business can access interest rates that are that low, they will move forward with great confidence and with very little fear imposed upon them. Clearly, that is the biggest differentiating statistic that one can look at in characterising the Japanese economy. If you want to wind back to before the bolsheviks, the socialists, took over Australia, we had a situation where our agricultural and other developing industries, most certainly mining in the case of Queensland, could access money—
Mr Bevis
—An agrarian socialist revolution!
Mr KATTER
—If I am providing interest rates of one per cent to business, I think I am very much on the side of business. Until our friends sitting opposite took over the running of this country with their enlightened economic rationalism—which they now seem to be running away from, after having imposed that disaster upon Australia for 13 years—we could access money through the Primary Industry Bank, the Commonwealth Development Bank, through QIDC in Queensland and various similar institutions in the other states. There was a whole range of financial institutions through which anyone who had a business which would result in the growth of the Australian economy, or a development oriented project, could access interest rates far, far lower than the rates that applied to the rest of Australia.
Compounded on that was the removal of every other way of controlling the economy in Australia except interest rates. To quote again from Fitzgerald's lectures, the `bluntest of blunt instruments' was used to control the Australian economy—one single blunt instrument. If we had a very bad inflationary problem, as we did, starting with the Whitlam regime—if I could score a political point here—which would create great problems in terms of the International Monetary Fund and our situation financially with the other states of the world, it had to be restrained. So we restrained it with massive interest rates. In days past, we used statutory reserve deposits, and that sort of mechanism, to pull in a situation of inflation.
Admittedly, there were other factors involved, such as wages. But our relationship financially with the rest of the world, which is governed by the International Monetary Fund, was very seriously placed in jeopardy by the inflationary pressures that existed. We used that one single blunt instrument called interest rates and we used that instrument to put rates up enormously
high, to 15 per cent and at one stage even 20 per cent, throughout this country. Of course, when you were competing against the Japanese economy, where interest rates were down around two and three per cent, you were going to take one massive hiding in the international competitive trade arena. That is most certainly what occurred to Australia during that period. We took one massive hiding because our businesses that wanted to get off the ground could not possibly borrow money at that level. Day after day, those that existed were falling over. Bankruptcies in Australia rose from around 4,000 in 1983 to 17,500 last year, and they are still rising as a result of that.
If we could go back and impose the enlightened attitude of a sovereign Australia where we provided investment opportunities with interest rates that were comparable to the rest of the world and, in many cases, much lower than the rest of the world—there was the 60‐40 arrangement in Australia where a very large percentage of all superannuation funds had to go into government banks and that money was rechannelled back out into the economy—we would not be mendicants of the IMF, but playing a useful role in helping other countries as we did some 15 years ago before the madness of economic rationalism took over this country.
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
(Maranoa—
Minister for Veterans' Affairs)
(11.16 a.m.)
—Let me start by thanking speakers in this debate. It is a very important bill. I would just like to record my appreciation, also, for the opposition's support which was indicated in the contribution from the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis).
As has been noted, the key impetus for the New Arrangements to Borrow, to which this bill provides for Australia's participation, were the difficulties experienced in Mexico in late 1994 and the associated concerns about the adequacy of the IMF's resources to cope with possible future crises of the international financial systems. The New Arrangements to Borrow were progressively developed from that point following those events. Australia played a very significant role in the establishment of the New Arrangements to Borrow and for this we can be justly proud. The member for Gellibrand, I am sure, recalls his time in government when this initiative was developed.
As has already been noted, this bill essentially serves two purposes. Firstly, it will enable Australia to adhere to the International Monetary Fund's New Arrangements to Borrow, and, secondly, it will simplify the framework for Australia's financial transactions with the IMF. The New Arrangements to Borrow, the NAB, as it is shortened to, will double the IMF's capacity to borrow to forestall or cope with an impairment of the international monetary system, or to deal with an exceptional situation that poses a threat to the stability of that system. The NAB will therefore enhance the IMF's ability to safeguard the international monetary system.
Under the NAB, Australia may be called on to lend up to SDR$810 million, or about A$1.5 billion to the IMF. There is flexibility in this arrangement. In certain circumstances, Australia will be able to opt out of a call under the NAB and may also request early repayment of a loan under the NAB. Participants in the NAB will meet once a year to review and discuss macro‐economic and financial market developments, especially those that could have an impact on the stability of the international financial system. This is potentially an important new forum for consideration of these issues.
The bill introduces a simplified framework for the conduct and recording of Australia's regular financial transactions with the IMF. Under the new framework, the transactions will
be conducted in a more transparent and cost‐efficient manner. The amendments proposed in the bill will have no impact on the Commonwealth budget outlays, or on the budget balance.
The member for Gellibrand raised a question during his contribution. He asked why the government has decided to finance a call under the NAB through the CRF. The government wanted the Commonwealth to be a participant in the NAB because decisions on whether to opt out of a call raised very critical policy issues that necessitate a proposed method. And, so that the proposed method is also consistent with the way we conduct our other transactions with the IMF, it is therefore an appropriate response from the government. Again, may I express my appreciation for the contributions and the participation of the people in the debate today and also indicate to the opposition that we thank them for their support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
COMMONWEALTH VEHICLES (REGISTRATION AND EXEMPTION FROM TAXATION) BILL 1997
Cognate bill:
COMMONWEALTH MOTOR VEHICLES (LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1997
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by
Mr Fahey
:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Mr PETER BALDWIN
(Sydney)
(11.21 a.m.)
—The Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill and the cognate bill seek to maintain the exemption from state taxes and charges applying to Commonwealth vehicles. The minister in his speech tried to imply that this was just a technical amendment required to maintain the status quo once the government privatises Dasfleet. Nothing could be further from the truth. The privatisation of Dasfleet would represent a change in ownership of the vehicles. The minister advanced no reason why everyone else should pay state taxes and charges on their vehicles but not the Commonwealth.
Why should the `battlers' we kept hearing about from the other side before the last election have to pay their motor vehicle taxes and charges, but not the Commonwealth? This is the essence of the issue here.
What about the government's supposed commitment to the principles of competitive neutrality? The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) said on 20 August 1996:
The application of full competitive neutrality will mean that DAS businesses will face equivalent payments, debt guarantee fees and dividend payments, even when they are competing for Commonwealth Government contracts.
At the first whiff of grapeshot, these principles go out the window.
This issue also exposes the government's hypocritical approach to privatisation. Contrary to the minister's words about public sector reform, these bills expose the fact that the sole purpose of privatising Dasfleet is to get an artificial boost to the budget bottom line.
If privatisation is such a good financial deal, why does it need a subsidy? Such a subsidy is at the expense of state taxpayers, schools, hospitals, police services and all the other things state governments are responsible for. What about the attempt of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to impose all Commonwealth taxes on the states last year? One would have thought that what was good for the goose is good for the gander, but not when it comes to this government.
As indicated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) at estimates hearings, we will not be opposing the bills. We have no intention of obstructing the government on a matter like this, but we do believe that Australians be should be aware of what the government is trying to pull.
Mr FAHEY
(Macarthur—
Minister for Finance)
(11.24 a.m.)
—I thank the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) for his very brief contribution. Nothing could be further from the truth in terms of the government's asset sale program. Effectively what these bills do is to maintain the status quo. Currently the taxes and charges, the self‐insurance provisions, apply in respect of the Commonwealth's fleet. It is the intention of the government, as it was the intention of the former government, to dispose of that car fleet. Effectively, this legislation maintains the current position, despite the fact that the cars will be owned by the private sector and leased back to the Commonwealth.
In that regard, the member for Sydney indicated that the government sought to impose these taxes and charges—that is, the Commonwealth's taxes and charges in respect of motor vehicles, the stamp duty provisions, the sales tax provisions—on the states during the course of the special Premiers Conference last year. That was not the case. In that instance, the Commonwealth gave the option to the states to make their contribution to fiscal consolidation either by way of the financial assistance grants or by way of imposing a very transparent and very up‐front process on such issues in respect of motor vehicles as sales tax.
The states chose—in my view, surprisingly—to maintain their advantage in respect of motor vehicles, particularly on the sales tax exemption, and to make their contribution by way of a reduction for 2½ years in respect of the financial assistance grants. So the member for Sydney has got it wrong. This particular bill will enable the Commonwealth to simply get out of the ownership of a very large fleet of some 18,000 vehicles. There is no need for the Commonwealth to be the owner of that. The provision of those vehicles can be supplied, as it is to many states and to many private companies, by the private sector, and the provisions that currently apply will apply in that regard. It does not give an advantage to the private sector in any shape or form. It simply maintains the provisions that are now there to the extent that there is a need to have that fleet and there always will be. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
COMMONWEALTH MOTOR VEHICLES (LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1997
Second Reading
Consideration resumed from 28 May, on motion by
Mr Fahey
:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

Consideration in Detail

Proposed expenditure, $10,937,163,000.

Proposed expenditure, $1,982,406,000.
Mr BEVIS
(Brisbane)
(11.29 a.m.)
—The budget appropriations this year for Defence are particularly important. They address a whole range of important policy initiatives and a series of decisions that the current government has made. In fact, it has been a period of more decisions than policy, regrettably; a period in which there has been decision by press release, in which there has been an absence of policy, and in which our neighbours look with some bewilderment at what it is that Australia now sees for itself in terms of its own security and its interaction with the region and the wider world. Regrettably, it has also been a period in which a string of decisions without any direction or policy has produced, within the ranks of service personnel and people in the department, a drop in morale which is now reaching proportions of serious concern.
During the course of the consideration in detail of this bill, I hope to make a number of contributions dealing with a series of different topics. At the outset, it is important to comment on the confusing signals which this government has been issuing in relation to its view of its place in the region. No strategic analysis has been released. In fact, I believe that no proper strategic analysis has been undertaken by this government.
A little over a year ago when this government came to office it had the opportunity to endorse the former government's strategic analysis or to institute a new one. The Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) and the government decided to do neither at that time. Subsequently, the government has decided that it will institute its own strategic review. Unfortunately, it has decided to do that far too late in its three‐year term. That is compounded by the fact that, without any concept of a strategic review in mind, it set about making some of the most
significant changes to the defence force structure this country has seen in more than two generations.
The minister has proclaimed the army restructure and the defence efficiency review in those terms, and yet they have been done without any consideration of what it is that Australia needs to defend itself. It has been done without any consideration of what it is that Australia confronts in the region and in the world, or of what our place in the region and the world is.
Having jumped step 1 and step 2, which should have been a proper force structure analysis, we have no strategic review and no force structure analysis, this government has set about a major restructure of the army. It has set about a major restructure of the defence organisation—I will say some more about the DER later. Suffice to say at this point that the defence efficiency review is not something I regard as being confined to administrative matters. I will detail my reasons for that subsequently, but the DER clearly goes beyond administrative considerations in matters of efficiency and, in doing so, should have been at least delayed until there was some serious concept in the mind of this government of our place in the world.
That is not the case. It has become very evident in a series of statements made by the minister that either he has a confused view, or that the department and his office have a confused view. On each occasion that these confused views have been put into the public domain and reported accordingly, the minister has replied the next day, saying how he has been terribly misquoted. The first time that happened last year—and I can recall it quite well, as it was at a conference here in Parliament House in May—I gave the minister the benefit of the doubt and thought, `Well, fair enough, some poor journalist has given the wrong slant to it.'
However, it happened some months later when the minister appeared on the Channel 9
Sunday
program—I think it was last July. He made the offhand comment that the Americans might like to establish a naval base in Darwin. When these ideas are thrown around by senior ministers of the government in the public domain they actually have some importance. They have some weight. That is the sort of offhand comment a minister might make in a private conversation. He might get away with it as a second‐rate shadow minister, but a minister should not get away with it when he has the responsibility of government on his desk and the responsibility of the defence forces on his shoulders. He should not make statements like that in his position.
He also should not have talked about the upcoming meetings with American senior officials following shortly after that
Sunday
program in July.
(Extension of time granted)
It became clear in subsequent meetings with the officials in the United States that they had no interest in talking about a naval base, or even something less substantial than that. At the same time the minister was floating the prospect—and it was not just the Minister for Defence, as I think the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Downer) got into the act as well—of prepositioning American equipment in Australia.
As I recall, when the US Secretary of Defense was asked by the Australian media about that on the eve of the talks, he said, `It is not on the agenda.' The Americans had no interest in pursuing it yet, for some weeks prior to that, senior government ministers were floating those ideas around. I think it was part of a public relations spin that the government wanted to put on its defence policy. It wanted to somehow say, `Our defence posture is different from the former government's defence posture and, in relation to our critical alliance with the United
States, as a new Liberal government, as a new coalition government, our relationship is better than the former Labor government's relationship with America.'
I can understand why the government, for some political gain, might want to put that twist on it, but everybody in the defence and foreign affairs organisation understands quite well that that was never the case. The relationship with the United States under the former government was extremely close, as it is under this government. That is only proper and it is something on which there is a bipartisan view. But putting that public relation spin on it, as the government sought to do, generated a lot of questions in the minds of people around the globe, and particularly in this part of the world, by talking about joint deployments with the United States troops in our region. When the government starts talking up joint deployments with the United States in our region, I guess a few people in the region start asking in which country in the region joint deployments are anticipated. I think that is not an unreasonable sort of response that people in the region might have to that sort of proposition.
I can recall the rhetoric that the government used, for example, in relation to the Tandem Thrust exercise, a major joint exercise. The government claimed great credit for having established the Tandem Thrust arrangements, saying that this was a new symbol of some closer ties when it was, frankly, a figment of the imagination of the PR people. I am indebted to the minister for acknowledging, on one occasion in the parliament, that the Tandem Thrust exercise was set in train by the former Labor government. It is not something that we have sought to criticise the government about.
What I do get concerned about is the small‐minded public relations spin that the government sought to put on the Tandem Thrust exercise in its early days and following the Ausmin talks, claiming it as theirs and trying to say, `Here's the evidence that we have a much closer relationship with America than the former Labor government.' But when there were a few questions, comments and concerns flying about regarding the Tandem Thrust exercise, we had the government saying, `Really, it wasn't the coalition's initiative. This was actually a Labor initiative and we followed it through.' Yes, it was a Labor initiative, and yes, the government did follow it through, and yes, we support that.
What the government seems not to understand is that the public relations spin it puts on these things has an impact not just on the Australian psyche but also on the views of others in the region, because it is not taken in isolation. It is taken on the back of the enormous incompetence displayed by the government, and particularly the foreign minister, in things like the DIFF program, which strained relations with many key countries. Those sorts of statements are seen together. They are seen together with the debate about the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and with the way in which the Prime Minister actually defended that member's right to go and say all the things she said. But then when people like the Lord Mayor of Brisbane come out and attack the member for Oxley what does the Prime Minister do? The Prime Minister actually attacks the Lord Mayor of Brisbane for having the hide to criticise her.
People in the region watch this, and they put it all together and say, `What is the new relationship with the United States that this new Liberal government talks about? What is their attitude to us, given what they have done to DIFF? What is their attitude to multiculturalism and engagement with the region when, at the most senior levels in government, they actively support the sorts of comments that the Independent member for Oxley makes and criticise those in the Labor Party who attack her?' All of those things go toward building confusion
in the region and they go directly to the question of national security, because so much of national security is about the perceptions which people have, one of the other, and their relationship with the region.
Let me go directly to some of the comments the minister has made.
(Extension of time granted)
The minister has complained, following a number of his speeches, that he has been unfairly treated by the media. I think that Brian Toohey, who I must confess is not one of the journalists I would often cite—
Mr Bruce Scott
—Well, why do you? It suits your argument.
Mr BEVIS
—Indeed—an occupational hazard that I am sure we are all guilty of. I think he belled the cat very accurately in his article in the
Australian Financial Review
a couple of weeks ago, on 12 June, when he said this:
For McLachlan no danger can be overlooked, no response ruled out, no matter how remote from Australian shores. At least that is the message when he speaks in public without a formal text. But there is another McLachlan—the one who reads out more restrained, officially prepared statements. The upshot is that an already complicated policy making task has become even more difficult.
He has belled the cat there. That is exactly the situation. It is such schizophrenia in statements which creates confusion for people here in Australia who are charged with implementing these policies, and it really does raise questions.
In their heart of hearts, people in the region think that fundamentally we are on the same course that we were on, but they scratch their heads and look with some bewilderment—it would not be so bad if they looked with amusement, but they actually look with some bewilderment—at the policy direction we are taking. Toohey makes the observation:
If McLachlan's instincts prevail, they will once again have to consider how to project—
`they' being the military planners—
Australian military force into the northern hemisphere.
According to departmental insiders, the best insight into the `authentic' McLachlan—the one whose extempore public utterances are an accurate reflection of his private views—can be gleaned from his remarks on
Meet the Press
on the Ten Network in April.
That
Meet the Press
interview certainly evoked a few responses around the country. I read the response that the minister gave to the
Courier‐Mail
, and managed to persuade the editorial writer at the
Courier‐Mail
to write an editorial on the Tuesday actually attacking their own front page of the day before. So, 10 out of 10 for your PR capability: I wish your strategic analysis was half as good, because you certainly did the job on the
Courier‐Mail
.
But let us look not just at what the
Courier‐Mail
said but at what everyone in the country said. When the minister spoke on
Meet the Press
, he made a whole series of statements which I will not go into on this occasion, as I am sure there will be another opportunity for me to do so. Let us have a look at what they said, because the minister said that he was improperly interpreted. He was improperly interpreted by everybody in Australia.
The
Sydney Morning Herald
heading said, `Our troops ready to help South Korea, Minister says.' The first sentence says, `The Minister for Defence, Mr McLachlan, has signalled that Australia will consider sending forces to help defend South Korea if starving and unstable North Korea launches a desperate attack.' The
Sydney Morning Herald
thought that was the tenor of what you were on about. The
Australian
said, `Our troops may fight in foreign conflicts.' The
Courier‐Mail
said, `Troops on call for war in Asia' and the first sentence of
that front page article said, `Troops could be sent to fight internal conflicts in Asia as Australia adopted a tougher approach to regional threats, Defence Minister Ian McLachlan said yesterday.'
The
Age
in Melbourne got it wrong, too, because it said, `Australia may fight in civil wars overseas.' So far, we have the
Australian
, the
Sydney Morning Herald
and the
Courier‐Mail
, and now the
Age
, getting it wrong. The
Age
said, `Australia may send troops overseas to help friendly nations fight civil wars in the future, the Defence Minister Ian McLachlan indicated yesterday.'
The
Daily Telegraph
got it wrong as well. We have got poor journalism in this country: all the papers misunderstood the minister! The minister clearly has an identification crisis here. The
Daily Telegraph
said, `World is our battlefield: Minister widens military posture.' The first sentence of that article is, `Defence Minister Ian McLachlan dramatically widened Australia's defence posture yesterday by saying Australian troops could be deployed anywhere freedom was under threat, including allies' international conflicts.'
The
Canberra Times
got it wrong as well. There is not a decent paper in the country, Minister. It is hard to get a good journalist. The
Canberra Times
had a heading that said, `Defence strategy switch: Minister'. The article introduction said, `Australia is preparing to significantly change its defence posture, rejecting the coastline defence strategy of the past decade and designing defence capabilities for action in the furthest reaches of the region.'
The
West Australian
misunderstood him as well. They said, `Defence strategy widened'. The
Advertiser
in Adelaide said `The nation's defence focus widens' and the first sentence was `Australian troops could be deployed anywhere freedom was under threat, the Defence Minister said.' And so it went on. But this was not the only occasion the minister has been misrepresented.
(Extension of time granted)
It is probably the most recent one, because those examples were from April this year, but I could cite a number of other examples. I have mentioned the
Sunday
program, and the views about the United States. There is one, though, that I should mention because it came up during the course of last week and the minister raised it in parliament, and it has to do with our relationship with China, which is a critically important relationship and, indeed, a very important area on which I would prefer to see a united bipartisan view.
I commend the decision of the Chief of the Defence Force to go to China. I note the progress that has been made there by him and Hugh White. I think that is a very worthwhile and desirable thing. Part of the problem is that we are in the process of patching up a relationship that has become worse because of blundering over the course of the last 15 months. The relationship Australia had with China was, I think, a very mature and mutually advantageous one at all levels and in all spheres, whether in terms of trade, security or diplomacy. The relationship with China that this government inherited from the former Labor government was a very good one indeed.
What we saw through those things I have just mentioned, and particularly the blundering of the foreign minister in the DIFF program, was a worsening of that relationship—not assisted, I might say, by the Minister for Defence. One of those occasions when he was no doubt misunderstood was in August last year when the
Australian
reported with the headline, `McLachlan criticises China'. Those sorts of statements that are made off the cuff by a senior minister and one with security responsibilities do us harm. It might be better if the briefs provided by departments to the minister, particularly in this area, were dealt with a little bit
more closely by the minister and we avoided these off‐the‐cuff comments. They do go to what happens to force structure. They actually do impact on your security in the region.
That goes back to my first point. The first thing this government should have done was sit down and, in its own mind, determine what it saw as our place in the world and what it saw as our strategic position. Frankly, had I been the incoming minister, that is exactly what I would have done. There should have been a new strategic review with the new incoming government and everyone would have said, `Fine, you're entitled to do that; go for it and make it public and put your stamp on it.'
Having done that, you then sort out what you think the structure of defence should be; you need to address that and you then set about building that structure. We skipped the first two steps with this government and went about making a whole series of changes in the structure. I think that is very much the cart before the horse.
I should make one final comment in terms of the strategic situation before I move on to other matters. That is to say that some time later this year the minister will have the final report of the strategic review. I would be willing to bet good money that the minister has already seen drafts of the strategic review. When that final document is available, I would simply urge him to ensure that there is a public release of a suitable document.
When this matter has been raised in the past—and it has been raised in estimates committees; it has been raised directly by the media with the minister—he has declined to give a commitment. In fact, at the estimates committee his departmental people nearly got stumped because they intuitively said, yes, there would be a publicly released version, only to be told very quickly that no, that is not the minister's position. They had to retract that in the estimates committee and say that this was a matter that the minister would give consideration to when the report was finally done.
Minister and Madam Deputy Speaker, the public release of a strategic review document I think is very important. We have led the region over the last decade in providing some transparency and in building confidence about what our view of the world is. We have encouraged other people in the region to do precisely the same and we have had success. In recent years we have seen a number of countries move to our model of a publicly released strategic review. It is a confidence building measure, not just between us and our neighbours, but amongst all the peoples of our region.
(Extension of time granted)
It is important that we do not retreat from making available a public document that sets out our view of the region. As I said, we have been successful in encouraging others in the region to do the same. The minister has not ruled it out but he has certainly cast doubt on that in the press conference at the release of the DER and again through the Senate estimates committee. If the minister can confirm that there will be a document publicly released, I can assure him that that decision will be greatly welcomed by me and the opposition.
There are a number of things that are important in terms of the structure, and I should make some comment about the defence efficiency review because, whilst the budget papers are scant in relation to that, certainly in this financial year we will see a number of very important changes made to the structure of the defence forces as a result of the defence review program. The defence efficiency review is now translated into a defence review program.
This defence review program is a bit like the phantom: it is everywhere and it is nowhere. This is the phantom set of documents or set of decisions. The minister might not just aid public debate and accountability in the parliament. He might help inform some of his own
senior staff who are somewhat bewildered, as are the rest of us, with what actually constitutes the government's response to the defence efficiency review.
The government has spoken about a DRP, defence review program, and we have had press releases from the minister, as is his want, to announce major changes—press releases, again, without policy. So we have this series of decisions, and one of them says, `There is going to be a defence review program and we intend to have the whole lot of this in place by 1 July.' One of the things that became apparent after about six minutes of questioning at the Senate estimate's committee only last week is that, at the most senior levels, the people in the Defence Department have not got a clue what the DRP is. That is not because they are not good and proper officials, it is because the direction and guidance from government is simply not there.
Let us see a consolidated DRP. Let us see a consolidated government response. Let us see the detail of what the government plans to do in pursing those matters that were identified by the defence efficiency review. It does not exist. There is not even a collation of orders from the CDF. There is no document that can be identified. There is no collation of documents that can be identified as the defence review program. If there is, I would invite the minister to describe it, identify them in this debate. Better still, let them become available for some sort of public scrutiny or at least let a public version of them become available so that the people of Australia will have some idea of what it is that this government intends to do with the defence forces of Australia.
It is a fairly fundamental area of accountability I would have thought. The government should tell the people of Australia what it is doing with the defence forces of Australia. To date, what we have got is a one‐page press release and a lot of confused answers from senior officers of the Department of Defence who themselves are trying to figure out what the heck it is that the government wants of them. This is a major management question that the government has simply glossed over.
Let me go to some of the things that are probably in the defence review program because they are certainly in the defence efficiency review, at least that document is public. There is to be a significant cut in the number of defence personnel. We are, I think, anticipating a civilian and uniform personnel, full‐time, change of 8,000 positions, 5,000 of those being uniform. Of those 5,000 uniform positions, about 2,200 are anticipated to be shifted to other areas, which leaves you with a net cut between 2,500 and 3,000 uniformed personnel. That is in the first tranche.
There is a second tranche that covers some 13,000 positions and, of those 13,000 positions, I believe 5,000 of those are uniform. I believe the estimate of how many uniform positions are likely to go out of that is about 3,000. So we are looking at a reduction in uniformed strength of about 5,000 directly as a result of this efficiency review. This goes to force structure. It is not about how to make the place run more efficiently. It is changing the very bricks and mortar that make up the defence force. This is force structure.
Who did this review? It was not done by people experienced in force structure and defence matters, it was done by a committee, half of whose members have experience in financial management.
(Extension of time granted)
They are people who work for Western Mining, people who manage the funds in AMP, and John Stone of all people, a former discredited, defeated National Party senator and former Secretary of the Treasury.
They are people who you might actually want to look through accounting procedures, but they are not the people who you ask, `How many soldiers do you need? How many aircrew
do you need? Do you need a RAAF base in Richmond?' They are the decisions they have made. These are people whose expertise in defence you could write on the back of a postage stamp, and you handed to them the opportunity to restructure the entire defence force—and that is what they have done.
Let us forget all this gobbledegook about how it was only about efficiency and saving dollars. When you cut 5,000 uniform people and about another 10,000 civilians out of an organisation, when you propose the sale of major defence bases, when you propose to amalgamate the first division deployable headquarters with NORCOM—which is actually in your DER documents—when you propose those sorts of fundamental force structure changes, forget about all this rhetoric telling me and others that this is about efficiencies. It has got nothing to do with efficiencies—well, it does to the extent that those people were set a task of finding somewhere between $500 million and $1,000 million a year, and they did that for you. But in doing that, they went to the very heart of force structure questions.
Again, they did all this without any guidance on what our strategic position was—that is, what is the threat against which we are establishing a force structure? So they have gone about doing all those things in the absence of any of that policy, and the people who did it were the wrong people anyway.
What are we going to end up with after army restructure, the defence efficiency review and the other cuts in the budget to staffing? My recollection is that the budget also cuts the establishment of uniform personnel by 1,000, which is separate to those cuts I have just mentioned.
At the end of the day, we will end up with a permanent uniform force in Australia of about 50,000 people, and the end of the day is pretty soon. The end of the day is about two or three years down the track. We will have 50,000 full‐time uniform personnel. In army, air force and navy, the total strength will be 50,000 full‐time uniform personnel. That represents the lowest number of full‐time uniform personnel that Australia has had since 1962. This government will preside over a cut in uniform strength in the full‐time defence personnel to levels not seen since 1962.
Army is personnel intensive. Army says of air force and navy that they crew the equipment—or, to use the sexist terminology, they man the equipment—but, in army, you equip the man, you equip the soldier. In army, where it is people intensive, as part of this process this government has initiated, the permanent numbers will be reduced to 20,000 full‐time people. That is the lowest number of full‐time uniform personnel in the army this country has seen since 1951.
That is the result of what the government have done, and they have done all this without a strategic review and without a force structure analysis. They will reduce the defence forces to their lowest level in 40 years, without any concept of where we are in the region and what the structure of our forces should be to address that analysis. That is gross incompetence. But worse than gross incompetence, it presents for Australia a major problem. If at the next election there is a change of government, it will present for us, as the new government, with major challenges to put right those things which you will already have undone.
The course the government have set upon is not something that can be reversed overnight. I think the government have made a number of serious mistakes in the way in which they have gone about these things—as they did when they decided to abolish the ready reserve.
The ready reserve ended this year. It was one of the most capable brigades in the organisation. The pity of it was that the minister chose not to accept the advice of the army and the chiefs in the ADF about the need to retain the ready reserve. He stuck to a fairly blinkered dogma that he inherited from his predecessor, the shadow minister in the last parliament. That was a wrong decision.
(Extension of time granted)
Some of those young men and women who made up the ready reserve will regrettably be departing the scene. They chose not to be in the general reserve. They chose to be in the ready reserve. Some of them certainly will want to be in the permanent force, and I know a number have transferred to the permanent force.
Many of them specifically wanted to be in the ready reserve because it was unique and had a different set of conditions and opportunities. I fear that many of those people will walk out the door. We will lose those very young, capable and talented people. I would urge the government to reconsider that. It was the wrong decision and I would happily publicly applaud a decision of the government to re‐establish it.
I have touched on the question of army restructure in passing in terms of the global numbers. A number of things about the army restructure which give rise to concern are embedded in the budget proposals before us at the moment. Again, the degree to which this amount of change is understood and to which there is a plan and it fits with the defence efficiency review or DRP is a cause of a great deal of confusion.
I want to make some comment about the Holsworthy base because that has come under some significant scrutiny. The Department of Defence has a committee that is looking at what they will do, if Holsworthy has to close as a defence base, to make way for a second airport. As the minister should know, that committee has also had to consider not just what happens at Holsworthy, but also the impact on surrounding airports—both civil and military—and the impact on the opportunity for live firing ranges in that important part of Australia.
The government is moving much closer to a decision of having Holsworthy as the second Sydney airport. I think that is an insane proposition. Assuming that they can overcome the problems of unexploded ordnance—and we do need to understand this has been a live firing range since the Rum Corps days—and assuming that they do not mind bulldozing through gorges that are 150 feet high, most of which have been laden with unexploded ordnance over the last 100 years or so, the minister might like to comment on what the budgetary implications will be for the $150 million worth of new buildings that have been erected in and around the Holsworthy base over the last five years. Some, I think, would be ongoing. They certainly were in the last budget and possibly are in this budget.
The minister might like to tell us what he proposes to do with those facilities that are costly, purpose‐built and brand new, if Sydney's second airport happens to be a stone's throw away from them. He might also like to tell us where the assets would be relocated to, what the cost of that would be and whether Defence will be supplemented for any of those things.
All of this has meant that personnel in the Defence Force have had to endure a series of changes without any clear guidance. They have had to endure the uncertainty of not knowing whether they have a job. They have had to endure the uncertainty that, even if they have a job after this round of cuts, they can look forward to the prospect that sometime in the next couple of years there will be a fresh round of cuts and their head might be in the noose for that one. That would be bad enough.
Unfortunately, the government has decided to injure Defence personnel through other measures. The Medicare surcharge, for example, is unlike the basic Medicare charge which Defence personnel have a rebate on. If they have a family, they only pay half the Medicare fee because Defence picks up the service person's costs. For reasons best known to the government, they decided to slug the Defence personnel with the entire surcharge rather than half of it.
Mr Fitzgibbon
— Bishop was rolled.
Mr BEVIS
—Yes, it would not be hard. They have decided to impose upon service personnel the new superannuation surcharge tax for those people who do no more than agree to their request to stay on as pilots and air traffic controllers. What they did not tell all those people who took the retention bonus is that, if they were not already over the threshold, this will put them over the threshold.
For the great bulk of those people who the government went to and asked to stay on as pilots or air traffic controllers, on the one hand you gave them a retention bonus and, without telling them, with the other hand, you took away a big bundle of money out of their superannuation through your new superannuation surcharge tax. I am sure they will be delighted to learn about that. It was a fairly underhanded way of doing it.
I think the least the government could have done was to have been upfront and honest with those people and said, `Look, if you take this surcharge, this will be the implications for your superannuation.' You did not do that.
(Extension of time granted)
The last issue that I want to talk about is defence industry. This budget is going to span a very critical period in defence industry matters. There will be the sale of ADI, if we can take the minister's comments at face value, and the legislated sale of AIDC, which brings with it the prospect of the sale of the government's shareholdings in the Submarine Corporation. In this area, I have to say that defence industry policy is not much different from general government industry policy: it is non‐existent. If its strategic policy is one of the spaghetti bowl approach to clarity, then I have to say that its industry policy is simply not there at all. That is the case in defence industry as it is generally in industry.
Any person in this parliament, from either side of politics, who spends more than five minutes talking to industry leaders will be told that up‐front very quickly because they are angry and confused: angry because, by and large, they supported the election of this government, and very angry that, having done that, they now find industry policy jettisoned.
I make a couple of quick observations about that. An article in the
Australian Financial Review
in March this year, noted:
The manufacturing sector said yesterday that Government cost cutting in the last Federal Budget had almost halted a decade of growth in manufactured exports by the end of 1996.
And the government was also told that the lack of a comprehensive industry policy focused on winning and retaining investment could result in much of Australia's installed production base disappearing in coming years as multinational companies reassessed their current investments.
What that means is that there is no industry policy. They are saying that there is a lack of comprehensive industry policy, and they are right. In defence terms, the person charged with that responsibility is the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop). You have got to say that that is probably part of the problem rather than part of the solution. The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel has given to coining a phrase, `Bishop's principles'. She actually gives speeches at industry forums, trying to talk up her own self‐importance by referring to Bishop's principles.
I spend a lot of time talking to people in industry, and have done for some years, particularly when I was chairing the parliament's industry committee and I have not heard one of them refer to Bishop's principles. But the minister has a habit of referring to Bishop's principles. She gave great heart to the industry sector when she gave a speech in February of this year on defence and industry—future directions under a coalition government. The hard‐hitting part of it where she was laying down the markers—this is what Minister Bishop was going to do for defence industry—she came on strong and said, `It can also count on my personal support.' This is where we get to the important part, because here is the minister responsible and you expect a bit of heavyweight punching power. She went on to tell people what it was that she was going to provide as this personal commitment. She said, `I'll help in any way I can with letters of support, telephone calls, visits or whatever is required.' Now there is some hard‐hitting policy development for you! The Minister for Defence Industry has said, `I'll do anything I can to help you. I'll write letters. I'll make phone calls.' The fact of life is that she is a standing joke in the defence industry community. The pity of it is that defence industry policy has gone down the drain in the same way general industry policy has.
That really is a major problem and it can be glossed over, but the government has abandoned the defence industry systems that were put in place. Indeed, DER recommends that things like the defence industry development program be abolished. The government is going to do those things. It is going to take away the small measure of support that was there. There are success stories out of the DID program and, of course, there are failures. Any investment of that kind is going to reap failures as well as successes.
The simple fact is that, in a process of looking at dollars and having no concept of where we are heading with defence, these decisions have been taken which are harmful and destructive to defence industry. Defence industry is critical to defence capability, and the minister and the government will say that. Unfortunately, they have done nothing to substantiate those words. Worse, they have stripped away measures that were in place before.
I commend to the minister the opposition's policy on heavy engineering and shipbuilding, which I am sure he has. By all means steal ours, but do something to help defence industry so that we are not left with a situation where, as well as having to rebuild the defence forces when we get re‐elected next time, we will have to rebuild defence industry as well.
Mr McLACHLAN
(Barker—
Minister for Defence)
(12.10 p.m.)
—I was pleased that the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), the shadow minister for defence, after the first two five‐minute tranches, finally got to 1997, having thrashed about a bit on events of last year. I was also pleased that the honourable member has chosen not to put about the sort of nonsense that he put about last year when, after all, we are supposed to be talking about Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997-98. Last year he claimed that there was a decrease in actual outlays in last year's budget even though he had spent a long period of time being educated by some of the people from the department.
I also noticed that the fellow he quoted, Brian Toohey, is saying the same thing this time, not that there was a decrease as the shadow minister said last year, but that there was an increase. Obviously, the shadow minister has been back at his books and learnt a few things and he will notice that we have, in fact, stuck exactly to what we said we were going to do, which was to neither decrease nor increase the budget this year—
Mr Bevis
—On the Labor government's estimates.
Mr McLACHLAN
—Yes, on the Labor government's estimates, simply because we have no option but to hold defence at the level of expenditure which was in the forward estimates, much as I personally would like to see the defence budget increased. I have said that publicly and I am sure that there are one or two other people in this room who would like the same result.
As for Bishop's principles, perhaps you could listen to one or two words from the Archbishop and then we would get to a slightly better conclusion than the one we got to in the last 20 minutes.
I was disappointed to hear the shadow minister carrying on about the sorts of things that happened last year. I know that, prior to discussing the enhanced arrangements that we finally concluded with the Americans, there were a number of things on the table. We did not discuss all of them publicly and we certainly did not discuss all of them with the shadow minister. But when we looked at what sort of enhanced arrangements we might make with the Americans, we certainly did discuss them with our senior regional neighbours beforehand, and I have said that publicly before.
So the stories that were put about by some people in the press at that time, and since, about our neighbours being worried, are nonsense.
Mr Laurie Ferguson interjecting
—
Mr McLACHLAN
—We gave you a bit of fun. You are sitting over there somnambulating away, you can do the same thing up the front.
The stories that are being put about now by some of the press that some of our regional neighbours are worried about these enhanced arrangements is nonsense because our neighbours are not worried. They have not said they were worried, and they were not worried before those arrangements were made.
That leads me to say something about our major northern regional neighbour, and that is China. As I reported in the parliament the other day, there have been certain meetings taking place in recent times. The CDF was up there last year. We have had the chief of the air force up there. We have had the VCDF up there recently, and Hugh White, as you said.
There is absolutely no doubt that we had some difficulties with the Chinese last year, and they had some difficulties with us, but we have talked those over in some depth. Some of those difficulties arose out of the Taiwan issue, some of them arose out of matters to do with the Dalai Lama, and there were others. We have spoken to the ambassador and other Chinese officials, and the Prime Minister has discussed those matters also.
We have now come to a settled series of arrangements where the Chinese have no difficulty with Australia's relations with the US and they do not see Australia's enhanced arrangements with the US as being directed against China. That is their view and that has been their view, even though we have had some differences in the past with the Chinese. That is the nature of relationships between peoples.
I will need to continue talking, as I cannot possibly address the mishmash of subjects that the shadow minister addressed. There seemed, in many cases, to be no logic to his points and I do not intend to spend much time addressing them.
(Extension of time granted)
I will, however, address one or two of his points. Firstly, I noticed that the shadow minister threw up this matter of the sale of some facilities. He knows very well that the Defence Efficiency
Review suggested an extra 33 properties or so that were not on the Labor Party's list. These sorts of lists—
Mr Bruce Scott
—Labor Party lists?
Mr McLACHLAN
—Yes, the Labor Party sold 70‐odd properties in the last four or five years for $180 million. These lists amount to further sales of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of defence properties. He also knows that with the DER those extra 30‐odd properties would come up for evaluation in the same way as every one of these properties on your lists were evaluated for possible sale or to be kept.
When the shadow minister rushes around the country saying, `I am prepared to sign a document that we will not sell Richmond,' does he mean the same document that the Labor Party would have been prepared to sign when it said it would not sell government instrumentalities such as Qantas and TAA and the rest of them? It would have to be an enhanced document. It would have to have gold edges around it. Quite frankly, the fact of the matter is that nobody would believe you.
The shadow minister knows very well that it is our responsibility to evaluate very cautiously all the facilities we own. You can bet your boots that in 100 years time most of the facilities we have now will either be changed, sold, revamped or whatever. In each of those cases there will be a local problem and there will be local political capital made of it on one side or another. Nevertheless, it is our obligation to carefully evaluate them, along with the local councils and the local people and so forth. I have no doubt that there will be some political involvement in every one of those facilities when those occasions arise—if they ever do.
I notice that Smithfield, Salisbury and Elizabeth North in South Australia are on Labor's list. In other words, some of the major facilities were on that list—
Mr Bevis
—Parts of them.
Mr McLACHLAN
—Exactly—parts of the major facilities were on the list. As you know, when you get to those facilities the plans will be different from what you would like to have people think, which is that the whole facility will disappear.
In regard to Holsworthy, the final environmental report has still not come down. When it does, we will evaluate it, but I must say that, in the process of having a preliminary look at Holsworthy and Badgerys Creek, when we went to Badgerys Creek we found that absolutely nothing had happened there in the previous 18 months. What was the previous government's second Sydney airport? There was no proposal. It was going to be—and was—allowed to drift through that election. It would have been interesting, if Labor had been lucky enough to win the election, to see how it would have let it drift through to the next election. Quite frankly, nothing was going to happen at all, as you well know.
When we took over the portfolio of Defence we found that we were right at the bottom of the budgetary expenditure that could hold the capabilities of the Australian defence forces where they were. There are some aspects which I would not report publicly which are extremely worrying in regard to our capabilities. That is, for one reason or another, the position that we found ourselves in.
Almost instantly, I asked for a strategic review to be undertaken. I have said publicly many times that I could not understand why the strategic position of this country was not already in the hands of the government—in other words, why you did not have continually upgraded
strategic reviews. How could you go X years between one review and then suddenly have to revamp the whole thing to have another review? That matter ought to be dynamic.
When I get the strategic review, and make the public version—which, as I have said publicly a number of times, will happen—we will need to have a version which will be different obviously from the original.
(Extension of time granted)
We make no apologies for that; it has ever been thus. But I would have to say that I will be insisting, while I have this job, that that strategic review is dynamically upgraded all the time. I do not want to be looking back to a situation and saying, `Isn't it a funny thing? For the last five years we have been ordering all this equipment and doing all these things, but suddenly we have found that the game has changed halfway through.'
The same thing applies in regard to the Defence reform program. There is no doubt that there will be some pain—we have said this plenty of times publicly. But we have tried to make the structure of the organisation and the system itself much more efficient. If that is successful, then that system will have some dynamism to it and, in itself, as in business, it will have the capacity to make change from within. People criticise me for equating this situation with business because it is not quite the same, but there are a lot of principles that are the same.
I note the shadow minister criticised me for going and getting some outsiders. But he knows very well that 30 or 40 of the people in the secretariat were all from Defence, or were Defence civilians, and those people were really the contributors to most of the changes—those people and the 200 to 300 people who made submissions one way or another. The fact that we got some outsiders was absolutely essential, I felt, because you cannot make radical change totally from within. You must have both the insiders and some outsiders evaluating those circumstances.
Although this is reasonably radical, we really had no alternative. I have had a lot of people from the middle ranks come to me and say, `About time. We had to do this.' We had $10 billion in 1996 dollars and no further money for at least two or three years. We had to ensure that we could make changes in our acquisitions and keep up. Quite frankly, making these changes will only enable us to keep up, in my view. We have some major decisions to make, as the shadow minister knows, in regard to major platform decisions—not necessarily acquiring—because these lead times are so very great.
He also made the comment about the army being down to 20,000. My figures show that the army was down because national service was in place in the early days and it was down to those figures in the early 1960s. Every military organisation in the world is cutting its numbers. Why are the numbers being cut? Firstly, it is a matter of expense but, secondly, the platforms are getting very sophisticated and expensive and they are being operated by fewer people.
It is exactly the same as making motor cars or driving caterpillar tractors. The military is no different. One man with the right equipment around him, whether it is for making holes in the air, or whether it is in the army or the navy, is doing far more because of the sophistication and the cost of the equipment that he has got. That cost enables that sophistication and capability. So, it is not a possibility under these sorts of budgetary restraints to be able to do everything. If we are going to have soldiers kitted out with the sorts of communications and abilities that we see today, they are extraordinarily more expensive than a soldier 20 years ago. Numbers are not the answer. Capability and readiness is what we are aiming for.
I cannot possibly address all the areas. I am quite happy to have a debate anywhere or in any parliament that the shadow minister happens to be in, if they let him stay. With regard to the DER, I will be reporting in the spring session as to the implementation of the DER, so you will get an opportunity to debate all these things again on that occasion.
Mr LAURIE FERGUSON
(Reid)
(12.25 p.m.)
—There are many commendable aspects of the veterans' affairs portfolio. Indisputably, this area—like areas such as immigration until more recent times, when the Prime Minister decided to run shotgun on that portfolio—has had a large degree of bipartisanship. We certainly recognise commendable aspects of this budget: medication management, the look at compliance packaging, the attempt to reduce the problems for people with memory lapses and eyesight problems—at the same time, it is not only altruism, with savings of $20 million in the government's predictions over the next four years—and the extension of disability pension to another 10,500 people and also some service pension and defence service home extensions to a small number.
As we have indicated in many speeches in RSL conferences around the country and in correspondence with constituents, commendable aspects of the budget include also the continuation of Their Service—Our Heritage, and equally the minister's emphasis—understandable, I would think, from his background—on rural and remote areas, in regard to information delivery and information on home safety and security measures, et cetera. But I should say that, at the same time, this causes me concern, parallel with Medicare offices throughout this country. We find some country seats with three and four offices, conveniently, but many in urban New South Wales and suburban electorates, where Mr Deputy Speaker and I reside, are totally without Medicare offices in 1997.
We support the provision for rural and remote areas; we recognise the significant numbers of veterans in those areas and the difficulties that they have because of distance, et cetera, and perhaps, to some degree, the lack of information. We support these gestures—the linking of this with state and federal departments—but we want to be very certain that we do not see, as a consequence of this, a shift in resources long term within the department.
Further with regard to resources, we see that the average staff numbers for the portfolio in the 1997‐98 financial year will be cut by 610 from 3,406. That includes a reduction of 275 positions as a direct result of the government's imposition on the portfolio of an efficiency dividend of 14.3 per cent over three years. Once again, there has been a long‐term commitment on both sides of politics that there should be service delivery by a separate entity, by a separate department. One has to question the critical mass of this department long term, with these kinds of reductions in the number of employees in the department, and to question, considering the aging of Australia's population, and more particularly veterans, whether that is going to be a defensible position in the long term.
The secretary to the department, Dr Johnston, told the Senate estimates hearing on 12 June, at page 329 of the transcript, that because of the combined effect of a number of changes instituted by the department the staff could be reduced `by up to 30 per cent over the next three years'. He said, furthermore:
. . . we need to identify areas where we can contract out some more of our business . . .
There is a very distinct possibility that there are going to be longer term questions for the level, quantity, extent and timeliness of the service provided to veterans posed by these kinds of reductions. They are significant, they are noticeable. It is all right to go around assuring various conferences that you believe in this department, you believe these are a distinct part
of the welfare community in this country, they have particular needs, they have a particular need for services. But if you have a situation where these kind of reductions are occurring, then there must be some concerns.
The other reason that there must be increasing questions as to bipartisanship in this field is the interaction of this department with a number of others. It is no good going around and simply telling people, `We are going to give this much for the south Goulburn memorial,' or, `We are going to do this in Roma,' and so on, when we see that there are very noticeable changes in the Department of Social Security, changes that are going to impact directly on veterans. We saw a significant number of those in aged care in regard to income support in this country. The veteran community in this country does want to see the minister in there fighting and taking on the Social Security and Treasury direction that is dominating decision making.
In the long term, as we look at this portfolio, it cannot be just distinguished to one side by a fixation with commemorative activities and belief that in the long term that is going to simply impress veterans as being the ant's pants of the whole portfolio. There is a concern about what is happening throughout the portfolio, and the impact of other portfolios upon it.
(Extension of time granted)
In 1996, we saw $1.26 billion slashed from social security over a two‐year period in this country. Again in this budget of far less strenuous reductions, the fact of life in 1997 is that after two budgets there are cuts of $1.16 billion over three years. They are obviously having a very big impact upon the constituency of this minister and upon the people that he is representing. The opposition, veterans and older people in this country are not a collection of Man Fridays finding Robinson Crusoes in regard to this particular budget. It is not one off; it is not the only budget in which there have been failures to defend standards and conditions in the portfolio.
Last year we saw the government, with the simple intention of victimising a mere 340 people in this country and saving $21,000 over a four‐year period, change the rental assistance for single people within this particular department.
