We saw the introduction of user charges in HACC or home care and there have been arguments that veterans are particularly discriminated against because of a lack of recognition by state authorities that they are actually responsible for these people and they are not just shoved totally into the control of veterans' affairs. Last year saw earning credits altered and obviously changes in deeming. When we come to this particular budget, it is not a one‐off situation. It is not a one‐off instance of deterioration of people's rights.
I will turn to some of the aspects of this particular budget. One measure involves saving $15.5 million over four years and relates to various panels for diagnosis. I want to put on the record some of the comments made by the Vietnam Veterans' Association. Quite obviously they have deeper concerns about this, because they have a view—and it has been articulated by departmental representatives as well—that PTSD is the main target of the government. There have been throwaway lines about back problems and other things, but the diagnosis of this condition is one which does seem to be the government's thrust.
The Vietnam Veterans' Association reminded me that even the Agent Orange royal commission stated in 1985:
The result is that approximately one quarter of Vietnam veterans can be expected to be in need of psychological or psychiatric help. . .
Furthermore, the 1992‐93 Auditor‐General's report is apparently argued as being a very distinct and very influential reason as to why the government is attacking the rights of these veterans in regard to their compensation. This is the document which is the seminal driving force behind the change to smash these people's conditions and—as has been said by the department—deprive five per cent of people of their compensation, that is, 150 of the 30,000 applicants every year who are supposedly the target of this change. This not very sympathetic report said:
It is generally recognised by experts that the background prevalence of PTSD for Vietnam veterans is quite high—the ANOA's consultants suggest it is perhaps 30% of all veterans. . .
Furthermore, they put the point that PTSD is not the only psychiatric problem facing Vietnam veterans. In fact, they state:
Statistics from 1993 to 1997 show that some 40% of psychiatric conditions accepted as war caused by the Repatriation system were conditions other than PTSD.
They further indicate that a particular study of 84 members of the D company—of whom only 30 per cent were at the battle of Long Tan—found that nearly 30 per cent had full blown PTSD, whilst a further 55 per cent suffered some of the list of symptoms associated with it—a total of 85 per cent with war caused psychological damage.
What we have is a variety of government reports—most of them unsympathetic, most of them critical and most of them driven by the attempt to reduce government expenditure—saying that this is a very real problem for Vietnam veterans. What we are seeing as part of this budget process is an attempt by the government to make a major change in regard to panel diagnosis under the pretext or veneer of a whole lot of veterans trying to be corrupt, undermine or steal money from the government. As I say, they have a variety of suggestions as to how they are going to cut this down.
(Extension of time granted)
Furthermore, from personal analysis by people who are immediately connected with these particular Vietnam veterans, the veterans have said:
That more and more are hitting the wall is not surprising either. We are reaching the age where our youthful energy is deserting us. Before, we could suppress our ailments and `soldier on'. Now the youngest of us is close to 50. We can't pretend we are not sick any more. We have to face ourselves and admit we are crook, even though we'd like to deny it.
So in all of the plaudits, in all of the aspects of this budget that we do find commendable, that we are happy with and where we feel the minister is putting up what should occur, this is one area where there must be grave concerns about the thrust of government policy.
The Vietnam veterans have stated their view that:
. Veterans should not have to personally face a reviewing tribunal.
They also state:
. Accreditation schemes have the danger of appearing like the Repatriation Commission simply picking psychiatrists it thinks will be tough on veterans and allowing only them to diagnose psychiatric conditions.
They further state:
. The introduction of any new system for the diagnosis of war caused psychiatric conditions must not be accompanied by the restriction of appeal rights to the appeals board or tribunal.
We know that there are a variety of thoughts with regard to the future direction of those tribunals.
What is occurring there is, on all appearances, a very reasonable concern that this is a significant assault. The government might say at this stage that it is only 150. But, quite frankly, I think a number of service organisations, the opposition and the general public have to be vigilant because this might be one of the few areas where the government is understating for the next few years what it expects to accomplish from this. It does seem a very interesting facet that to tackle only 150 cases that they supposedly claim are sham, corrupt or improper over that period of time needs this kind of emphasis from the government.
There are other aspects of the budget. One that has been raised very strongly, both in this portfolio and in Social Security, is the question of the government's changes with regard to pharmaceuticals. From recollection, the figure is $39 million in savings over the next four years. This interfaces with the health department and it is interesting to note that, a year ago, the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) said, `The new drugs are actually better and I would like to have Australians having access to the best and newest drugs.' He would like them to get access, but the fact of life is that in 1997, in this budget which this minister is part of, there is a very significant attempt to essentially reduce the ability of people to get access when they cannot afford it.
I note that the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, Dr Johnston, told the Senate estimates committee last week that:
. . . I would be misleading you if I did not indicate that there is an expectation that treating doctors will be a bit more questioning in the prescription of some of these treatments and will not proceed with that in all cases.
Assurances by the minister that, really, this is going to have a minimal impact are deflated, undermined, criticised and basically ridiculed by the comments of the secretary of the department that there is going to be a fundamental impact.
In the budget papers there is a figure of $39 million over four years, so to say that it is not going to have an impact, that it is not going to hurt people and, at the same time, to be recouping and saving that kind of money really does raise very significant questions. Both the delisting of these medicines and the therapeutic group premiums will have a significant impact on the portfolio. The opposition have indicated that they have concerns about these, as have service organisations.
The question of what is occurring with peoples' rights and with the panel diagnosis is interrelated with another part of government policy. That is, the way in which other departments are eroding peoples' rights to actually take on departments, including this department, and this government. Amongst those changes has been a very strong attack on legal aid. There is also the question of the Human Rights and Equal Commission.
(Extension of time granted)
Not only do we have the question of what they are doing on the pharmaceuticals front, but we also have the question of what the impact of aged care changes is on a population that is significantly present amongst older Australians, that is, the veterans community. The figures show that 78,000 of Australia's 97,000 war widows are aged over 70 years of age, and that is 85 per cent of them. Aged care impacts upon this particular portfolio. One has to question how strenuously, how rigorously, the minister took on these kinds of issues within the government because they are having a very real impact upon the people who are covered by this department.
People's conditions are being eroded whether it is to do with therapeutic changes, aged care, appeal rights, or whether it is in regards to diagnosis. People's conditions are being very rudely impacted upon by changes such as access to legal aid and in areas such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.
It is interesting to note the comments of the organisation People With Disabilities (NSW) Inc. In commenting on those changes they say:
PWD rejects the Attorney‐General's attempt to rationalise and sanitise these cuts. The cuts are patently not equivalent to the 4% efficiency savings applied to other agencies within the Attorney's portfolio: the cuts to HREOC are obviously almost eleven times greater than cuts applied elsewhere.
. . . . . . . . .
. . .. PWD genuinely believes that the cuts are motivated by an unstated policy of the Government to dismantle these structures which protect the rights and interests of vulnerable minorities with in the Australian community.
They mention:
. . . an unprecedented deterioration in the social fabric of the Australian community.
I have had service groups come to me expressing their concern at the assault on legal aid under the technicality of the improper payment of money for cases that are state and not federal, et cetera. There is this Human Rights and Equal Opportunity thing. The Ombudsman's office is being undermined. All of these things are impacting directly upon veterans in this country. Even if the minister thinks this is irrelevant, not connected, not of importance, not relevant to this portfolio, they are certainly matters which people feel are impacting upon them.
In conclusion, there is, and there always will be in this portfolio, a variety of aspects upon which any opposition of the day will be in agreement with because there is this tradition in regards to income support and in regards to commemorative activities that there will be a degree of commonality of policy in this area. But there has been a failure to draw the line on eroding conditions in areas such as pharmaceuticals, aged care and deeming.
There are single veterans, believe it or not. They are not all conventionally married 70‐year‐olds. There are single veterans who live in the same house who have been hit by rental changes. These things are significant. They do impact on this portfolio. They are not totally separated. They are not isolated. They are not irrelevant. On these matters, the opposition does have grave concerns.
Mr SERCOMBE
(Maribyrnong)
(12.44 p.m.)
—I wanted to use this opportunity to raise with the minister the matter of the exclusion from eligibility for repatriation benefits of members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in what was then Malaya in the period 1955 to 1960. In doing that, I think it is a matter that previous governments of both shades ought to have addressed but did not, regrettably. Nonetheless, it seems to me that is not an adequate reason for this government to not now address this particular issue.
In 1955, the Menzies government committed Australian defence forces from the three services to the Malayan emergency. I understand that the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act 1956 specifically excluded members of the Navy from eligibility for repatriation benefits. That was particularly ironic at a time when HMAS
Anzac
and HMAS
Tobruk
were both involved in bombardments of enemy positions in Malaya. Later that year HMAS
Queenborough
and HMAS
Quickmatch
were similarly engaged. The Australian Navy was a component of the Order of Battle for Malaya and was part of the Royal Naval Far East Fleet during that emergency.
A couple of historians have dealt with this matter. Lieutenant Colonel N.C. Smith in a book entitled
Mostly Unsung
said:
Prior to the arrival of the RAN ships the available Navy force had been barely adequate, with little or no capacity for refitting or a meaningful presence on both the east and west coast.
Another historian, Brigadier E.D. Smith, in a book entitled
Counter‐Insurgency Operations: 1 Malaya and Borneo
said:
The other reason that so few arms of any significance were brought into the country was due to the constant but unspectacular blockade exerted by the Royal Navy's Coastal patrols [which included RAN ships] and RAAF flying boat patrols.
These agencies maintained the territorial detachment of Malaya from the outer world because a series of random searches at sea served to act as a powerful deterrent to would‐be gun runners. The Royal Navy's part
[which included RAN ships] in ensuring that the [enemy] received little of value by sea was one that was taken for granted by the Malayan people and the land forces defending them.
It is quite clear that the RAN performed a valuable role. Apart from bombardment of shore positions, they were obviously involved with signals intercept. That was found by the historians to have played a very significant role in that particular conflict.
I understand that the Full Federal Court in 1966 held, when some matters relating to the question of active service were tested, that the expression `in actual combat against the enemy' included conduct which answered the description of `integral participation in an activity directly intended for an encounter with the enemy, whether offensive or defensive in character'. I submit that, and veterans from that time submit, all RAN ships were involved in operations that clearly meet that category. They feel most aggrieved that they continue to be excluded, almost uniquely, I think, from consideration for eligibility for repatriation benefits.
The other matter I wish to raise also relates to anomalies in relation to the treatment of veterans. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard), shortly before the election, made a commitment that a major initiative of the coalition was the military medals policy. This policy standardises and considerably widens the eligibility of ex‐service personnel to receive an Australian services medal. That position was supported by the then coalition spokesperson on veterans' affairs.
In September last year, the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) issued a press release following an address to the RSL national congress. She stated:
I am pleased to announce that the Government's policy is largely in place with the Governor‐General having already approved changes to the determinations for the medals under his authority; Her Majesty's assent is being sought for these changes.
On 28 May this year the Minister was forced to concede that the coalition had in fact not honoured its commitment to those who served in Korea, in the Malayan emergency and in the Indonesian confrontation. Eight months after she said that everything was in order she was conceding that:
. . . it was indeed then discovered that those people had been awarded an Imperial Medal at the behest of the Australian Government, and therefore it was an Australian medal rendered in respect of that active service in Korea, in the Malayan emergency and in the Indonesian confrontation. Accordingly, the government made a decision that that would represent double medalling and that that would not be done.
(Extension of time granted)
A fortnight later the Minister appears to have done yet another double flip. Her office told the Melbourne
Herald‐Sun
on 11 June that the government would announce a medals about‐turn in two weeks, after the Prime Minister returns from overseas.
I can understand with all this confusion and double‐speak that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and his office will be more than delighted to refer calls or inquiries on this matter to Mrs Bishop's office, but it would be very useful to get some clarification of—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)
—She is actually the member for Mackellar.
Mr SERCOMBE
—I am sorry. Bishop's principles are what Bishop's principles are in this particular circumstance. It really is a fairly shameful mucking around of the veteran community.
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
(Maranoa—
Minister for Veterans' Affairs)
(12.50 p.m.)
—Firstly, can I thank the shadow minister and the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) for their contributions to this debate. It is certainly pleasing to see members of the opposition taking an interest in the Veterans' Affairs portfolio.
Can I just say at the outset that we often get calls that we are not doing enough for veterans. That is so for both sides of the parliament as the opposition did so when in government. I just remind us all in this committee here this morning that we do appropriate almost $6.4 billion to care for our veteran community, our war widows and some dependants of veterans. It is important that we do focus on that fact from time to time. The government does see this very much as a bipartisan portfolio and we do give thanks for the shadow minister's comments in that area as well as some areas that he has flagged that he has some concerns in. It is important that we do acknowledge that all governments have tried as hard as they can to make sure they meet as many of the needs of our veteran community as possible. Given the constraints of budgets from time to time, it is not possible to extend some areas as far as perhaps we would like.
I just touch on the issue of some outsourcing that has been going on in the department. The shadow minister raised this issue and referred to some of the comments by the secretary in Senate estimates. I would remind the opposition, when they look at this outsourcing, of the numbers of staff that were in the department when they came to government. Admittedly, at the time they came to government, the ownership of all repatriation hospitals was with the Commonwealth.
During their time in government, we saw the staff of the Department of Veterans' Affairs fall from something like 13,000 down to 3,400 or thereabouts. The large numbers of reductions in staffing certainly were associated with the privatisation of those repatriation hospitals which we in opposition supported. I would remind the opposition, when they talk about the outsourcing of some activities of the department today, to just look at what they did when they were in government. I also remind them that we supported them in that process.
It is important that we do look at the efficiency of the department, as you should look at the efficiency of government. Also, I am sure every business person in this nation would be aware of the need to look at the efficiency of their business operation. Through running an efficient department and making savings, we have been able to deliver in this budget an extension of benefits to veterans who were not previously entitled to them. I will refer to a couple of those.
The member for Maribyrnong raised the issue of the Far East Strategic Reserve in relation to the Malaysian emergency. I would refer him to our press release. If he has not already read it, I would commend it to him because we picked that up in the budget. We conducted a review of the anomalies we spoke out about prior to the election. We not only picked up the Far East Strategic Reserve, we picked up 11 other areas of anomalies.
Mr Sercombe
—Including service pensions?
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
—We picked up 11 other areas of anomalies. I will just read these for the benefit of the member. They include
HMAS Vampire
and
HMAS Quickmatch
in relation to service in Vietnam prior to 1962. We also picked up the embassy guard with the Australian embassy in Saigon after our withdrawal there. We picked up the naval service people that you refer to. We have picked up the BCOF people—the British occupation forces in Japan. We have picked up 12 other areas of anomalies that were previously not acknowledged as service. That needs to be acknowledged and recognised.
Those people will be eligible for a disability payment through the Department of Veterans' Affairs. They will also be eligible for health treatment for war related injuries that may have been inflicted during that service in those previously unrecognised areas of service.
(Extension of time granted)
I will now deal with the area of panel diagnosis that was touched on by the shadow minister.
I can assure him that on this issue there will be no throwaway lines from this minister and, I would hope, from anyone in the parliament, because it is a very serious issue and one that is acknowledged by us and has been acknowledged by previous ministers and by previous governments. It is a serious issue. We want to make sure that, through a better approach to this, we can have confidence in the diagnosis of the psychological disorder.
Members may not be aware, but last year we brought Professor Arieh Shalev out here from Israel. He is a world renowned expert in the area of diagnosis of PTSD. He spoke at conferences all around this nation, including to our serving defence forces. Currently, we are circulating an options paper. We are having discussions with the ex‐service community, including the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia and the Vietnam Veterans' Federation of Australia. We are working very closely with them. This options paper will be circulated before any final process is agreed to.
Far from rushing into this issue, we have identified that we need to have confidence in the process. Veterans themselves want to have confidence in the diagnosis. I think there are as many who do not get diagnosed with PTSD who feel they should, as there are those who do get diagnosed. We need to make sure that we all have confidence in the diagnostic process.
I would also point out that we have very real concerns about the health of Vietnam veterans. We have acknowledged that with the release of the mortality study of Vietnam veterans. Only recently, we circulated a questionnaire on health to over 53,000 Vietnam veterans around Australia. That questionnaire was drawn up with the help of Vietnam veterans' associations. It includes questions about their lifestyle, their children and their relationship within their marriage. It is an important questionnaire, and it is a further demonstration of our commitment to assist Vietnam veterans, to make sure that we are targeting their needs as well as possible and that we are not leaving them feeling left out.
I also point out that, for the very first time, we will be asking female veterans who served in Vietnam in any capacity, for one day or more from 1962 to 1973—and we have identified 484 of them—to also participate in that questionnaire. I hope that wherever they go members
of the opposition continue to urge Vietnam veterans to fill out that questionnaire—they have until 30 June to complete it.
In relation to the Veterans' Review Board and the appeal process, let me assure the shadow minister and the opposition that we take our responsibility in this area very seriously. Our appointment of Brigadier Bill Rolfe to the principal member's position on the Veterans' Review Board shows our commitment to putting people in the position who understand the culture of the people for whom they have responsibility in relation to reviews of claims that have been rejected by the department.
Brigadier Bill Rolfe was a Vietnam veteran who served back here in Australia after his service in Vietnam. I will remind people that, as a soldier in Vietnam, he was wounded and lost both legs. If ever there was anyone who could understand the culture of Vietnam veterans, it would be Brigadier Rolfe. His appointment is another demonstration that, when it comes to dealing with veterans issues, we are serious about having people who understand the people for whom they have responsibility in terms of those processes of review.
My time is short, and I want to wrap this up. There were other issues raised, but I thank the opposition for their bipartisan support.
(Time expired)
Mr SERCOMBE
(Maribyrnong)
(1.01 p.m.)
—I wish to pick up on the comments of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) about the moves in the budget to remove some anomalies. Obviously, I and other members of the opposition would welcome any move to remove anomalies, and I would appreciate some clarification from the minister. If he is unable to do it now, so be it; I would welcome it in writing in due course. Could he clarify the question of service pensions for RAN personnel serving in Malaya during the Emergency?
It is certainly my understanding of the budget that, in fact, that issue has not been resolved. Certainly, some of the other anomalies that the minister referred to are, I readily acknowledge, welcome. But the principal thrust of my comments is that, to the best of my knowledge, that particular RAN one has not been resolved to the satisfaction of the veteran community. If the minister is able to call me wrong now, I would be delighted to be called wrong, but it is certainly my very firm understanding that that glaring anomaly remains. It would be very useful to get the minister's comments—in due course, if not now—on what is being done to resolve it.
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
(Maranoa—
Minister for Veterans' Affairs)
(1.02 p.m.)
—The member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) asks whether those Navy personnel who served in the Malayan Emergency would be eligible for a service pension. The answer to that question is that they will not be eligible for a service pension, but they will be eligible for a disability pension and also for health benefits in relation to those injuries that could have been caused by their war service.
Whilst we all acknowledge that perhaps, in some of these areas, we would all like to go further from time to time, I would remind those on the other side of the House that they had 13 years to look at this one, so I would ask that you look at this issue in a bipartisan way. We have picked them up for any disability that may have been caused as a result of that service, and they will receive a disability pension for any disabilities that they identify as resulting from that service. They will also be eligible for health treatment in relation to those disabilities or war‐caused injuries. They will not be eligible, though, for a service pension.
If those people are, in fact, on a social security pension, they may well be eligible for the `bring them back' program by which we are trying to bring those on a part disability pension
and those who are on a part social security pension back into the Department of Veterans' Affairs. We estimate there are some 30,000‐odd veterans in this category. Those I mentioned may well fall within one of those categories, and we are happy to bring them back to be eligible for that payment under the Department of Veterans' Affairs.
In conclusion, I thank those on the other side of the House and remind them that we are committed to the health and welfare of our veterans. I thank them for their contributions and I commend Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997 to the Main Committee.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Transport and Regional Development
Proposed expenditure, $265,658,000.
Mr TANNER
(Melbourne)
(1.04 p.m.)
—I will speak very briefly on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98 with respect to the Department of Transport and Regional Development, primarily because there is very little of great consequence in this current budget with respect to transport—so much so that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development was able to put out only two press releases as a result of the transport decisions in the budget. I will deal in brief detail with the issues that the two press releases dealt with.
Firstly, on the question of roads, in the budget of last year the government cut $622 million from the forward estimates for the national highway over the four years of that budgetary year and the three subsequent forward estimates years. Yet again, in the current budget, we have seen reductions, albeit slight, in overall road funding. The major savage decisions were made last year; they have been continued this year and, indeed, slightly exacerbated.
It is noteworthy also that particular states, such as Queensland and Victoria, appear to be bearing the brunt of the reduction in road funding that has occurred. In my state of Victoria, for example, throughout the entirety of the 1990s up to last year Victoria received between 20 and 21 per cent of total federal road funding. That percentage went down to something like 17.9 per cent in last year's budget, and in this year's budget it is declining even further, to 15.9 per cent. Similar patterns can be seen with respect to road funding in Queensland.
It is also notable in this year's budget that the proportion of funds going to the roads of national importance category—or, as I call it, the roads of National Party importance category—has increased again, at the cost of the national highway. In Labor's last budget, the national highway had an allocation of $834 million. That is a figure that was roughly similar, in real terms, across almost all of the time when Labor was in government. In this budget the national highway allocation is $697 million; there has been a very substantial drop from the $834 million in the 1995 budget to the $697 million in this budget.
It is true that there is $112 million allocated for roads of national importance but, by definition, that will not go to the national highway. It will go elsewhere, based on highly dubious and, I suggest, very open‐ended criteria which are designed ultimately to allow all sorts of pork‐barrelling on the part of the minister to occur and are already, effectively, being used for that purpose.
I turn to the second issue on which the minister managed to get a press release out. His press release with respect to roads did not exactly tell us the true story about what has been happening with road funding over the past 15 months, and similarly his press release with respect to the national rail infrastructure authority or the track authority, which we have just been debating in the main chamber this morning, was a little less than forthcoming.
The former Labor government proposed to spend $370 million over five years to allow the then Track Australia to own and operate the interstate track and to maintain the interstate track in Australia—a very important infrastructure investment and micro‐economic reform. In last year's budget this decision was continued but cut from $370 million to roughly $245 million, I think, from memory. This time around, the minister has announced that the amount that will be spent will be a mere $175 million. His press release said $175 million; the budget papers, at table 12.4, I think, from memory, said that the figure would be $185 million. I am not even quite sure that he can get the figure right. He thinks he cut it by $10 million more than he actually did, by the look of it.
In any event, the minister tried to turn a cut, a vice, into a virtue by putting out a press release announcing—yet again—something that the former government had announced, something that his government had announced and something that was being announced in the context of substantial reductions in funding. He was trying to pretend that this was a wonderful decision for the rail industry and transport in Australia, when in fact it is a terrible decision. It is something that I think anybody who has got any association with the rail industry—users, workers and communities that depend on the rail industry—will live to regret. They will regret that this substantial reduction in the level of investment that goes into maintaining and upgrading the track, which is of particular importance in many areas such as the Brisbane to Melbourne and Melbourne to Adelaide sections of the interstate track, is occurring; that the process of negotiating with the states to develop the authority appears to have stalled; and that the minister is trying on this very day to get a bill through the parliament which will give him the power to make all the decisions with respect to the future track authority without any future reference to the parliament.
(Time expired)
Mr FITZGIBBON
(Hunter)
(1.10 p.m.)
—Unfortunately I missed the early part of the shadow minister's contribution, but no doubt he took the opportunity to remind the parliament that, in its first budget, the Howard government cut $622 million from the national highway budget over four years. Again, in the 1997‐98 budget, it copped another slug. So where does it leave the national highway program, when the former Labor government was only spending about $840 million each year: $622 million over four years, and we were only spending about $840 million? That gives you a very clear indication of the significance of that slug. As a result, national highway projects right around the country have ground to a halt.
I want to talk specifically about one of those projects, a project known as the Kurri Corridor, a project which would provide a link between the F3 freeway and the New England Highway just north of Branxton in my electorate, a corridor that would have enormous economic benefits for the Hunter generally and, in particular, the Upper Hunter. The link would bring those communities in the Upper Hunter just that much closer to Sydney and all of its markets and, of course, to the port of Newcastle.
Mr Robert Brown
—And we would have funded it.
Mr FITZGIBBON
—We would have, indeed. The Labor government was on track to fund this very important project. I know you are not concerned, Mr Deputy Speaker, because much of that money is now going to the Pacific Highway.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
—I was just interested in the interjection from the honourable member for Charlton.
Mr FITZGIBBON
—A very worthy project, indeed, but we should not be doing it at the expense of the national highway system. Not only would the Kurri Corridor have provided
enormous economic benefits to the valley, it would have overcome some very significant problems experienced by both the Cessnock and Maitland and, indeed, Newcastle councils.
I want to focus specifically on Cessnock's problems. The main roads through Cessnock are providing a short cut between the F3 freeway and the New England Highway for about 400 trucks each day. Those 400 trucks daily stream through Cessnock's central business district. This is a local economy in difficulty. Coalmining has in a sense moved on and our economic base is shrinking.
Mr Bruce Scott
—They're on strike down there today.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
—Order!
Mr FITZGIBBON
—You are not doing much to help it. Cessnock has some economic difficulties. The council wants to do something about that. It wants to start by refurbishing the central business district but it cannot make a move while ever that main street is accommodating 400 heavy vehicles each day. The Kurri Corridor would have fixed that problem but now there seems little hope that it will ever be constructed. A change of government, of course, might help.
So Cessnock council is looking at some alternatives. It has now undertaken a study into a simple bypass of the town, a $33 million project which would effectively take those heavy vehicles out of Cessnock's central business district and out of those roads such as Allandale Road and Aberdare Road which house a number of residents. Of course, this thing has to be funded. We should not fear because the present Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp)—or should I say just `Transport' since his statement that the Commonwealth has no role to play in the area of regional development—when he was shadow minister, visited Cessnock and spoke with Cessnock council and the National Party candidate about their concerns. What did he say? `You need not fear. We will have a fund in government known as roads of national importance'—or significance—`and this looks like a project which could quite neatly fit into such a scheme.' That is what he had to say before the election but we have not heard from him since.
So what are Cessnock council's options? It is now asking the state government to fund the project; as I said, it is some $33 million. You know, Mr Deputy Speaker, how difficult it is to get that sort of money out of a state government for a road project. The council will be visiting the minister, the now minister, to ask him to meet his commitment from prior to the election, but I fear that they have very little hope. I cannot see them spending $33 million—
(Time expired)
Mr ANDREN
(Calare)
(1.15 p.m.)
—One of the most disturbing things to have occurred during the life of this parliament is the demise of regional development as a serious portfolio responsibility of the government. Regional development is paid lip‐service. It was given very uneven attention by the previous government, I might say, although at the very end of its term Labor seemed to get things right in at least one area with the creation of the RDOs, those regional development organisations which, finally, after years of similar bodies, state and federal, with overlapping responsibilities and no real purpose, seemed to have the right formula. The personnel was right, the plans were in place, and the expectations were credible. What did this government do? It eliminated RDOs because of the Labor taint and it eliminated in all but name the Department of Regional Development—and this from a senior National Party minister. No wonder the people in the bush are scratching their heads in bewilderment and looking elsewhere to put their votes.
One of the most cynical exercises was this government's complete rejection—having promised to support it—of the feasibility study into Parkes export airport. I mentioned this in more detail in my response in relation to primary industry expenditure last night. Western New South Wales feels rejected by the government's walking away from a miserly $250,000 commitment to a project that looks like coming up trumps, despite the government's lack of interest and, I might say, lack of vision.
I welcome the funding for a national rail infrastructure, but I wonder if it will benefit the main western rail line through New South Wales, Bathurst, Parkes and Broken Hill. That infrastructure needs urgent attention to take advantage of the natural advantages, the rail freight facilities at Bathurst, Blayney and Parkes, combined with the north‐south Newell Highway road intersection office. As well, by encouraging heavy freight onto rail, and hub and spoking smaller loads from depots, such as Bathurst, Blayney and Parkes, the load is taken off both the highways and the highway budget.
One hundred and seventy‐five million dollars over four years is fine, but far more will be needed if we are serious about rail regaining and exploiting its potential to save money. It is rational economics—the cost of not having heavy and hazardous freight on rail. The impact of that is there for everyone to see at the moment: the risk of accidents; the breaking up of road surfaces; and the struggle by local government to meet its road commitments, especially with its FAGs, those federal assistance grants, cut by 1.2 per cent in real per capita terms in this budget.
It is interesting, too, to note the concern now being expressed by local governments and states about the impact of changes in load allowances. The air suspension on the new generation of trucks is being regarded with grave suspicion, with data showing bridge damage likely to be substantial from the double‐B era of vehicles. I suspect that the $11 million set aside for a national survey of bridge requirements might turn up some interesting data. While this government supports increased mass weights on vehicles on the premise that it will mean fewer vehicles, the so‐called road friendly suspensions may not, according to my information, be so friendly after all.
At a time when the west of New South Wales is crying out for support, it seems that this government, as did the one before—except on the Mount Lambie section, and then only after extreme public pressure led by the Highway Safety Action Group—will continue to disregard the claims of the Great Western Highway for national highway status. Coalition members across the mountain should hang their heads in shame, if they are not pushing for this status. Not only is it a major tourist link through their districts to the historical goldfields and other attractions of the central west, but also it is a main artery, feeding traffic to and from the west.
With increased loads, both in size and frequency, of timber and farm produce and other items travelling the route, this link is a potential social, physical and economic disaster. Its accident record is worse than that along the Pacific Highway. The absence of any commitment to the western rail line is hampering growth and decentralisation. I realise that we are a vast country with a huge demand on the $697 million road budget. But smart spending on an integrated rail and highway transport system should include the main western rail line and the Great Western Highway.
I spoke last night about the work for the dole scheme, and how the government might investigate a farmhand scheme with a proper training component and award wages. Around 50 schemes in regional Australia covering 10,000 people is not enough to soak up even a
fraction of the 30 per cent plus of young rural people who are unemployed, not forgetting the middle‐aged unemployed. Without any major job creation program and with only this token attempt to address the real unemployment problem, exacerbated by the penalties of the new youth allowance, this government is either totally ignorant of the real situation of rural Australia, or so hell‐bent on bottom line balancing that it is sorely risking its claim to truly represent regional Australia.
Mr ROBERT BROWN
(Charlton)
(1.20 p.m.)
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I endorse the comments that were made by the member for Calare in relation to the attitude which this government is taking to the whole question of regional development.
It is apparent, of course, that the bureaucracy generally would advise governments about the structure of the bureaucracy and the relationship between portfolios. To have a Department of Transport and Regional Development is a very sensible arrangement and a very sensible connection. In July last year, we had the government announcing that the regional development and urban programs within this Department of Transport and Regional Development would be terminated and so the funding was withdrawn. The Department of Transport and Regional Development then in effect became the Department of Transport. The Minister for Transport (Mr Sharp) is quite clearly charged with the responsibility, as Minister for Transport, not to develop transport but to tear away funding, to destroy programs and to sell off the assets. That is the role which the Minister for Transport has been required to adopt.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I think there is a great deal of concern in regional Australia about the fact that this government, in effect, has turned its back on it. To a large extent, the government has allowed economic forces to determine the direction in which regional development will go. That simply is not good enough. Governments do have a responsibility for national planning, for determining regional strategies and for acting as a catalyst for the type of development that needs to be undertaken. If you allow, for example, market forces to determine the nature and the direction of regional development in Australia, you can finish up with the type of thing that we are seeing now in places like Geelong and Newcastle.
Newcastle, for example, I referred to yesterday. BHP has made a decision that the primary steelmaking capacity and facilities in Newcastle will disappear from September 1999. The free marketeers and the economic rationalists might well say that is the way the market is taking us. The point that I emphasis is that that betrays a complete lack of understanding about what regional development and regional economies are all about.
In Australia we do have very significant identifiable regions. They are integrated and they are coordinated. They operate as regions. Allowing steel, for example, to come out of the Newcastle region or the Hunter region would be like saying, `Here is an engine of a motor car with a bit here that probably is not necessary. We will allow that to be taken out,' and you take out the carburettor. The engine then, of course, stops operating.
Mr Deputy Speaker, that is probably a good example of the essential role which the component elements of regional economies play and the way in which each of them depend on other sections of it. What we need is a national government which is prepared to provide leadership in questions of national development. National development takes place as a result of the coordinated and the integrated development of each of those regions and the contribution which in turn each of them make.
We have had not only a withdrawal of funding from regional development in Australia by this government, but positive attacks by this government on regional Australia. Some of the
best examples are the wholesale closing of offices and government agencies in the regions of Australia. In the budget of last year there were 11,200 in the public service, many of them in regional Australia, who lost their jobs. This year another 16,500 and in addition to that 8,000 in the defence forces in Australia. As a result of other decisions made by this government another 22,000 telecommunications workers are going to lose their jobs. Many of these are in regional Australia.
The government has slashed labour market programs. It has replaced all of those significant initiatives, which the previous government had made, with programs and ideas which clearly are identified as gimmicks and continue to be seen as gimmicks by the Australian community.
(Time expired)
Mr CHARLES
(La Trobe)
(1.25 p.m.)
—I had not intended to enter this debate but the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has just encouraged me to rise to my feet to respond to one portion of what he had to say. I, as much as anyone else, regret that we will no longer make primary steel at Newcastle. That hurts me and I think the honourable member acknowledges that. But to imply that somehow government, through lack of production of infrastructure, or BHP itself, or between the government and BHP, we should continue to make a product unprofitably is just an absolute nonsense. That is not economic rationalism. It would be totally irrational to continue to make products for which you lose money.
The honourable member for Charlton, no matter how his sympathies may lie, will have to admit that the communist theory and philosophy, the Marxist theory and philosophy, failed and so the walls came tumbling down. The world, even China, has become enamoured of the free market. No matter how much you might dislike it, nonetheless that is a fact. It is a fact that BHP cannot afford to make a product for which they lose money, as they are doing. A large portion of the product of that mill is exported because there is not enough domestic market. The product out of that mill, the bar and rod and wire, is more expensive than product made by Smorgons in Melbourne or a BHP in Sydney, because those operations use electric arc furnaces.
To the best of my knowledge—and I would bet on it—nobody will ever build another blast furnace in the world. Not one more blast furnace will ever be built. Today, some of the more recent ones are absolutely huge—I believe, 3.5 million tonnes for one blast furnace. When I grew up on a blast furnace, a million‐tonne unit was a huge blast furnace, absolutely gigantic. Those expanded themselves, but to build a new furnace at 3.5 million tonnes is just unheard off.
The point is that those old furnaces with old technology just cannot compete with a scrap fed electric arc furnace. BHP ain't got the scrap to feed to Newcastle, because Australia's scrap is already consumed by Smorgons, by BHP and by whoever else it is in Sydney.
I am not an apologist for BHP; I regret the fact that Newcastle is going to close. I simply make the point to the member for Charlton that you have to make economic decisions based on profits and on losses. It is not the government's fault that the world price for bar and rod has fallen with respect to its price for flat product. Port Kembla is profitable and Port Kembla is expanding. Why? Because it makes flat product, it makes it in modern facilities and those furnaces will run, I hope, for a very long time.
It is not economic rationalism per se, nor is it some sort of economic conspiracy against the people of Newcastle. I think all of us have the greatest sympathy for the people of Newcastle.
I certainly hope that we can find mechanisms to help Newcastle to help itself to attract new industry and new jobs, and build an exciting future that is not dependent on the old steel mill, not dependent on old technology. As much as I regret their losing that culture, I know—because I am an old steelworker—that old steelworkers never die. We never forget our steel mills. It is part of our life and part of our culture, and nothing else will ever be the same once they have finished. I thank the member for Charlton for his contribution, but he got that little bit wrong.
Sitting suspended from 1.30 to 4.30 p.m.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
(Hon. N.B. Reid)
took the chair at 4.30 p.m.
Department of Transport and Regional Development
Proposed expenditure, $265,658,000
Mr FITZGIBBON
(Hunter)
(4.30 p.m.)
—When my time expired earlier, I was talking about the government's slashing of the national highway budget and its impact on that system, and in particular about the fact that that will now more than likely cause the Kurri Corridor in my electorate not to be funded. I was talking about the problems that that will cause for the Cessnock area, in particular. I was calling upon the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) to make good his commitment prior to the election to fund a bypass of Cessnock under the roads of national importance fund—if, indeed, he is not going to commit the government to the Kurri Corridor.
I have to ask, Mr Deputy Speaker: where is the minister? Where is the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Ronaldson)? We are talking here about some significant issues and, at the very least, we should have the parliamentary secretary in here. What do we get instead? With the greatest respect to the minister, we get the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) from Queensland, rather than the minister himself or, indeed, the parliamentary secretary. I know that yesterday, Mr Deputy Speaker, either you or one of the other members of the speakers panel passed comment on the fact that ministers were making an effort to get into the Main Committee for these discussions, but it is very unfortunate that the Minister of Transport has not seen fit to do so or even to send his parliamentary secretary up to represent him.
I want to return to Cessnock's road problems. Other members will recall that I was speaking about the 400 heavy vehicles that pass through the town each day. Cessnock Council will be pursuing the federal minister on the issue of his commitment to a bypass, and we hope that they will be meeting with him very soon. But we will also be seeking a commitment from him that the Kurri Corridor will be funded in the longer term.
I want to turn to a short‐term alternative. Even if the minister funds a bypass of Cessnock tomorrow, it is obviously going to be years before it is constructed and, therefore, the heavy vehicle movement problem in Cessnock is going to remain with us for some time. I myself have described the idea as naive and novel, but it would be wonderful if we could load limit the state road that those heavy vehicles are using. Of course, it is impossible to load limit a state road and, in any case, it would be difficult to differentiate between those trucks that are actually servicing the Cessnock area and those that are using the town only as a short cut to the national highway.
I have recently written to a number of organisations, including the Transport Workers Union, the Road Transport Forum, and the New South Wales Road Haulage Association. I have asked
them to do something which is, as I conceded, fairly novel and which may be naive, and that is to simply ask the trucks not to go through Cessnock and not to devastate our local community. They come through Cessnock simply because it saves them seven minutes and 14 kilometres, that is all. It is not a significant amount of time in the scheme of things, when you are talking about haulages from, for example, Melbourne to Brisbane. It is a saving of only seven minutes and 14 kilometres.
The industry is not one which enjoys a great image out in the community, so what a perfect opportunity this would be for it to enhance its image in the community by effectively saving Cessnock. That is what they would be doing: saving Cessnock's economy by allowing the council to get on with the refurbishment of the CBD—and it would cost them only seven minutes.
I suspect that, in any case, there are some false economies involved in taking the short cut. They may save seven minutes, but there might be some additional costs to the operator because of the number of stops, right‐hand turns and acceleration distances et cetera. The reason I raise this is that I think my campaign to have them voluntarily withdraw from Cessnock would be greatly enhanced if the state and federal ministers became involved. I have had good responses from the trade union movement, the Road Transport Forum and the New South Wales Road Haulage Association. They are running some campaigns for me, putting some articles in their industry newsletter, et cetera. But I would like to write to every operator, to every one of those people who own those trucks that are passing through Cessnock as a short cut.
(Extension of time granted)
It is very difficult for me to identify the operators of those trucks, but it could be that 60 per cent of the trucks are owned by only four or five people. It is very difficult for me to identify them, but certainly the state and federal ministers have the resources and the capability to do so. Yesterday I wrote to them both, and I have also contacted the office of Carl Scully, the minister in New South Wales, and had a positive response from his office.
Today I am calling upon the federal minister to at least do something for Cessnock. If he cannot fund the Kurri corridor, if he cannot come good on his pre‐election commitment to fund a bypass of Cessnock, he can at least help by joining my campaign to simply ask those trucks to voluntarily remove themselves from Cessnock and stick to the national highway. I am confident I will have the state minister's support, because when they leave the national highway to go on to the state road through Cessnock there is effectively a cost shifting from the Commonwealth to the state. I would have thought the state government would have a very strong interest indeed in getting those trucks back on the national highway where they belong.
My simple message today to the minister is this: fund the Kurri corridor. If not, fund a bypass of Cessnock, as he committed himself to do prior to the election. But, at the very least, join my campaign to have those trucks voluntarily remove themselves from those Cessnock roads.
Mr KELVIN THOMSON
(Wills)
(4.38 p.m.)
—I wish to raise in this debate the recent announcement by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) that the Essendon airport will be privatised, or the lease on that airport sold off. That is a matter of great concern to people in my electorate who live around that airport. In particular, they are concerned that selling off the airport to a private sector operator, and the pressure for profit which will come from that, will lead to pressures to reduce existing protections for residents around the airport.
There are questions people in Essendon, Strathmore, Pascoe Vale and Oak Park want answered. Firstly, what guarantees will the minister provide that the existing jet curfew, from 11 p.m. to 6 a.m., will be retained? It is absolutely essential that that curfew be retained. Secondly, what guarantees will we get that the existing limitations on the size of aircraft which can use Essendon airport will remain in place? We do not want to see those size restrictions changed and the airport revisited with large freight aircraft. Thirdly, we want to see the guarantees concerning flying training remain in place. There are already concerns regarding the extent of flying training coming from Essendon airport and some of the safety considerations which arise as a result of that, but we are most concerned at the prospect of restrictions on ab initio flight training being abandoned.
We also want to seek from the minister guarantees that no attempt will be made to rezone land around Essendon airport. There were, in the past, reports suggesting that land around Essendon airport could be rezoned industrial. Fortunately, the government of the day rejected those reports and recommendations, but we have had National Party MPs suggesting that land around the airport might be rezoned industrial. That would be outrageous and a scandalous thing to do to residents in that area, and we seek assurances that in light of private leasing of the Essendon airport there will not be any such attempts.
I also want to put to the minister that if the airport is to be sold to the private sector, why should it not be made a fully open bid? That is to say, the public interest would be best served by having open tenders for aviation and non‐aviation uses of that site, and, as taxpayers, we and the community ought be able to examine those options.
I note that such a change would not impact on Tullamarine airport. I have personally contacted the Australian Pacific Airports Corporation which are taking over the lease on Tullamarine and they have neither sought, nor obtained, any guarantees regarding the operations at Tullamarine airport and the ways in which they might be affected by Essendon operations being relocated. So we do not see any reason that Essendon should not be put out for fully open bids for whatever use a private sector bidder might be able to put it to.
I also want to ask that the minister makes available the departmental advice that he received concerning the future of Essendon airport. The reports are that the departmental advice was that Essendon was unprofitable and its operations ought to be relocated. That is something that we want to see and are entitled to see, and I therefore request that the transport minister makes that departmental advice available.
It is a matter of great concern to people in my electorate that the charge to retain Essendon airport has been made by National Party MPs and, in particular, Senator Julian McGauran. Senator McGauran ought to worry about unemployment in Gippsland which, on yesterday's figures, is 12.9 per cent, the worst result in Victoria. He ought to be doing something about his backyard as I, as a local member, have been doing concerning my backyard by supporting the motor vehicle industry.
It is a matter of great concern that it is the personal convenience of Senator McGauran, and his desire to use Essendon airport on his way to work, as it were, that is driving this decision. It is also for the personal convenience of Pat McNamara, who says that having Essendon airport saves him 20 minutes travelling time twice a month. That is a scandalous way to be making public policy and, as I say, it is a matter of great concern to people in the area surrounding Essendon airport that the minister for transport has made this decision under
pressure from National Party members and without regard for good public policy on the most appropriate use of this site.
(Time expired)
Mr O'CONNOR
(Corio)
(4.43 p.m.)
—I am very pleased to have this opportunity to participate in the committee stage of the deliberations on the budget that was recently brought down by the government. I want to raise an issue which relates to the matters which have been raised in this debate by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson). My concern is not so much the sale of Essendon airport—although I have expressed a public view on that—but rather the development of Avalon airport as a dedicated air freight hub for the export of perishable products to South‐East Asia and other destinations. It is a very important consideration for the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) because this particular development impacts on both areas of his portfolio.
I would support the view of the honourable member for Wills that Essendon airport ought to be closed down. It is an inappropriate facility to be operating in an inner urban and residential area of a major city. It ought to be closed down and at least part of its functions transferred to Avalon airport.
Avalon was recently leased by the government to a joint venture between Lindsay Fox and a British company, Serco. The Geelong community has long argued for this facility to be developed as an air freight hub for the export of perishable products. I would encourage the government to support the project through the various programs it is funding in this budget, particularly through its supermarkets to Asia strategy and some other programs that might be appropriate. I hope that the minister for transport will examine those programs and assist the development of this facility in whatever capacity he can .
Avalon airport is situated at the juxtaposition of four key transport assets. There is the airport itself, the Princes Highway, the port of Geelong and the national standard gauge. Very few locations on the face of the earth have this particular transport advantage.
We have a skilled labor force in the Geelong region. The proposal that we are mounting to turn Avalon into an air freight hub for the export of perishable products will see produce drawn from the south‐eastern region of Australia, a four‐state hinterland comprising Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Riverina of New South Wales.
We have tertiary institutions very keen to support this development from a training point of view and some very substantial commercial players that are ready to invest in this development. The government did close ASTAS in its first year, with the loss of 450 highly skilled jobs to the Geelong region. I am asking the minister to look closely at this proposal and the government to look to ways to edge this development along. We believe it offers the Geelong region the opportunity to create 5,000 jobs in the immediate Geelong region, if the vision we have for this facility were to become a reality.
The government and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development should assist this particular development on two grounds. The first is the utilisation of a critical transport asset because Avalon is a very high quality airfield compared to others throughout Australia and the second is regional development because of its job creation potential.
Comparable developments overseas have seen enormous job creation take place around the development of airports as air freight hubs. We certainly have the productive hinterlands to feed this particular facility. All that is required is for the Victorian government to show a bit of metal and a bit of vision and for the federal government to pick up the baton on this project and run with it. I can certainly promise a bipartisan approach to the development of this
facility because I have been advocating such a development for well over 4½ years, as have other members of the Geelong community.
I ask the Minister to examine the proposal closely and to use government programs to support it.
(Time expired)
Mr ROBERT BROWN
(Charlton)
(4.48 p.m.)
—Mr Deputy Speaker, earlier today I took the opportunity to make some observations about the regional development part of this portfolio, or rather I should say the regional development part which used to be in this portfolio until the present government withdrew all of the funding as a result of the announcement made in June or July of last year.
My comments provoked a response from the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) who has, I acknowledge, a personal interest and background experience in the steel industry. In replying to some comments that I made about the BHP decision to withdraw from primary steel producing in Newcastle and the important core activity that that represented for the regional economy, the member for La Trobe suggested that the market imperatives were of primary importance, if not of exclusive importance. If the market realities were such that profit could not be made for any particular activity, then the obvious decision that private sector owners would make—that is, to close that activity down—would appear to be the most appropriate.
I make two points about that, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I do not want to spend too much time on it. The first one is this: BHP in Newcastle makes a profit. The trouble is, BHP in Newcastle is not making the profit that BHP wants, which is 15 per cent return. No steel industry, no steel corporation anywhere in the world is making 15 per cent. BHP Steel in Newcastle makes a profit. That is the first point.
The second point I want to make on this question is that the claim made by the free marketeers, the economic rationalists and the economic libertarians to the effect that market realities must be allowed to rule supreme, is something we have to get right away from. If the market mechanism was appropriate to resolve all of the types of problems that the free marketeers appear to suggest, then we would not have any need for government. We would not have any need for any type of mechanism for the maintenance of social order, social equity, social justice and social security. The market would do the lot.
I know people will say, `Oh no, it's absurd to take it that far.' But the point I am making is that, once you start to move along the spectrum of the roles that market mechanisms can fulfil, you have to draw the line somewhere. Market mechanisms will not resolve all of society's problems. That is the very reason why government, in a positive way, exists. If we do not exist for those reasons, then we exist for no reason, and government might just as well wither away.
For 200 years, people have accepted the fact that market mechanisms are not sufficient to overcome the types of social inequities that a free market system, a free market society and a free market economy may cause. For that reason, it has been accepted that government—the public sector—does have a responsibility to attend to those examples of market failure to ensure that where social equity, social justice and social security are not necessarily provided by market forces and the operation of the market, government will be active in those areas. So it is a matter of degree.
Quite clearly, I believe that line should be drawn not so far along as some of the free marketeers would appear to support. Governments do have a role and governments have to accept that role. The sooner we come to some type of rational decision about where
government responsibility ends and where the indicators of the market can be allowed to operate, then the sooner we will be making a better approach to the whole question of public policy. I spent more time on that than I wanted to.
The matter I want to go on to now is the general question of transport funding. I said this morning, and I repeat it again, that the area of funding in regional development has been eliminated, so the only area which remains in this portfolio is that of transport.
(Extension of time granted)
In the area of transport, I am also concerned about the very significant retreat which has taken place as far as policy is concerned on the part of this government.
In relation to the national highway system, everyone will be aware that in 1974 the Whitlam government adopted that national highway system and established the intercity links all around Australia—not all intercity links, the highway from Brisbane to Cairns was an additional road that was put into the Queensland system. There are other examples around Australia. But 16,000 kilometres of highways around Australia were accepted with full responsibility by the federal government as national highways.
During the period that I had responsibility in the area of land transport, I declared two additional roads, the Sturt Highway in New South Wales and the Newell Highway in New South Wales, linking Adelaide to Sydney and Melbourne through to Brisbane respectively, as additional lengths of the national highway. That added another 2,500 kilometres, for which the federal government took full responsibility. They were added to the national highway network in January 1994 and they are now locked into it.
In this area, where the federal government has primary responsibility, we see that very serious cuts have been made. It was announced that the cuts over a period of years in the Howard government's allocations to national highways would have been a bit over $600 million. In last year's budget the reduction was $113 million. In this year's budget the reduction is $138 million.
In the two years that this government has been in office, the real reduction in national highway funding has been over 15 per cent. I well remember, because I was the minister responsible, the criticisms that were levelled at the previous Labor government by the then coalition opposition about the level of funding. The level of funding when Labor was in government averaged in excess of $800 million every year. During the One Nation and Working Nation programs the cabinet was responsible for allocating an additional in excess of $600 million into those road networks.
I draw attention to some of the transport programs and transport initiatives that were taken during those years. I am delighted, of course, in my usual modest way, to take some credit and to take a great deal of pride in some of those initiatives. I have referred already to the 2,500 kilometres of national highway that were extended as a result of the addition of the Sturt and the Newell highways. There were programs for state arterial roads, programs for provincial cities and rural highways, and programs for local roads.
I know that the cuts that have taken place in funding for local roads will mean, for all of those 850 local government authorities around Australia, a reduction of something like 400 kilometres of new sealed road every year. I hope people in local government understand that. I hope they realise where the cuts are being made and who is making them. We introduced the black spots program together with a 10‐point road safety program and those initiatives together were responsible for bringing down fatalities on the roads each year from something like 2,400 to a number below 2,000. I know that it is now crawling up again.
Urban public transport provided the states with a lot of urban transport opportunities that would not have been available to them otherwise. We established a National Road Trauma Council, the National Road Transport Commission and the National Rail Corporation, an important initiative which this government is in the process of considering the best way to dispose of it.
The last decision that I participated in before I ceased to be minister was with Allan Brown, the Victorian transport minister. We came to an agreement to complete the last link—from Melbourne through to Adelaide—in the standardised rail right around Australia. That then stands as a monument not only to the Liberal government in Victoria and Allan Brown as the minister, but also to a Labor government in Canberra and Bob Brown the minister at that time.
These are the ways in which a national government can accept responsibility not only for transport itself—and the tremendous importance that transport has to the development of the national economy—but for the important role that it plays in regional Australia. That is why those two portfolios are linked together. That is why they should be funded, and funded adequately. This government has betrayed both of them.
(Time expired)
Mr O'CONNOR
(Corio)
(4.58 p.m.)
—I wish to address my remarks at this stage of the debate to the regional development portion of the transport and regional development portfolio. It is very clear that there is a central failure of the government's economic policy, especially in relation to the regions of Australia. I travelled throughout those regions after the first budget and after the second budget, and there is a deep sense of betrayal at what the government has done to the regions of Australia in those two budgets.
Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that infamous first Howard budget when the funding for the regional development program was completely withdrawn by the federal government. For the life of me I cannot understand how the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) can come into the parliament and say that he is the minister for regional development when, by his own admission in that press release after the first budget, he declared that the federal government had no constitutional interest in the area of regional development.
Of course, what followed in that budget was a reduction in business support programs that have hit regional businesses. There has been a massive curtailment in labour market programs that delivered skill formation to rural and regional businesses and, of course, there was the abandonment of the building better cities program, which was a vital conduit for getting moneys into regional businesses throughout Australia. We see that the essential funding has not been restored in the budget that has been delivered by the government.
The reflection of the government's failure in the area of regional policy is contained in the unemployment statistics that were released recently. We see that the state of Victoria is bearing the brunt of conservative governments at both the state and federal level, with massive increases in the rate of regional unemployment since the Howard government came to power in March 1996. To quote some of the statistics that have been recently released, we have seen a dramatic increase in the unemployment rate from 8.4 per cent in my particular region, the Barwon‐Western District region, to 12.9 per cent.
That is a massive increase in unemployment in my own region, and that story is repeated throughout the length and breadth of Victoria. Clearly, through the length and breadth of its programs—and not only in this portfolio but in other areas in the budget that it recently delivered—the government is failing to deliver the critical support that is required for the
regions of Australia to sustain their economic base in the face of significant rationalisations that have been undertaken in both public and private sector employment over the past five years.
We have seen the Kennett government in Victoria drive the boot into country Victoria, but we thought perhaps that the Howard government, with a significant National Party input, would be more sympathetic to the desires and aspirations of the regions. But, no: not only did the first boot go in with the Kennett government but the second boot went in with the current federal government in its first and second budgets.
All we asked of the coalition government when it came to power was to maintain the high levels of growth and job creation that we had given in the past four years with a four per cent growth rate. That was a fairly simple task, we thought, because we had done it over the past four years. But, in your first budget, you admitted defeat. You rolled over and admitted defeat by saying to the Australian people and to the people in the regions, `We can only manage 3.5 per cent.' You admitted defeat again in the budget that you have just delivered.
I cannot for the life of me understand where you are at, and neither can the regions of Australia. They know now. There is a real and deep sense of betrayal. The payback will come at election time, because the National Party has betrayed country constituencies, and the rural Liberals have done nothing either. The payback will come at election time.
(Time expired)
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
(Maranoa—
Minister for Veterans' Affairs)
(5.03 p.m.)
—I thank members from both sides of the House for their contribution to the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98. There have been some very emotional speeches and some very major contributions from some. I will not mention all the names, but there were certainly some in relation to Newcastle. We all feel a sense of sadness for the people of Newcastle. That has been reflected from both sides of the House. It is a genuine concern, and the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) spoke extremely well in relation to the situation in Newcastle—being a former steelworker himself and understanding the industry.
I cannot help myself in relation to responding to the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor). He said that the government has done nothing for regional development. He comes from the city of Geelong. What have we done in relation to car tariffs that will directly benefit the people of Geelong and the people of this nation? We have halted the tariff reduction that Labor put in place and we are ensuring jobs for the people of Geelong and many other parts of regional Australia, including up in the mid‐north coast of New South Wales—and so the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) will have jobs for people in the future.
The member for Corio has left the committee, and no wonder: he did not want to hear the truth of what we have done. He has run away. He has slunk out of the chamber. We are creating jobs. As the member for Charlton said, there is a role for the government. We acknowledge that. Our decision in relation(Mr Robert Brown) to tariffs for the motor car industry was appropriate, and it is going to support not only the motor car industry but component manufacturing industries in regional Australia.
Mr Bevis
—What about sugar in Queensland?
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
—I will listen to your side of the debate in silence; I would hope you would extend the same courtesy to this side of the House. I will just touch on federal road funding and regional development. The other side of the House seems to have lost something in relation to regional development. We are committed, and remain committed, to regional Australia. That is clearly evident by the fact that we have established a ministerial working
group on regional affairs. Those RDOs that were put in place under Labor are still out there, where the people in the regions wanted to put them together. We think it is appropriate that local government is involved, because local government is the level of government closest to the people.
Let me outline some areas of funding going into our regions. We have $75 million going to the Pacific Highway. I well remember the member for Charlton when he was transport minister.
