I think it was during the election campaign of 1990 and there were the tragedies of the road accidents and deaths on the Pacific Highway. None of us liked witnessing those tragedies. To ensure that the Pacific Highway is funded, we have given the Pacific Highway its own line in the Budget. I think if members on the other side of the House were honest with themselves they would say that the only way to commit to a road such as the Pacific Highway, which was in chronic need of upgrading in many areas to prevent dangerous accidents and many deaths occurring, is to give it its own line in the Budget.
The $75 million of road funding on the Pacific Highway will see jobs created in regional Australia and will also see a much safer road infrastructure in a very fast growing region. We are going to spend $696 million on the national highway system. We have $112 million for roads of national importance. We have reinstated the $36 million that is going to the road safety black spot program that was abolished by the Labor Party. They said that local government could pick up those black spots. We have reinstated it.
We have done a lot for regional development and I have to remind those on the other side of the House of what we have done. There is the $250 million for regional telecommunications infrastructure, another job creation program that will bring much better telecommunications infrastructure into regional Australia. There is $1.25 billion going into the National Heritage Trust, an injection of funds into our greatest natural resource—that is, our land, our rivers, our streams.
(Extension of time granted)
There is $58 million going into the national landcare program and $10 million for tourism in regional and rural Australia. So there is a range of initiatives.
I urge those on the other side of the House to go back to their offices, look up the appropriation bills, find those programs, go into their constituencies and promote them, because they will help their own constituencies. That is their responsibility—to work for their constituents. There are a lot of initiatives that will assist regional and rural communities. There is funding to ensure that we have a national road program. We have identified the needs of the Pacific Highway, with its own line in the Budget. This is a government that understands the needs of our regions, and also understands the need for a national road infrastructure. We are committed to a national highway program.
In conclusion, I want to thank those members from both sides of the House. I urge them to go and look at the budget appropriation bills, because there are a lot of initiatives there that they can be involved in with their communities and that will advantage their own communities. Many of them, of course, live in regional areas. I thank members.
Mr ROBERT BROWN
(Charlton)
(5.10 p.m.)
—I must very briefly respond to a couple of the points that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) made. I appreciate, as have others, the fact that so many ministers have been here to hear the consideration in detail stage of the appropriations of concern to them.
I know that Minister Scott knows that the black spots program was initially introduced by the Labor government. It was supposed to be a program initially of $40 million. It was so
successful in achieving all of the objectives that had been set for it that we finished up applying a total of in excess of $270 million to it. I have no objection to the re‐introduction of that particular program with funding of $36 million per year. I hope it achieves the same sort of success as it did under Labor.
As far as the Pacific Highway is concerned, one would believe almost that it had been ignored by the Labor government, but in fact we were responsible for contributing towards a program which represented $300 million going into that highway over a period of three years. I know the points that were made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs reflect his knowledge of the very serious problems that were posed by that road.
The other thing that I want to make brief mention of before we conclude the discussion on the transport appropriation is to make an appeal to the government to consider very carefully what it may finish up doing with the Indian Pacific rail service and perhaps the Ghan service as well. Under the previous government, the Ghan was completely refurbished and became the first major train service of that kind to be significantly improved. There was then a program of $12 million for the refurbishment of the Indian Pacific. There is no question that those two services, in particular, are two of the really great train journeys of the world.
Everyone realises that, throughout the world now, tourists are increasingly looking for experiences of that kind. We have, for example, the Orient Express trains in Europe and Asia, and Rovos Rail in southern Africa, and I will be taking the opportunity later on this year to have a close look at Rovos Rail. I will be going on that service between Pretoria and Lake Victoria. Let me say at this stage, to get it in the record, that I will be doing that trip at my expense because I am interested in the developed of these services. Rovos is privately owned. Rohan Vos has undertaken private investment for the refurbishment of all of those trains. It is a magnificent service, and I am looking forward to having a look at the way in which private services are operating.
We also have the Rocky Mountaineer in Canada and the Sunset Limited in the US. We have had the traditional trans‐Siberian railway services, and all of these at the present time are in the process of development.
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 5.13 p.m. to 5.25 p.m.
Mr ROBERT BROWN
(Charlton)
(5.25 p.m.)
—Before the division, I was making an appeal to the minister, to the government and to the government's advisers to give close consideration to all of the options that might exist in relation to those rail services. I know there are problems associated with their operation at the present time. I am not sure what the annual debt is of the Indian Pacific but I know that it is substantial. But there are people now who travel around the world looking for tourist experiences and adventures. Any people with whom you speak who may have had the opportunity to go on the Indian Pacific either from Perth to Sydney or from Sydney to Perth all speak so well of it. When I have had an opportunity to be on it I find it is really quite remarkable to see the diversity of people from so many different countries around the world. When you talk to them, you get some idea of the number of people who travel to Australia simply to take that trip because they have heard of it. It is a magnificent trip. People who believe that the Nullarbor is boring find that it is anything but boring when they get on the Indian Pacific.
In conclusion, Mr Deputy Speaker, I appeal to all of our colleagues, and encourage them, to take the Indian Pacific if they have to go from Sydney to Perth at any time, instead of flying
over—with all of the traumas associated with that. In fact, what we should be doing is taking advantage of the opportunity to use rail services more often. Everyone says they love travelling by rail and no‐one is doing it. I appeal again to the government and their advisers to ensure that the Indian Pacific and the Ghan are not mothballed, that they examine all of the options, and that they ensure that those magnificent train journeys continue to operate for all the people who would seek to take advantage of them.
(Time expired)
Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
(Batman)
(5.27 p.m.)
—I rise to speak about the all‐important issue of regional Australia, and in doing so to place some facts on the record going to the failure of the government to actively support regional Australia, not only in the most recent budget but also in the budget of last August.
The Prime Minister (Mr Howard), in the lead-up to the election, said that he was going to govern for all Australians. I will tell you what: there is one section of Australia that has lost, and lost dramatically, as a result of this government's decisions in its first two budgets. I would remind the chamber that soon after being elected, the Howard government said that there was no constitutional role for the government to actually serve and assist regional Australia. I must say that to me there is one issue of major importance to regional Australia at the moment. That goes to the questions of jobs and job security. For regional Australia, it has been a wasted 15 months of government; regional Australia has lost. It has lost because of a failure of this government to give support for initiatives aimed at attracting industry and investment. It has lost because this government has really walked away from its responsibility to give ongoing support, for example, to area consultative committees and regional economic development organisations.
The facts speak for themselves. The Prime Minister, in the lead-up to the recent budget, went all around Australia in the media suggesting that he was going to get relevant. That was the headline in the
Australian
in the week before the recent budget. The Prime Minister, after 12 months, thought it was necessary that he had to thump his chest and tell regional Australia that he was going to get relevant.
I will tell you why he had to tell regional Australia that he was going to get relevant: there was one reason and one reason alone. He basically failed regional Australia on the question of jobs. I would like to refer to this government's record with respect to jobs in regional Australia after the first 12 months. It is interesting to note that outside of the capital cities, after the first 12 months of this government, 77 per cent of rural and regional Australia have seen no dent in the unemployment queue.
Let us go to a couple of states, because facts speak loudly. Outside of the Melbourne metropolitan area, unemployment went from 8.5 per cent in March 1996 to 10.3 per cent in March 1997. Outside of the Sydney metropolitan area, unemployment went from 9.8 per cent in March 1996 to 10.6 per cent in March 1997. I know the Minister for Veterans' Affairs does not like these facts.
Outside of the Brisbane metropolitan area, unemployment grew from 10.3 per cent to 11.5 per cent in the first 12 months of this government. Outside of the Perth metropolitan area, unemployment grew from 7.5 per cent to eight per cent. Finally, outside of the Adelaide metropolitan area, unemployment grew from 7.3 per cent to 7.8 per cent. Yet this government has the hide to come in here today and suggest that it is a government that governs for all of Australia. It has the hide to come here today and suggest that it cares about unemployment in regional Australia. Regional Australia has lost because of a lack of attention and support
for regional Australia. Regional Australia requires a government that is prepared to get involved, roll up its sleeves and offer a helping hand to try to reduce unemployment in regional Australia.
The real problem is that it is getting worse. I take the chamber to the most recent long‐term regional unemployment figures and I will deal, by way of example, with the seats of Richmond, Page, Cowper and Lyne. In March 1996, unemployment was 11.8 per cent. Guess what it is this week in four coalition seats: it is 14.5 per cent. This government suggests that it cares about unemployment in regional Australia. I would hate to see what the government is doing for those seats if it did not come in here and claim that it was delivering on the issue of jobs. In that area, there are now 3,000 more unemployed people than there were in March 1996.
But that is not the real black spot. There are worse areas of regional unemployment as a result of the first 15 months of this government and the fact that in its budget strategy it has walked away from its responsibilities. It has taken jobs and services out of regional Australia. It has closed Commonwealth Employment Service offices. It has closed taxation offices. It has closed Family Law Court opportunities.
(Time expired)
Mr SLIPPER
(Fisher)
(5.32 p.m.)
—I had not actually intended to speak in this debate but I must say I was appalled by the contribution made by the shadow minister opposite. One could have taken into account what he said more seriously if he was not part of a government that destroyed 420,000 full‐time jobs during the recession that we had to have. It ought to be noted that full‐time employment fell from 6.2 million in July 1990 to 5.8 million in November 1992.
He also outlined some of the figures in relation to unemployment in rural and regional Australia. The simple fact of the matter is that his government had no ideas; they ran out of them. In fact, youth unemployment in much of rural and regional Australia was up around 30 per cent. This government has a range of programs designed to give new opportunities to young people, not only in rural and regional Australia but also in urban and metropolitan areas. I think people are sick and tired of absolute hypocrisy.
The member opposite is a member of a party which in government was responsible for the worst recession we ever had. It was a government which simply could not tell the truth. It was a government which was prepared to do and say anything to crawl back into office. It was a government that saw 313,000 men lose full‐time work, many of those people in rural and regional Australia. I think it is about time that the honourable member opposite stood up and was honest and said that the Labor Party over the last 13 years made a monumental botch‐up in the area of unemployment. They failed to offer hope to young Australians. They, indeed, were complete and utter failures.
If he came in here and said that Labor got it wrong over the last 13 years; if he came in here and said that their policies were disastrous for rural and regional Australia, he would have credibility and he would have the right to criticise what this government is doing. His party was a government which was responsible for the worst economic situation that this country has ever seen—a government which, during its 13 years in government, had an average unemployment figure of 8.7 per cent. He fails to recognise that the coalition has only been in office for 15 months and that the benefits of the very many programs which we have implemented have not yet flowed through to the job market.
I would ask that he be honest. I would ask that he express regret for the disaster that was the Labor government over the last 13 years. It is absolute, complete and monumental hypocrisy for the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) to come into the Main Committee and claim that this government has been a failure when the record of the former Labor government is there for everyone to see. I thank the Committee.
Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
(Batman)
(5.36 p.m.)
—I welcome the contribution of the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). But I am prepared to deal with the facts; he was rather provocative as to the question of truth. Last Thursday evening, on the
7.30 Report
, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) wanted the Australian public to believe that we ought to be patient, that it is a big ship and it is really a huge problem to turn it around. He was talking about the question of unemployment. But, after all, facts tell the real story.
I want to deal with the performance of this government after the first 15 months in office. Let us go to the issue of facts and the question of jobs. In the 15 months since the Howard government took office, the number of jobs has only risen by 86,800. More importantly, the number of full‐time jobs has actually fallen by 700. The number of male full‐time jobs has fallen by 9,900. The number of people unemployed has only risen by 39,000, because unemployment has risen from 8.5 to 8.8 per cent.
Now go to the issue of youth unemployment, where we are now all about fudging the figures with the new youth allowance, hiding young unemployed people, forcing them off benefits. I will tell you why. The Prime Minister said at the National Press Club on the eve of the election that he would be judged by his performance on the question of youth unemployment. What we have is a new strategy now about honesty and integrity in government; it is about fudging the figures. And I am not surprised, because after 12 months the youth unemployment rate has risen—yes, risen. That is a real problem for this government, because the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) is correct—this government has to be judged by its performance on the issue of jobs.
I am prepared to basically judge our performance, as the previous government, against the performance of this government in its first 12 months. That is what the member for Fisher challenged me to do. Unemployment under this government in the first 15 months has risen from 8.5 to 8.8 per cent. What did the current Prime Minister, who was the then Treasurer, leave us with in March 1983? Surprise, surprise—he left us with double‐digit unemployment—a pretty big ship, as he described it on the
7.30 Report
last Thursday; a big unemployment ship to turn around.
I note that the member for Fisher is yet again running for cover, because he does not want to deal with the facts. We reduced unemployment, in our first 12 months, from 10 per cent to 8.9 per cent. As he puts his tail between his legs and runs out of the chamber, because he does not want to deal with the facts about unemployment, I would again take him to the question of regional Australia. I have dealt with some of the Northern Rivers seats in New South Wales. Let us go to the real black spot on the unemployment front in regional Australia at the moment—Victoria. Rural and regional Victoria has become the black spot, and we know they like to talk about black spots. Regional unemployment is now 11.2 per cent, compared to a pretty bad state average in Victoria of 9.2 per cent. We have a coalition government at a state level there, as well as at the federal level.
We ought to go region by region. In the Barwon‐Western District region it is 10.9 per cent, a huge achievement. In March 1996 it was 8.4 per cent—and they say they are creating jobs!
They want us all to believe that this government cares about regional Australia and is committed to trying to reduce unemployment queues in regional Australia. Let us go to the Central Highlands and Wimmera. I know the Deputy Speaker understands the importance of these issues as a representative of rural Australia. Unemployment—surprise, surprise—is 9.8 per cent in that region. That is a bit higher than the national average, but what was it in March last year? It was 7.9 per cent. That is another great achievement, one that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) likes to stand up and gloat about.
We will go to the Loddon‐Mallee district. It is 12.3 per cent—a bit worse than the state average of 9.2, the gift of Jeff Kennett for John Howard, but much worse than the national average. What was it 15 months ago? It was 10.4 per cent. I tell you what, they are really getting the runs on the board! The Prime Minister is playing on a sticky wicket when he talks about unemployment in regional Australia.
We go to the Goulburn‐Ovens‐Murray region with 8.1 per cent. If you care about regional Australia, you have to be prepared to invest in regional Australia—to prop up and support regional initiatives under area consultative committees, to be willing to get involved and to get your hands a little dirty in trying to develop local economic development strategies and to be willing to support labour market programs.
(Extension of time granted)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
—Before the member for Batman continues, I remind him that the committee is debating the appropriations for the Department of Transport and Regional Development and not DEETYA.
Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
—That is why I was really trying to deal with the all-important question of how you support regional initiatives such as REDOs and area consultative committees. Do you know what REDOs and area consultative committees used to do? They used to really embrace those Working Nation labour market type of programs because out in regional Australia there is a real problem in raising the necessary expenditure to support capital works. I can understand that because I believe that regional Australia is entitled to the same level of services that we receive in metropolitan Australia. That is why regional economic development organisations are of the utmost importance to regional Australia.
On that note, I want to talk about the fact that regional economic development organisations are now most concerned about the fact that the Working Nation programs were ripped away from them. This government wants us to believe, for example, that Green Corps is of assistance to regional Australia. I will tell you that it is not of much assistance to regional Australia and, more importantly, it is not of much assistance to the unemployed. The facts show that in the first round of pilot projects under Green Corps, the majority of people were either employed or engaged in full-time education. The opportunities did not even go, in regional Australia, to unemployed people.
If I were a National Party representative, for example, of those northern New South Wales seats, I would be crying out for support for the unemployed—not support for people who have jobs or education opportunities. I would compare that with the old LEAP programs that the old REDOs used to really embrace and support and try to provide infrastructure in their regions with.
I go, for example, to Green Corps—a mere $3.7 million for 1996‐97. That compares with nearly $90 million under the former Labor Party government's LEAP program—the old landcare and environment action program.
I agree with the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). Let us deal with the facts and the real issues that Australians are concerned about at the moment—the issues that regional Australia is, in some ways, I suppose, off its face about. Their view is that this government has walked away from its responsibilities. The real issue goes to the question of unemployment and the requirement to put in place regional initiatives that do something to assist regional Australia.
If you want to assist regional Australia then, for example, it is not smart to close the Taxation Office in Launceston, it is not smart to close the Department of Immigration office in Townsville, and it is not smart to close the CES office in Mareeba because they are all local jobs that regional Australia depends on.
When you take those jobs out of regional Australia, you do not just take government jobs out of regional Australia but you actually take out regional Australian private sector jobs because those pay packets disappear from regional Australia. Public servants are not buying local goods and services and therefore the private sector jobs disappear.
I understand why the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is looking a little concerned at the moment because when we lay the facts on the table the conclusion is that this government does not care about the all-important concept of one nation, of one Australia and of all Australians being entitled to the same level of services, irrespective of whether you live in metropolitan Australia or regional Australia.
I put to the House that the Commonwealth government has a responsibility to get involved and assist regional Australia. The Commonwealth government has the responsibility to actually develop regional initiatives such as the old REDOs aimed at trying to create jobs and, in the meantime, also assist the unemployed with decent labour market programs.
That is what it comes back to: do you care about Australia at large? Are you going to run away from your responsibilities for regional Australia? Do you believe that the high level of unemployment that currently exists, for example, in the Northern Rivers seats of New South Wales is acceptable? Or is it the view of this government that it is prepared to cop ghettos in the Northern Rivers area of New South Wales, as indicated by its lack of support for important country towns such as Lismore? I know that does not count much to the coalition government because in the end it is has got a huge majority and it is prepared to sacrifice a few seats on the way through. But I do care because if you do not invest in those regions and actually support regional initiatives, you end up with an underclass in Australia.
This government might be prepared to tolerate a regional and rural underclass; I am not prepared to tolerate a regional and rural underclass. As far as I am concerned, whether you live in Mareeba, Burnie, Sydney, Melbourne or Adelaide, you are entitled to the same level of services, the same investment, and a willingness by the government to actually lead and make hard decisions.
(Time expired)
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Health and Family Services
Proposed expenditure $2,879,850,000
Mr ANDREN
(Calare)
(5.46 p.m.)
—I wish to comment on a few aspects of this department's expenditure, particularly as it applies to the new aged care reforms. I am sorry that the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) is not here to hear these remarks, but I presume she will read them at some point.
I, too, want to place on the record my support for the thrust of the reforms, particularly the accommodation bonds option of funding infrastructure for nursing home accommodation. Somewhere this week I saw a mention that $1 billion, or thereabouts, is needed to bring the system up to standard. Obviously, as much as we would like to pay for that bill from the public purse, it is just not feasible. So the users who can pay option is the only route.
Just let me clear the record. During my move to splendid independent isolation in the House in the week that the vote was taken on the aged care bill, I became a little disorganised without the aid of any unofficial whipping support, so
Hansard
will show my voting against the bill but supporting the consequential amendments. I misread the third reading division as another attempt to gag debate and so literally misplaced my support for the legislation. I correct that now.
However, I must say that there is still a great deal of concern out there in the regions—and elsewhere, I presume—about certain aspects of this legislation. Let me just detail them quickly. Those providers of concessional only or near enough to total pensioner clients are concerned at the lack of capital funding the system will provide. The St Vincent de Paul organisation in Orange is one which doubts its ability to raise sufficient funding through bonds, and it certainly does not believe that the $5 a day contribution from the Commonwealth will go anywhere near meeting that need. They are talking about at least a doubling of that amount.
The Uralba Hostel at Carcoar is typical of a smaller rural community aged care centre. It believes that the $5 a day for concessional residents will go no way towards meeting its capital requirements. These shortcomings in the plan are causing real concern out there and are jeopardising the positive sale of these reforms in the marketplace. This money—that is, the $5 a day—will provide for this Carcoar hostel $9,250 per client over five years, while a bond could deliver $13,000 in the same time.
You see, the home with concessional patients is worse off. Why can't they access a bond? Because in very many cases the partner is living in the home, or on the farm, and there are no assets to access to pay the bond. It is a catch‐22 situation. There is, according to Uralba Hostel at Carcoar, no way they are going to be able to pay for capital rebuilding or upgrading.
Uralba agrees totally with the ageing in place philosophy, keeping elderly people in hostels where possible. But, if they are forced to push these people into nursing home accommodation—and they are becoming more and more every day nursing home‐type patients—the subsidies they will receive are well below what they get now and they will not be able to meet capital updates. They will not even meet the standards to be able to charge bonds and will not, perhaps, be able to survive in places like Carcoar.
Take the case of Yeoval multipurpose health centre, once just the district hospital, which was closed by the state government. The community fought like blazes and started their own cooperative health care which has grown into the model for multiservice health delivery. I would urge the minister to take a look at that facility, perhaps visit it, and see what I believe is the future of integrated hospital health and aged care delivery in rural Australia.
Yeoval entered into a recurrent funding agreement with the federal government, took out a loan, and is being repaid by the Commonwealth for that capital program. Now it has to decide whether to maintain that arrangement or go down the uncertain path of accommodation bonds and the $5 per day for concessional residents path with all the same concerns that Carcoar has about its aged care capacity under these reforms.
I realize there is $40 million set aside for rural and remote areas to address critical capital funding problems, but I suspect neither this amount nor the $5 per day contribution will go anywhere near being sufficient.
I ask the minister to seriously consider what I have said here today. I support the thrust of these reforms but the expenditure details, I believe, are seriously flawed.
Ms ELLIS
(Namadgi)
(5.51 p.m.)
—I want to specifically address, in these few minutes that I have, the questions that arise from the decisions the government has taken, as evidenced in the budget papers, to do with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I am particularly concerned at the changes to the therapeutic group premium, as it is formally called, which are apparently going to take effect from February next year. As we know, this is going to make Australian citizens have to pay more for the latest and safest or most effective medication in the six drug groups that are treating things like high blood pressure, high cholesterol, ulcers, depression and so on.
The reason for my major concern is the comments that were made by the president of the AMA, Dr Keith Woollard, very shortly after this decision was announced in the budget. He has said that although separate medications within the six nominated classes had similar therapeutic effects, they could have different side effects which made them less appropriate for some patients. He said:
They—
the government—
have lumped them together as drugs having basically identical actions, but in fact they don't.
I find that particularly alarming when it is coming from someone like the president of the AMA. I couple that with statements from the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, where they feel that it is necessary to monitor the changes that are going to take place under the PBS through this new strategy. The national president of the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia said that the PSA would monitor the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme contained in the 1997 federal budget to detect whether or not they were having any adverse effects on consumers.
I find it pretty appalling that a government can take a decision where, first of all, the AMA has a view quite different on medical grounds to the government's and, secondly, an organisation like the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia believes it is necessary to monitor for adverse effects. I do not think that it would be very responsible for a government to take a decision in the health area where there could be any question of adverse effects on consumers. Mr Plunkett, the president of the PSA, has said that while some people argue that some of the moves may be a cost saving measure for the government, others argue that it will significantly change prescribing patterns and adversely affect the health of patients who will not be able to afford to buy those more expensive drugs.
I seriously believe that the government needs to look very carefully at what it is doing to the PBS, for two reasons. First of all, the PBS as we know it in Australia has been a very highly applauded and, might I say, highly envied process by the rest of the world. It has worked extremely effectively and has been held up as a model for many places around the world when they look at the way that we can dispense pharmaceuticals on a fair and even basis to our community. Secondly, and even more importantly, there is the question of whether or not it is going to adversely affect the health of those people in this country who may not have any choice in terms of whether they can afford to buy the preferred drug.
I also ask this question of the minister: when, if ever, will the detailed arrangements and costings of the new structure be made available? The model has, I believe, been talked about in Senate estimates; we do not have that detail, it has not been made available. I think it is terribly important to everybody involved in this process that they have access to that detail. As I said at the outset, I raise very sincere concerns on the basis of health care and I question the government's decision in this PBS process very seriously indeed.
Mr MOSSFIELD
(Greenway)
(5.55 p.m.)
—In the five minutes that I have, I want to refer to the child‐care aspects of the expenditure. In looking at child care, we need to look at the 1996 and 1997 budgets, because some of the effects of the 1996 budget are only now taking effect. In the 1996 budget, we saw a $500 million cut in child‐care funding and in 1997 we have seen a further cut of $321 million—amounting to a $821 million cut in two budgets. This, of course, is going to have a devastating effect on child care, throughout the country.
Initially, I want to relate one example of a single parent who came into see me. I do expect that, when I get back into the electorate at the end of next week, there will be quite a number of people who use child care coming in to see me. The single parent—a single lady with one child—is going to TAFE at the moment to study to improve her skills so that she can get employment. Her actual child‐care bill has increased by $36.50 since May. Taking into account that she is a single mother on a pension, that is an astronomical amount of money. Of course, the end result is that she cannot now afford to keep her child in child care for the full week, and has now withdrawn her child from the child care facility for at least two days per week and has to use other arrangements through parents and grandparents. This is at considerable inconvenience to herself because she has to travel considerable distances to take her child to be minded.
To clarify the cost increase of $36.50 since May, it comes about in two stages. Firstly, as a result of changes to child‐care assistance, the child‐care fee for this particular lady went up from $28 per week to $43 per week—an increase of $15 per week from 26 May. Secondly, as a result of the removal of the operational subsidy which will take effect from 1 July, her fee per week for that one child went up from $43 per week to $64 per week—an increase over that period of $36.50. This is quite outrageous. It is totally impossible for people to keep their children in child care when they are on low incomes and have large bills and a mortgage to pay—or, as is the case with this particular lady—when they are actually on a pension.
Having given that example, I just want to give a little background to child care in general. Maybe a lot of people do not know that this was not a Labor Party piece of legislation. It was not the Labor government that introduced child care. It was, in fact, the McMahon government in 1972 which introduced child care, in recognition of the increasing number of women in the labour force and the subsequent need to provide affordable, quality child care to their children. In hindsight, of course, this was a very noble and far‐reaching piece of legislation. It certainly showed a lot of vision in relation to the numbers of women who have entered the work force over that period. But now we see a government of the same persuasion actually cutting back on child care.
The need for child‐care places to assist women in the work force should be recognised. The rate of female participation in the work force has increased from 40.6 per cent in 1972, when it was introduced, to 53.4 per cent in 1996. This increase has been particularly high in the 25‐ to 59‐year‐old age group. My own particular electorate contains a large, fast growing residential area where two‐income families reside and more young families are moving in at
a rapid rate. There is, therefore, an urgent need for family support services, particularly child care, to allow both parents to take part in either full‐time or part‐time work so that the family's budget can be balanced. Clearly, this is no time to decrease child‐care funding; it is now time to increase it.
It has also been suggested that low income families will have a considerable increase in the cost of their child care. It was thought initially that that might be between $29.50 and $50.90, but in the case that I have quoted there was an increase of $36.50. There are some industrial consequences too.
(Time expired)
Mrs CROSIO
(Prospect)
(6.00 p.m.)
—I too want to speak in this budget debate on this particular area. I not only want to touch on what my colleagues have mentioned—and I will come back to that—but also want to say how I believe some of these cuts have hurt some of the most disadvantaged families in our electorates.
I have already condemned the cuts and I do so again here quite publicly. For example, look at the cuts to pharmaceuticals where another $700 million has been taken, after $500 million was taken last year. We are looking at a situation where people out there will pay in the vicinity of $20 for a prescription. Look at the cuts to child care, where $320 million is to go over four years, and that is on top of the $500 million cut we endured last year. Look at what is happening to public housing. Something like $400 million is to be cut there. I know it does not necessarily relate here, but I still want to touch on that.
The savings spoken about are going to come by increasing the cost of drugs for those who are least able to afford it. We find that there is going to be $112 million saved by abolishing the subsidy on a number of those medicines. If you talk to some of the pensioners who can ill afford to pay the price now and you say to them, `You will probably be paying in the vicinity of $9 for a prescription,' they reply, `Where are we going to get the money from?'
People who can afford it will pay for the best but people who can ill afford it are the ones who will be caught in the trap. I think it is appalling that the government is saying to them, `You're going to have to take the generic brand. You're going to have to tell your doctor that he has to give you the generic brand because this is the way we are going to save all this marvellous amount of money.'
People who are very ill, and especially the aged, do not understand the treatment they are getting. They cannot say to their doctor, `Look, if you give me drug X, I really cannot afford to pay for it. You have got to give me drug Y because that is what the government said I am supposed to be taking.' Evidently, government members now know that it is going to have a bad effect on particular people.
Aged people get used to taking medicine of a certain colour and a certain shape. They get used to the doctor who treats them. They know they must take their red one at this time and their blue one at this time. How do we convince those people to change? I am referring to the aged in my community. The generic brand may be a different colour or a different shape, so who is going to say to them, `Don't worry about that, it's cheaper for the government and that is why you are going to change. If you get mixed up and you find that your tablets are not doing the right thing, don't worry about that either, you can always come back and see us'? That is really an appalling stance on which to base some of the savings we are going to make in this budget.
One war veteran came to me and he said, `I've got a special cream that is prescribed for me on the free list because of an allergy I picked up during the years I was away fighting.
Does that mean I've got to pay for it?' We investigated that for him—he is quite an elderly man—and we found, yes, that cream is going to come off the free list as well. I had to get back to him and say, `Yes, it is, but we will try and take another tack for you, we will go to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.' The ointment is something he has to use for the eczema that goes all over his body but it is now going to be taken off the list. I do not think the government has considered how some of these decisions are going to affect the people in the street.
When you talk about child care it looks very clear cut—$320 million over four years. It is almost like going back to the days when you were told, `You have your kids. Stay home and look after them.' It is saying to the women who make up 52 per cent of the population, `If you have your kids, you are not going to have a job. Get out. We want to get the unemployed back into jobs. We are going to do it for the sake of the family.'
That is an appalling situation. We are going to go back to what was referred to many years ago as latchkey kids. I remember, even in my own community, kids of eight, nine and 10 going home with a key around their necks. You used to think it happened only in the movies and you only read about it. This is fact; this is what happened. That key was on a chain around their necks and they had to use that to let themselves in.
We do not realise the ramifications that are going to occur in communities like mine where the mother and the father are both out in the work force. They are now going to have to pay up to double the fees. They will not be able to pay the fees in the child-care centres where the increases have averaged between $27 and $43 a week. That is an appalling cost on top of everything else that parents on very limited incomes have to cope with. They are trying to add to society through their work. They are also trying to make sure that their children are looked after properly on the limited amount of money that they bring home.
I do not think that the government should go backwards and say, `In future, if you want your child minded, and if you cannot afford to pay those fees, that is going to be bad luck. Tell you eldest kid to pick the kids up from school and bring them home,' or, worse, go back to what it was previously. I can go back 15 to 20 years ago when you virtually had a little backyard shed where children were minded because it was offered at a cheaper rate. I do not think we should go backwards and I do not think we have a need to go backwards. I believe that is what some of these cuts will do. There are a lot of other things I want to touch on and I will get to them when I get another call.
Mr JENKINS
(Scullin)
(6.05 p.m.)
—Mr Deputy Speaker, one of the difficulties when dealing with such a large portfolio as Health and Family Services is that when we consider it in detail we jump around all over the place on different topics. At some stage, whilst we cannot dictate to the minister how he wants to handle responses, he might try to get some order or he might choose to respond to some of the topics already raised.
I wish to raise the therapeutic premium groups decision of the budget. I think it is an important decision that needs to be explained because it is a vast extension from generic prescribing to, as it now seems to be called, brand premium. The problem there is that, of course, under generic prescribing we developed a system that was dependent upon the drugs being the same and having the same bioequivalence but under different brand names. This was important for the generic manufacturers who were coming on board as drugs came out of patent. It gave them an attempt to compete against those that had already got the drug listed
under different brand names. In fact, to the extent with which we can have that form of competition to have the drugs listed, it engendered that.
But the theory behind the therapeutic group premium is dependent upon the fact that, and I quote from an answer in the Senate estimates, `the drugs are very similar, chemically related drugs.' The problem is that they are not the same. I think the minister would understand that. It is not for me to talk to him about medical practice, but there will be situations where these drugs will not suit the patient's circumstance. That is the difficulty with this in the clinical sense. There will be patients that require to have other drugs in the group for whatever reasons. It is one of the quirks, I suppose, of modern medicine that these things happen, especially for some of the conditions where patients will be having a cocktail of medicines and therefore really need those medicines adjusted.
The other thing that I might add is that these are drugs that are already listed. We are not talking about generic manufacturers trying to bring on a new brand name of the same drug. I reject the argument that the therapeutic groups premium will create the competition that is suggested because it is a very closed market dependent upon the listing.
The thing that has to be stressed and is sometimes I think glossed over and ignored is that those drugs that get listed on the pharmaceutical benefits schemes are listed at costs that are much reduced compared with what drug companies can achieve on more open markets overseas. Already, over the years, because of the nature of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and because of the nature of the way in which drugs are listed, we have been able to attempt to put a lid on the costs.
I know that the minister, like his predecessors under Labor administrations, will jump up and down and say that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, if you look at the graph, is going right out of the ceiling. But he has to acknowledge that attempts have been made to put a ceiling on that and to dampen it. But I just believe that the therapeutic groups premium is not the type of thing which is likely to achieve the results that are suggested. It is not likely to get the acceptance with the consumer that is expected. Already we have had to have a very softly, softly approach to generic brand funding. The honourable member for Prospect (Ms Crosio) talked about people preferring their red tablets and their blue tablets. One of the real things that we had to be careful about with generic prescribing was where there was a change in the colour and the shape the patient was going to have some rejection of the concept. We have slowly but surely, I believe, won the battle.
What we probably have not done yet is educate the consumer to ask the questions at the right stage. Even under generic prescribing, the patient is there with the general practitioner, the GP writes out the script, the patient takes it to the chemist, it is dispensed, and it may not be until the patient gets to the cash register that he realises that, under the brand premium scheme, he has a higher cost drug. These things need continual education. It is too early and too ambitious for the therapeutic premium group scheme.
(Time expired)
Mr ALBANESE
(Grayndler)
(6.11 p.m.)
—I rise tonight on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98 to raise the issue of Medicare office closures. Two office closures in my electorate will be caused by this budget: one in Leichhardt, situated at Leichhardt Market Town; and one in Marrickville Road, Marrickville, just down the road from my electorate office. A third closure—that of the Campsie office—in the electorate of the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) will also impact on my constituents around the Canterbury area.
These office closures were foreshadowed in last year's budget. Thus 12 months of uncertainty have been caused by this government. Last year a document indicated that up to 86 offices might be closed throughout the nation. The budget last week indicated that 43 offices will be closed. It is interesting that 17 offices are to be closed in New South Wales, and nearly 80 per cent of those offices are in Labor electorates. This very political decision by the government says: `If you vote Labor, you do not deserve services.'
People in Labor electorates are less likely to have access to transport and their income tends to be lower than that of people who live on the North Shore and in the eastern suburbs of Sydney, and yet it is the people in the Labor electorates who have been most adversely affected by these changes.
There has been considerable disquiet, certainly in my electorate, about these changes. On 17 May, a rally was organised at Leichhardt Market Town, with the support of the local council and the local state member, Sandra Nori, the member for Port Jackson. I participated, along with the workers—about to be non‐workers—of the Leichhardt Medicare office. That rally was well attended.
There was another rally on 17 August last year at the Marrickville Road Medicare office, organised by myself and Dr Andrew Refshauge, the New South Wales Minister for Health and Deputy Premier. At that stage, it had not been indicated that the Leichhardt office would be closed. I invite the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), who is at the table, to the rally which is being held on 3 July at the Marrickville Road Medicare office.
It has been organised by me and other members of the community, with the support of the local Marrickville council, and the state member, Dr Andrew Refshauge. I invite the minister to come to Marrickville, to downgrade himself and come to an area which, whilst it has some economic difficulties, is an area that I am proud to be associated with. I am sure the minister would get a very interesting welcome to that electorate, especially when he tells the people that their Medicare office is being replaced by a fax machine in a pharmacy somewhere up the road.
Opposition to these office closures does not just come from the people directly affected. The closure of a government office in a strip shopping centre takes away business from the other shops in that area, because the people who go to the Medicare office to get their rebates or whatever will not be going there. A lot of concern has been expressed to me by small businesses in both Marrickville and Leichhardt about the negative impact that these changes will have on their business. That is symptomatic of a government which is reducing services.
It also flies in the face of the commitment that this government made during the election campaign that there would not be any attacks on Medicare. There is no doubt that closures of Medicare offices, in conjunction with the massive cuts to health funding and pharmaceuticals, which the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) has highlighted here tonight, all add up to a major attack by this government on the public health system. It should be noted that New South Wales in particular has suffered in terms of public health funding. It would appear that it has been penalised for having a Labor government, just as people in the western suburbs of Sydney are being penalised for voting Labor at the last federal election. I am sure, with responses such as this, they will continue to do just that.
(Time expired)
Ms ELLIS
(Namadgi)
(6.16 p.m.)
—There are two more issues that I particularly want to raise in this debate tonight. The first one is the removal of particular areas of health concern from the Commonwealth to the states and territories. In saying that, I note that two particular
programs—the immunisation program and the Aboriginal sexual health program—are to be retained by the Commonwealth. That is fine and I do not have a problem with that. There are very obvious reasons, particularly in relation to the immunisation program and the great debate around that, as to why that has been done and why it is a good decision.
But I really wonder how a government makes it decisions in this area. I understand that programs such as the cervical cancer program, the breast screening program, the national drug strategy, the HIV/Aids strategy and the national women's health program are all going to be allowed to slip through to the states and territories. I have serious concerns about this government's attitude about the role between it and the community when it looks at the way in which it wishes to govern and in which it wishes to deliver services to the community.
There are certain areas that I believe should either be retained by the Commonwealth or should only go through to the states and territories under very strict circumstances because of the need for equality of access to service and for equality of delivery and level of service that is going out to the community. I question very sincerely why this government can make a decision to retain certain programs and not others. Is it because some are more important? Is it because some are more sexy out there in the community? What is it that makes a Commonwealth government decide that it is going to retain its role with the immunisation program but it is not going to retain the same level of role with cervical cancer or breast screening or the HIV/Aids strategy? I would like to hear some detail on how this particular area of the government's health portfolio operates.
I want also to quickly touch on—and this was brought up earlier tonight—the issue of nursing homes. In the debate in the House, in the detailed stage of the particular bill and the budget decisions that surround it, there was a great deal of screaming and carry‐on from the government benches about our shadow minister and our side of politics running scare campaigns. I feel very strongly about that accusation. I had the opportunity the other day, and I repeat it here, to say that the comments coming to me—as a federal member in this parliament representing a constituency from the ACT—were coming not from my shadow minister but from the community. I want to talk about that.
The people who were presenting their views, concerns and worries about the whole implication of this strategy include Aged Care Australia; the Mirinjani Retirement Village at Weston, which is within the ACT; the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, speaking on behalf of the Alzheimer's Association Australia; the Australian Council of Social Service; the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation; Baptist Care Australia; Churches of Christ Network of Aged Care Services; the Salvation Army; Community Services Australia, and the Uniting Church. I also had direct representations from the Aged Services Association of New South Wales and the ACT, and the Churches of Christ Homes and Community Services Incorporated.
The reason for my bringing this up is quite clear: we were not running a scare campaign at all and we are not now. We are attempting to reflect to the government, through the appropriation debate, the concerns from people at an incredibly high level out there in the community who service those who require access to nursing homes. I am dealing right now with a constituent—in fact, I have had two conversations with her today—who is desperately trying to get access to a nursing home. Her overriding concerns are about how all of these future implications will impact on her family.
I have also had discussions with people within the ACT who are going to be able to leave a nursing home, because they have been inappropriately housed up until now, and they are younger people. They are trying to make sure in this program being offered to them, where they can exit that nursing home, that should they find, after being in there for some years, that the transition was not as favourable as they wished they could re‐enter. They have been told that they probably can, but only if they pay the up‐front fee.
There is a lot of myth and a lot of misunderstanding in the community, but also an enormous amount of fear. I think the fear is very well‐founded. Do not blame us for it. Go to the community and talk to them. They are the ones who are coming to me and telling me what they think of this particular decision.
Mrs CROSIO
(Prospect)
(6.21 p.m.)
—I also would like to bring to the attention of the minister the concern that is being expressed in my community over the cutting back of the family resource centres. It was not something that was advertised; it was not something that you were all of a sudden told was going to happen. You had to read through line by line, item by item, of the budget papers to find out that the 11 family resource centres throughout Australia, which were originally set up in 1991 as a Labor initiative in some of the most disadvantaged areas in Australia, were going to have their funding done away with. In fact, they have all been told that that funding has to cease as of December this year.
You wonder why, when you look at what is happening with domestic violence, particularly domestic violence against women of non‐English speaking backgrounds; at what is happening with drug and alcohol abuse, which is a topic very dear to my heart; and certainly what is happening with unemployment. In an area like mine, it seems that we have all of these things against us. When we have a service that is helping to coordinate help for people and to assist people affected by these problems, it's difficult to see that being taken away.
It is just another harsh decision that this government has taken without realising the long‐term ramifications. It is not just some little group of people who are buried away in an area that people do not have access to. These are very organised people who are concerned, who are out there working in the community, coordinating and putting programs into place. In my area in particular, I found it ironic that after the decision to cut family resource centres, including the centre in my electorate, which we call Ettinger House because of the historic place they operate out of—the very week when we were objecting to these cuts, the Minister for Family Services, the honourable Judith Moylan, actually came out and opened an ethnic Chinese nursing home. It was the completed product, but what is interesting is that the very first line of putting together the application for the nursing home occurred when a group of Australians of Chinese descent, who wanted to provide for their aged, went to Ettinger House, which in turn helped them fill in their application and showed them how to go about getting funding. Then, when all of that was done, we put it forward to the minister of the day, saying that we would like funding to go ahead for that group of people.
That is just one of the many examples I could relate, time and time again in this parliament, of what has been achieved since that resource centre has been operating in our area. In fact, when it was first mentioned the council welcomed it so much that they even provided the finance for it for the first 12 months while it was getting put together and before the government took over the payment.
It is a centre that is not just a few wishful people sitting around a cup of coffee in a corner. This is a centre that is operating both effectively and efficiently. It is saving the government
just in the type of hands‐on service it is able to provide. Yet we see in this budget that not just my centre in Fairfield but the 11 resource centres across Australia are going to go by the wayside. I do not think enough investigation was done into that and I hope the people in the Senate, when they are considering the budget, will consider that.
I would also like to add that my electorate is suffering again in the cuts to the Medicare centres. We are actually losing one in Cabramatta and one in Merrylands. In an electorate like mine that basically means that something like 500,000 people are going to be treated to one Medicare office in Fairfield itself—and the queues are out the door now. A lot of those people are from non‐English speaking backgrounds and the staff, who are superb, have to help them fill in the forms and show them what to do. There is going to be nothing else in all the area from Liverpool to Parramatta except the one in Fairfield. We are closing down the other two. It is absolutely appalling. This is an area where we need growth in these types of facilities, which are required, and what do we do? We are shutting them down. Where do these people turn to? Do you think they are going to go to a pharmacist and fax away a rebate form? Most of the people who go through my Medicare offices now are there waiting for the payment to come back. I know we have one of the largest bulk billing areas in a community like mine.
But those who have got to pay that money up front cannot wait for another week or two weeks for it to come back. That is why a lot of them take their forms in personally so that they can put them over the counter. They can be assisted by the staff there, and they can wait and get their payments. It may not mean a lot to this minister or this government. But believe me, in a community like mine that extra $15, $18 or $20 means a lot for that mother to go home with. She realises then that she can pick up the bread and the milk and the stuff for the kids on the way home because she has got that little bit more money back in her pocket.
That is not going to happen now. She is going to have to wait in the queues that are already accumulating out through the doors on that one particular service. Previously, they had the possibility of going to other offices in the area. Now that has been denied them. How many more cuts are we going to see for people that live in western Sydney? It is the largest population growth area in all of Australia, I daresay, with the largest growth, too, in the number of first settlers coming in—52 per cent of my electorate was born overseas.
We are not saying that they are the most literate people in the English language. They are not. They need these services. We welcome these legal migrants to the country—I am not talking about the illegal ones—and yet we are taking the services from underneath them.
(Time expired)
Mr JENKINS
(Scullin)
(6.26 p.m.)
—The honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) alluded to the closure of the 11 FRCs around Australia. In the budget papers the item that refers to it—and it is not an item in the appropriations—is in budget paper no. 2, page 7, where it mentions broadbanding other family and children services for 1997‐98, minus $3 million; and for 1998‐99 minus $6.4 million, with $6.6 million and $6.8 million in the out years.
I do not know whether we need some sort of cipher to work out what these code things are, but when you go to page 78 of this document to get the fuller explanation, it does not even mention FRCs. It talks about consolidation of a number of other programs. It is just a real worry that here is a government that has come in saying that they want to have transparency in their budget documents, and things like that, and it is just so difficult to work out what is going on.
The item I now want to turn to is an issue that has got legs since about last Friday and that is the defunding of the Family Planning Association and the Australian Pensioners Superannuants Federation. These were organisations funded under the Community Sector Support Scheme.
Later on, in response, I hope that the minister (Dr Wooldridge) can clarify what is actually really going on here because if one goes to the appropriations, it would appear on my reading of the appropriations that in 1996‐97 the estimated actual is $6.355 million. The appropriation for this year's budget, 1997‐98, is $4.987 million, a 22 per cent decrease. I want to make sure that I have got the facts right on that because if that is correct, then the explanation that the minister gave in his interview on
PM
on Friday and the explanations that the minister representing in the Senate has given in a couple of questions yesterday, are inadequate.
I understand the point that the minister put in the
PM
interview that he had four or five organisations, as I understand it, receiving seeding grants that have now gone to a fuller form of funding. But one has to ask why those two organisations that have substantially been defunded have been picked out.
As it transpires, it appears that a Coopers & Lybrand study that was commissioned by the government did not, in fact, recommend the defunding of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, so this is a decision of the government. But it would be interesting to have fully explained the reasons that the Coopers & Lybrand report cannot be made public because if it was important in the decision making of government, it should be important in the public discussion of the defunding because legitimately, there can be suspicion about why those two organisations were defunded.
It is legitimate to ask whether the defunding of the Family Planning Association is something that has been a requirement on the government because of the discussions with a certain independent senator. Likewise, with the defunding of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, is it because the federation has been harsh in its criticism of certain items? The honourable member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) mentioned that organisation as one that had been critical of the nursing home decision. It is legitimate to ask these questions as there might be legitimate answers that can quell the fears that people have. I think the minister would agree that these organisations have an important role.
I want to refer with a bit of modesty to a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs entitled
You have your moments
. The chair was the member for Scullin at the time—this was back in February 1991 so it is a dusty document. The committee recommended continued Commonwealth funding for national secretariats of non‐government health, housing and community service organisations on the basis that public education, public debate and community consultation assist the development of appropriate policies and programs, especially where disadvantaged groups are concerned. I think that that still stands and I am not saying that the government does not recognise that.
(Extension of time granted)
One of the reasons for the defunding appears to be that, as the minister has said, there are two other organisations that are well placed—I am not sure whether he is saying better placed—to convey the thoughts of people who have interests in aged care or aged people themselves. I would think that if it has been satisfactory to have this diversity of view, including that of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, then that should continue.
The minister may have a problem because he believes that, because that organisation takes up issues of social security and the like, it is outside of his portfolio. That was why I read the recommendation which was couched in terms of the government having an obligation. I believe the government cannot run away from seeing that it has an obligation to organisations such as this one, and that it should take a whole of government approach. The spokesperson for that association has said—I believe that most members would acknowledge this point—that income support is very important to the health of any sector of the community. To dismiss continuing funding for this organisation on the basis that it takes interest in social security matters is a nonsense.
But the real thing that I want to get clarified is whether the underlying reason that these two organisations have been defunded, besides the suspicion that they might in some way be being punished, is that the funding for this program has been reduced by over a fifth. If that is the case, we will have things trotted out that say that it is the previous government's fault, et cetera, which, of course, is an absolute nonsense. But let us get it on the record so that we can clearly identify the commitment of the government to this program. I am quite happy to have it explained that I have got the wrong end of those figures. It is a one‐line item. It is an appropriation in Appropriation Bill (No. 1)—I think it is 340 2.02. That 22 per cent reduction needs to be explained.
As I said earlier, this portfolio has a smorgasbord of issues that one could raise. I am quite satisfied that a number of the issues that I would have raised have been raised by my colleagues, whether it be the issue that the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) raised, which affects my electorate, about the closure of the Reservoir Medicare office, or whether it be the discussions that we have had about nursing homes and aged care. The honourable member for Batman reminds me of the closure of the Heidelberg Medicare office, very important for the overall scope and coverage of Medicare offices in the region. I think it is perhaps a bit disconcerting that we have had this debate in the way that we have.
I know that from time to time the honourable member for Batman's behaviour either in the chamber or in the Main Committee is a bit disconcerting, but he reminds me of an issue about the Medicare closures. The simple fact is that the statistics show that six out of the eight closures in Victoria were in Labor‐held seats—six out of eight. Given the circumstances of the electorates we hold, that is a very important thing to expose and to keep reminding the minister of. It is also a fact that, on the occasions when I have tried to get a greater coverage of Medicare offices and an office in the city of Whittlesea, responses have been couched in terms of it being the HIC's problem. It is clear that, on this occasion, the minister interfered in the decision‐making process. Let us not get into the nonsense that it was actually the commission's decision: it very much had direct government involvement.
Mrs CROSIO
(Prospect)
(6.36 p.m.)
—The member who spoke previously, my colleague the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), reminded me that the newsletter that just came from the Alcohol and Drug Council of Australia pointed out that all public health funding had now collapsed into a one‐line appropriation. The ADCA is concerned because decisions have not even been made yet as to how much is going to be allocated to HIV/AIDS, national drugs strategy, diabetes, et cetera. One of their other concerns affects an area like mine, in that there is a major initiative which will involve removing methadone from the Medicare scheme and replacing this form of Commonwealth funding with a set payment through a specified cost‐shared funding scheme. Trials of the new arrangements will take place this year, and
methadone is due to be removed from Medicare in November 1998. This measure is expected to save the government around $19 million over four years. What a cheap saving that is!
Recently the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of this country announced—if my memory serves me correctly, it was on 5 June—a program of something like $13 million at a federal level over three or four years to look at domestic violence and associated crime—this without looking at what is causing domestic violence and crime in this country. At the same time, it is estimated that nearly $4 billion is being collected in this budget with excise and taxes on alcohol and on tobacco. Yet, in the same budget, we find—again, through press releases put out by the very reputable Alcohol and Drug Council people—that something like only $33 million out of that $4 billion is being put back into a drug education strategy.
If you take that one step further, you find that the $33 million that is going back into the national drug strategy program for education amounts to less than $2 per person throughout Australia. In other words, that is how much we think about the 500 lives that are being lost every year in this country through heroin overdose.
I recently had a private member's motion in the House, and there was even a
Witness
program last night, concerning drug deaths and what they mean to the families and to the community. It is a theme I have been pushing for quite some time, as you realise, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I will use the opportunity given to me tonight to again appeal to the minister. I know that in the questions I have had on the notice paper that both he and the Prime Minister have said, `You want a national drug summit, but that is actually a waste of resources and a waste of time.' What price do we put on human life? What price do we put on it when we can take $4 billion in revenue and yet give only $33 million back to the National Drug Strategy?
I believe that when we are talking about the cost of human lives we have to relate those human lives to our own areas. I know for a fact that something like 44 heroin deaths occurred in 1995 in my electorate due to heroin overdoses. In the very week that I was speaking about this particular topic in the parliament, three more people lost their lives in Cabramatta, which is part of my community. I know these people may not have parents who are as articulate as some of the other parents who are now taking up their cause, but they are still someone's brother or sister or husband or son or daughter.
People have got to start caring; people have got to start caring when they see that so many of the young people in the electorate are being affected. People have got to start caring when they see that 11 per cent of 13‐year‐old kids in one of the high schools in my electorate have already tried heroin. Yet I hear from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) that we do not need a national drug summit and that it is a waste of time.
I sit and try to talk to people. The experts all have different opinions. I have not got the answers, and so I say, `Why not bring the experts of Australia together? Why not bring all the states, the medical people, the police and the judiciary together? Why not bring together the community workers, the church workers, the families, and even the drug users? Put them all in an area together and say, `Let's work something out.' Obviously, what we have done in the past has failed. We have people still dying on the street; yet we are able, in our health budget, to make cuts in areas at the same time that an overall budget is reaping extra billions of dollars.
Action has got to be taken at this level here and now. It is a national problem. For a national problem we need a national solution. And to get a national solution we need a national summit. We cannot say to a community, `It's your problem; we're going to walk away from it'; to the states, `It's your problem; we're going to walk away from it.' It is Australia's problem. It is a medical problem. It has to be treated as a medical problem. It can only happen if we get the Prime Minister of this country taking the leadership role.
I appeal again to the minister in the chair. You have got to look at where we are going in this particular regard. It is not just me as a backbencher in the opposition calling for a national drug summit. You have got most of the Directors of Public Prosecution around Australia. You now have the AMA putting out their figures saying 1,182 people died last year from drugs and drug‐related illnesses. They are saying that the only way you are going to overcome it—the minister was a member of the AMA—is to bring the experts together and let us have a national drug summit.
Ms ELLIS
(Namadgi)
(6.41 p.m.)
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. One more really important issue that I would like to discuss here briefly tonight is the question of youth suicide and the ongoing funding that has occurred in previous, current and hopefully, future budgets. I say hopefully; in fact I know that it will be continuing.
The simple message that I want to bring to this debate tonight in relation to the funding of this program is this: the previous government had a commitment, roughly $13 million over four years, that began in the 1995‐96 budget for a program called Here for Life. My figuring now is that we have entered the third of the four years of that program.
We also have the current government bringing in a new program last year with continuing funding this year, called the National Youth Suicide Prevention Strategy, of $19 million. I am a member of a committee in this place that has recently brought down a summary report on this subject, which was tabled in the House recently.
When we consider the expenditure of the these funds I implore the minister to consider certain factors. It is imperative in my view that the previous government's program and the current government's programs are somehow linked, reflected or learned from. There seems to me to be a great risk that the allocation of the current funding through to the new program appears to be getting, to some degree, done in isolation from the earlier one. I would be happy to be contradicted on that.
There also seems to be, again in my view, a lack of, or a very low level of, funding through to the educational level. When I talk about that what I am meaning is that for the appropriate data to be available for any government to carry out a sincere approach to the question of youth suicide we really need much more detailed national collective data than we have. It is all very well for us to understand that, for argument's sake, young men in rural areas commit suicide at a higher rate than, say, young men in other areas. But we do not really understand to any great detail why. We know the symptoms; we can have experts give us the symptoms. But we really do not have that detailed data that I think should be had to that level.
The other thing is the need to recognise the signs of depression, particularly in our young people. Are we putting enough money and effort into our schools, into our counselling services, through to our GPs and our general community nursing areas so that they are actually taught to see and are advised to look for the appropriate signs, so that they can see what is going to happen in front of them?
One of the most appalling statistics in the whole of the debate of the question of youth suicide, or suicide generally, is that I understand that 60 per cent of those people who eventually succeed in the act of suicide have in fact tried it before. We really need to question what we are doing wrong in terms of follow‐up, counselling, recognition and understanding that we allow that 60 per cent who have tried it once or twice earlier and failed to eventually achieve that end.
We should look at this in a constructive fashion. I am not saying any of these comments in a particularly biased view. The committee that I am on really approached this subject from a very broad base of consensus. We all agreed across the board that we needed to do something desperately. But what I am saying is that from my perspective, from what I have observed and what I heard, these areas really need to be addressed. Are there enough school counsellors out there?
