Are we going to have a whole of government approach sufficient to attack this problem? Are we going to isolate it only into certain areas? Are we going to be able to say, within the health area, for argument's sake, that an effect within the education area is going to be recognised? Are we really going to put enough into youth services? Are we taking enough consideration of youth homelessness, youth unemployment and all of the other pressures that we have?
As the previous speaker was talking about drugs, are we looking at that? Are we taking enough into consideration from the mental health area? Are we looking at whether or not our services in addressing mental health are, in any way, contributing to the question of youth suicide? These are the things that need to be looked at carefully, holistically, across government and nationally.
I know that there is and has been, between the previous government and the current one, a huge amount of effort and money going into it. What I am suggesting is that we need to take a very deep breath and look very carefully at how we are expending those funds so that we really understand what it is we are attempting to attack and then direct those funds in the most precise fashion that we can, given the difficulty of the subject at hand.
Dr WOOLDRIDGE
(Chisholm—
Minister for Health and Family Services)
(6.46 p.m.)
—I thank honourable members for their contributions. I understand there may still be some people who wish to make a contribution and, if the opposition will allow me, I may make several contributions. I will try to respond to people's concerns. This debate has gone on for some time and I do have to leave. If there are any subsequent contributions, I will make sure they are addressed.
A number of members have put forward queries and that is right and proper. This committee stage has been very useful. The first contribution was from the member for Calare (Mr Andren) who talked about aged care. It did seem to me that he was more canvassing issues that were in the Aged Care Bill. He talked about uncertainty relating to accommodation bonds and the amount for disadvantaged customers of $5 a day. I think a lot of that uncertainty about accommodation bonds has now been removed. I just make the point that our costings on $5 a day, as I understand it, actually give homes more than they are currently receiving today. Obviously, people will always ask for more. That is one thing I have learnt in 15 months in government: I have not ever found anyone who has said the amount of money they get is enough.
The member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) talked about therapeutic premiums predominantly in her first contribution and said that it was going to deny people access to the latest and safest
medications. This is not actually correct. One of the reasons we are doing it is so that people can get the latest and safest medications. We are talking about medications such as Verpamil, which has been available certainly for 20 years and probably for 30 years. I say 20 years because I can remember it had been around for some years when I started medical school.
The difficulty with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is merely its size. It is already about 1½ times the budget of the state of Tasmania and, in spite of all the changes we are making, next year alone we will spend $300 million more on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme than we did last year. The difficulty is that what we inherited was increasing at 15½ per cent per year without taking into account new drugs coming on to the market. That meant something that is 1½ times the budget of the state of Tasmania is doubling in cost every four years.
We also have new drugs coming on board. One I am dealing with at the moment is Lanzapeen for schizophrenia. It is a particularly high‐cost drug that I am hoping to be able to bring onto the system. If I am going to find the resources to bring these new latest and safest medications on, I have to have a system that is able to afford that.
Therapeutic premiums are really an extension of what we have had now for seven years with generics. I do remember some of the claims that were made—and I have to say they were made by the government when in opposition—about what generic pricing would do. Most of those claims proved not to be correct. This sort of scheme already exists in a number of overseas countries, particularly Holland, Germany and New Zealand. It has not caused any of the great problems that people have suggested.
The member for Namadgi talked about the AMA opposing it. That is about my benchmark for good policy. I think if the AMA opposes it, I am probably doing the right thing. The Pharmaceutical Society of Australia said it is necessary to monitor the changes and I agree with them. I do not wish to do anything that is going to cause people difficulty and we will be monitoring them too. With the experience we have had in those overseas countries, I do not see that there is going to be a great problem.
The member for Namadgi also asked for detailed arrangements. We did, short of giving out the spreadsheets, give as much as we could in the Senate estimates, but there is a degree of cabinet-in‐confidence in these issues. Other than what we have given, where we have tried to be cooperative in Senate estimates, I am afraid I cannot give any more.
The member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield) talked about child-care funding and he gave an example from his own electorate. Child care is not my area, but I have been passed a note that it is difficult to see the justification for the fee increases he talked about. I note that he blamed the removal of the operational subsidy for the fee increases and I just note that that has not even come into effect yet. Therefore, it is a bit hard to see how the child-care centre could be blaming something that has not happened for a fee increase that clearly happened some time ago.
The fee increases quoted are for a single parent with one child, studying full‐time, and therefore needing care five days a week. It would appear to reflect a grossly unfair charging practice where parents studying and requiring part-time care are being charged for full‐time care.
(Extension of time granted)
Perhaps the honourable member's constituents should look at fees in private services which are significantly lower, do not get the operational subsidy, have never done so, and where standards there are protected through the community based services as well as by the child care accreditation system.
The member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) talked about the PBS and the government having taken $700 million out of it last year and $500 million next year. I think I have addressed that in the broad. She talked about a figure of $9 a script for her pensioners. I would be utterly confident none of her pensioners would have to be paying that amount. Again, experience overseas is that the majority of these savings come from the pharmaceutical companies and not from the pockets of the patients.
The member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), again on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, as was the member for Prospect, talked about it not suiting certain patients in particular circumstances. This is why we have not made a definitive decision on what is or is not in the categories. That is why I am asking a group of experts—the Pharmaceutical Benefit Advisory Committee, a completely non-partisan committee appointed on the basis of expertise—to determine what should and should not be in and to have a look at the particular circumstances that he states. He rejects that it will create competition. Well, I say that it will and by February 1999 we will know who is right.
The member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) talked about his Medicare offices in Leichhardt and Marrickville. It is no fun closing things down, but I do not make an apology for this. I concede that in Victoria and New South Wales there was a predominance of Labor seats where the Medicare offices were closed, but in South Australia and Western Australia and Queensland there was a predominance of coalition seats where Medicare offices were closed. If you take it over the country as a whole, it was about fifty‐fifty. The criteria that we used was that we had a look where there was another office within 10 kilometres—that did in some cases go out to 12 kilometres—and we had a look where there were fewer than 400 claims per day, rather than per week. I might have to be corrected on that.
We made a few exceptions. One exception was the office in St Ives in the seat of the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) which had the largest claims of any office we closed. We also left open one in Queensland that was slightly less than 12 kilometres away. That was also in a coalition seat. So one was an adverse event, one was a positive event, and both were coalition seats.
I accept that the decision was mine in the end, and that is the nature of these decisions. Of the original list the Health Insurance Commission gave to me, I accepted most of the recommendations. Some recommendations that I did not accept were in both Labor and coalition seats. I generally did not accept recommendations on the basis of strong support from a local member—and members on both sides of the House had put positions to me—and on distance. Initially, they were suggesting that some offices up to 20 kilometres from others should be closed, but I was not prepared to accept that.
I should put it on the record that the whole point of doing this is not cost saving but to try to provide a greater resource for people in country areas. I know it will be difficult for some people in city areas, but it is very difficult now for people in country areas. The trials of the new pharmacy claiming that we have run around Townsville have shown it to be incredibly popular. It has had some glitches, but the trial has sorted them out. As we further expand that around rural Australia, we will be giving rural areas something, where before they had absolutely nothing.
For the information of the member for Grayndler, the Marrickville office had 127 claims per day, which is low, and it was eight kilometres from the next nearest office. The Leichhardt
office had 286 claims per day and was 4.9 kilometres from the next nearest office. That was the basis on which those closures were made.
The member for Grayndler also talked about workers about to become non‐workers. I should put it on the record that this is being done in such a manner that no‐one will be retrenched and people will be redeployed within the system. The member for Grayndler talked about cuts in health funding as an attack on Medicare. The changes we have made have been to preserve Medicare, and that is something that the public understands.
The member for Namadgi talked about programs under the broadbanding of the public health agreement. I suspect that she does not actually understand what we are trying to do, which I take as my responsibility.
(Extension of time granted)
It clearly has not been adequately explained up to this point in time.
The two programs she mentioned—the immunisation program and the Aboriginal sexual health program—are retained by the Commonwealth because they are new. They are starting de novo. They have needed Commonwealth leadership to get up and running. That is the simple reason why those two programs have a significant Commonwealth element.
The ones that she mentioned—breast screening, HIV‐AIDS, cervical cancer—are part of the new public health agreements we are looking to sign with the states. That does not mean that the Commonwealth will not be having an involvement in public health. The fact is, any objective review of what has happened in the last 14 months would show that we have done pretty well in the public health area. I have tried to make it a big focus of my time as minister.
However, in the end, to have rigid demarcation between the Commonwealth and the states means that we may not be delivering the most flexible and most appropriate services. I have absolutely no intention of letting the states walk away from these programs, but for me to actually prescribe day to day, place to place, bed to bed, X‐ray machine to X‐ray machine how these might work, does not give a chance to integrate the federal and state systems.
One of the things that bedevils the health system, as it did under the previous government, is the jurisdictional problems between the Commonwealth and the states. I am trying to do something about it. It is difficult; I accept that. There is always criticism, but if people are being fair, they will realise that ministers on both sides have talked about this for decades. Now that we are actually trying to do something, it would be helpful to have a bit of support.
The member for Namadgi then went on to talk about nursing homes. They are probably covered in the previous comments. I understand that the community is worried. I suggest she says to her constituents, `Remember the system we introduced into hostels in 1987? This is just an extension of that. It has worked very well in hostels, and the reason it is being done is because of the $1 billion shortfall in capital funding that the Gregory report showed was the net result of 10 years of administration by the Labor Party. So it really is a pretty good idea.'
The member for Prospect talked about her Medicare offices. Cabramatta has a very low number of claims—70 claims a day, which is one of the lowest in Australia. It got knocked out on that basis. Merrylands was 287, which was still a fair bit below the 400 cut‐off, and there is another office 3.5 kilometres away. Again, I accept that that will cause some inconvenience to her constituents, and for that I am sorry. The people in country areas who have to travel 40 or 50 kilometres will be fairly happy, though.
The member for Scullin talked about the CSSS program and I am happy to discuss that. Off the top of my head, if he goes back to last year's budget papers he will find that the drop‐off in the forward estimates was because of decisions made last year, not this year. There was no change to the CSSS in this year's budget. As I understand it, the changes were last year's. The change in funding he is talking about is something that would have appeared in last year's budget paper.
The exercise we went through in looking at the funding of certain organisations has been cost neutral. It has not saved us any money at all. There were a couple of reasons why I wanted to do that. The first was that I have actually increased the funding of level 3 organisations fairly substantially—from $108,000 per year to $125,000 per year. The majority on that are pretty happy. I think $108,000 really is a bit too little to run any sort of national secretariat.
The second issue was we just had to change priorities, and I accept that that is difficult. I would say to the honourable member that we actually defunded more than just the two that he raises—it was not as if they were the only ones singled out; perhaps they are the only ones that have been screaming so far—and we did fund a number of new organisations, which are ones that are very worthwhile. Given that money is finite, I have made a decision that I am putting a priority with carers, with volunteers, with heart support, and an organisation that really was on its last legs after it had been defunded, after its seed funding ran out, by the previous government—Asthma. They are things that are very relevant to my portfolio.
The Pensioners and Superannuants Federation have done a good job. I accept that. But their predominant focus is not in the health area, it is in the income support area. They do do some work in health, but I had to make the decision that Asthma, heart, carers and volunteers were of a higher priority. I will obviously have to live with that decision.
(Extension of time granted)
The honourable member for Scullin then went on to suggest that it might relate to discussions with a certain senator. If he saw the full range of organisations defunded, I would suspect he would not, because we also stopped funding to the Natural Family Planning Secretariat as well. I understand paranoia might be a normal state in politics, but I can assure him it did not relate to anything in another place. He addressed the issue of a majority in Victoria being closed, I accept that. But if he looks at the criteria on which it is done and the criteria that I mentioned, he will see why that happened.
The honourable member for Prospect talked about the methadone program. I suspect she does not understand this aspect of what we are doing, because I wonder if she would take the same position if she did. The fact is that there are a small number of people, predominantly psychiatrists, who are ripping the system off, to an extraordinary amount of money, through the prescription of methadone. The fact is that methadone will still be available through chemists, it will still be available through health based services, and the people who will lose out of this will not be the people who need methadone, it will be the psychiatrists who are making three‐quarters of a million bucks a year by doing nothing but doling out methadone—and this does happen.
I spoke about this to a very senior person in one state, who is a psychiatrist, and this person's comment was, `It does not worry me at all. We don't have that rort in this state.' So it did have to end, but I can assure you I am supportive of community based methadone, particularly in the way it operates through pharmacists, and I have ensured that that has continued.
Finally, the member for Namadgi talked at length about youth suicide. I have to say I agree with her. I think the programs that we run do have to have a focus on what works and what does not, we do have to trial a range of projects, we do have to be honest, and we do have to try and build on what has been done previously, rather than start things anew. I hope that is the method we will be pursuing.
Mr GRIFFIN
(Bruce)
(7.03 p.m.)
—I am sorry that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has to go, although I recognise he has been here for some time, because there are a number of important issues which relate to my local area which I would like to raise tonight. One in particular is the question of the defunding of the national family resource centre program, particularly the South‐Eastern Resource Action Centre in my area. The minister has undertaken to take on board what is said from now on and I hope he will have a look at this issue. I look forward to a situation where he will answer this himself at a later time, or refer it on to the Minister for Family Services, the honourable Judy Moylan, for a direct response.
I would like to commence by reading from a letter from SERAC, from the Acting Chairperson, Janet L. Casey, which I think encapsulates the key aspects of this issue very well. It says:
I write on behalf of the Committee of Management of SERAC Incorporated to seek your support in overturning a decision to remove all funding for this program.
On 14th May, 1997—the day following the Federal Government's 1997/98 Budget,—SERAC learned that the funding for the FRC Program would be "reallocated". Subsequent advice from the Department of Health & Family Services (DHFS), in Canberra, confirmed proposals to defund all FRCs on 31st December, 1997.
No specific mention of Family Resource Centres was made in the Budget papers. Hidden away on page 124 of the Budget papers was the mention of
"Broadbanding other family & children's services"
.
The Minister's letter to SERAC explained the decision was designed "to achieve efficiencies and redirect funding to Government priorities. . . ..the Government has decided to refocus funding for the eleven (11) FRCs to broaden the existing networks that provide direct support to families in over 90 disadvantaged areas currently supported by
Youth Activity Services
."
DHFS notified the FRC Network that the "refocussed" allocation to YAS is planned to be
$2.5 million
, expected to be tagged to the employment of family support workers. The FRC budget was $4.7 million+,
so should we assume that the Government is also aiming for savings of at least $2.2 million?
The Commonwealth DHFS also funds the YAS program
"to provide young people aged 11‐16 years, with structured activities and positive peer supports outside school hours, to help prevent them developing patterns of destructive behaviour"
. SERAC agrees that expanding funding to direct youth services is a worthy initiative, but in our view this should not occur at the expense of the FRCs.
At various times since the Budget, Government ministers and local MPs have attempted to argue that Youth Activities Services can do the work of FRCs. This is in fact incorrect. Members of the National FRC Network have come to the conclusion that the proposal to de‐fund FRCs was taken because key decision makers in the government were not fully briefed on the positive work of the FRCs and the high level of community support for the program.
Some local Liberal MPs have publicly defended their Government's decision with arguments that are not supported by any documentation or feedback received by SERAC, to date:
.
that the program was designed to run for 5 years only, and this time is now up
.
that FRCs were designed only to co‐ordinate welfare services & there is no longer any real need for them
.
existing agents can now manage without the FRCs
The Commonwealth Government made the decision in 1991 to establish such Centres in areas of locational disadvantage as part of a national strategy to improve the effectiveness and accessibility of services for families. This particular centre services Dandenong, Casey and Cardinia—one of the fastest growing outer urban areas in Australia.
Whilst the
national potentials
of this small program may not be recognised by the current Government in Canberra, the
positive impacts of this program at local levels are significant
. In SERACs case, I particularly mention the detailed research conducted by this Centre and promotion of strategies to improve service delivery to families in our catchment
(particularly for the most disadvantaged families, adolescents and children)
; also SERACs effective facilitation of a co‐ordinated and forward thinking approach to social planning for local communities in this outer urban growth area. The closure of this Centre and the National Program can only be seen as short sighted.
The Australian Council for Social Services
commented that the abolition of funding to Family Resource Centres was "very damaging", saying further that "Family Resource Centres play a vital role in providing back‐up support to direct service providers." . . .
At the request of SERAC, I urge the minister to respond to th questions that have been raised in this letter. This is a serious issue. The activities of SERAC, which I will speak of again at a later stage, have played a crucial role in the coordination of services in the local area.
That in itself will, over time—and has over time—save money in the local area by ensuring that services are properly focused and, therefore, that services are provided on the most cost‐effective basis. Part of what they are about is trying to make sure that families get a proper go in their local areas.
(Extension of time granted)
Centres such as SERAC are very popular in their local areas. I would like to pick up again on comments made locally and the responses that I have received from the local community. I have here a letter from the Narre Warren Station Primary School, which was in my electorate under the previous boundaries. The letter is from the school principal, Mr Dick Turner. It says:
Dear Alan,
Re
: Funding of
Family Resource Centre
Program, in particular the
South East Resource Action Centre
I represented this community on the Committee of Management of SERAC in 1995/96. SERAC is a unique community support service that works with other vital agencies through three Local Government Areas. The LGAs are extremely diverse, from established suburbs experiencing regeneration from recently arrived migrant groups through to outer‐urban growth corridor development where infrastructure is inadequate.
I really want you to know how disappointed I am that this highly valued and efficient organisation is threatened with the funding axe. I almost believed that the Howard Government was a bit serious about family values. There is intense pressure on social cohesiveness in this part of Australia and the costs of family dislocation augur for long‐term damage and taxpayer expense. I would have thought that the innovative and proactive nature of SERAC is the Commonwealth Government's best hope of recovering the difficulties already evident in this community, and developing effective planning and efficient service response strategies for the future.
SERAC is a highly co‐ordinated, sophisticated and hi‐tech vital cog in the networking of local agencies and all levels of government in this region. It surprises me that advisors of The Hon Judi Moylan are insufficiently informed about, or insensitive to the importance of SERAC, and have failed to draw these matters to the Minister's attention.
The accountability and integrity of SERAC to the local community and to the Commonwealth Government are exemplary in terms of democratic best practice and any assessment of SERAC's operations would show how cost‐effective it is.
The fact is that the sorts of reports that SERAC has been producing over the last few years have been enormously important to local government and to other non‐government service
providers in the local area trying to ensure that the dollars that are spent by government are used effectively. That is really the point that has been missed in this decision.
Earlier, the minister spoke about the need to make decisions around the question of choices on the basis of having a limited cake and a number of different ways in which it requires to be allocated. That is the problem with this decision. Essentially, organisations such as SERAC can play, and have played, a very important role in local areas in order to try to ensure that that cake which needs to be allocated is allocated as fairly and as cost effectively as possible for government in terms of the delivery of services. Others have talked about the question of the need to look at those issues with a sense of concern as to what the real impact is on local areas. That is the sort of thing SERAC also does.
Here we see a decision which, I think, is incredibly short‐sighted. One criticism of government that has been made for as long as I can remember, and I have been here quite a while, is the question of new programs often being established to deal with particular problems which are serious but after a while, the programs are altered and the circumstances are that the real importance of those programs is lost over time. This is partly done sometimes for a concern with changing priorities. Often we are seeing a situation where in the first place, the understanding and the needs of a community are not fully understood by government and, therefore, decisions are made about the allocation of funds which although at the time make sense, or appear to make sense, in fact, in practical reality, they do not.
That is why organisations such as this are crucial in terms of ensuring that government dollars are spent effectively. When you look at the question of what will happen in that area and the lack of coordination which will now occur around service delivery, you have to wonder about the real efficiency of this decision in terms of government. What we might see here is a situation where some $4.7 million is saved under a particular program heading under the Department of Family and Human Services but instead, on from that, money being wasted or not used as effectively as it could be in terms of the delivery of services.
We talked earlier about regional development and the need for communities to have an understanding of the issues in their local area and their capacity to be able to influence those issues. We talk about—as members from the other side often do—the needs of rural and regional Australia and the fact that communities out there are hurting and that, basically, those communities know the answers and want government to listen. We are seeing here a situation where government has defunded an organisation which has played a crucial role in allowing local communities to articulate and develop responses to what is needed in their local areas. It is a bad decision, and I ask the government to reconsider it. I wish to get an answer on these issues.
Mrs CROSIO
(Prospect)
(7.14 p.m.)
—I will be very brief because I realise that time is going to be against me here. I was not going to raise the nursing home legislation, or the bill that has recently been debated because I understood that that was part of the last budget. I know that it only comes into effect on 1 July this year and that they are certainly going to put some other regulations back further.
The minister did raise it in reply to a number of speakers on this side of the debate. When the minister is saying that all these services are going to ask for more money, I would remind him that the Aged Services Association of New South Wales and the ACT that represent, I believe, something like 900 aged care services through New South Wales and the ACT, that they are concerned that the legislation is still not fully explained to the industry out there at
large. Not only do they feel that the $5 a day concessional subsidy is a pittance, but the fact is that we have not explained to them and to all the other agencies that are looking after the elderly in these nursing homes how they are going to come into effect and what they are going to have to do from 1 July.
I actually did a survey of a number of nursing homes in my electorate and I asked, `Do you understand what it is all about, what it is going to mean?' They said, `We don't know. We haven't got a clue.' I went so far as to question the availability of beds in one particular nursing home and they quite openly said, `We've got three available, but we are not going to give them out until after 1 July because we will get more money for them.' I found that appalling. If the minister wanted to touch on it, we could go a lot further rather than just rehash the bill.
You cannot say that these groups that are providing such wonderful services to our aged people are only after more and more money. They are after some understanding of how this bill will affect them bill is intended to do and after something more realistic than the $5 offered to those patients who are going to go in because they do not have the money available from selling their own homes.
There are other issues I would like to touch on but I realise time is up, Mr Deputy Speaker. Therefore, I seek leave to continue my comments at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Main Committee adjourned at 7.19 p.m.

Social Security Recipients: Electoral Division of Perth
(Question No. 1638)
Mr Stephen Smith
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:
(1) How many recipients of (a) Job Search Allowance, (b) Newstart Allowance, (c) Mature Age Allowance, (d) age pension, (e) disability support pension, (f) carer pension, (g) youth training allowance, (h) the sole parent pension, (i) widow allowance and (j) partner allowance reside in each of the postcode areas of the electoral division of Perth.
(2) How many recipients of rent assistance reside within each of the postcode areas of the electoral division of Perth.
Mr Ruddock
—The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) The Department of Social Security provides data on customers by payment type, (apart from rent assistance), in postcode areas to the Parliamentary Library on a regular basis for the convenience of members and can provide the information requested.
(2) The number of rent assistance recipients residing in each of the postcode areas of the electoral division of Perth at March 1997, was:
Postcode and Recipients: 6000—695; 6004—375; 6006—625; 6050—1,538; 6051—1,385; 6052—865; 6053—836; 6054—1,137; 6063—370.

Mrs Johnston
asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice on 13 May 1997:
What sums of federal funding were allocated to (a) primary schools, (b) secondary schools and (c) TAFE centres in the electoral divisions of (i) Canning and (ii) Brand in each year since 1989‐1990.
Dr Kemp
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) and (b) Commonwealth assistance is provided on a calendar year basis and the following are the identifiable grants to schools in the electorates of Canning and Brand since 1989.
Details of General Recurrent, Capital And National Equity Program grants to non‐government schools in the electoral divisions of Canning and Brand follow, together with details of Capital grants to government schools. Wik 10 Point Plan
(Question No. 1673)
Mr Price
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:
(1) Has he formulated a 10 point plan concerning the High Court's
Wik
decision; if so, does the number of properties of the Crown held in one form of lease or another total 9000 and cover 42% of Australia; if not, what are the details.
(2) How many of the leases are pastoral leases.
(3) How many pastoral leases are owned by foreigners or foreign‐owned corporations.
Mr Howard
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) I have formulated a 10‐point plan in response to issues arising from the High Court's Wik decision.
Most leases are administered by the states or territories. Information provided by the states indicates that there are over 171 000 leases, licences or other forms of occupancy for rural, agricultural or pastoral use in Australia. The Australian Survey and Land Information Group (AUSLIG) estimates that approximately 42 per cent of Australia's land area is under Crown leasehold tenure.
(2) Definitions of pastoral leases vary considerably between jurisdictions and within a particular jurisdiction, several differing tenures may be considered to be pastoral leases. Overall, the best information provided by the states and territories indicates that there are approximately 10 824 pastoral or grazing leases in Australia.
(3) Information held by state and territory land administrations is insufficient to determine the number of pastoral leases owned by foreigners or foreign‐owned corporations.
Administrative and Activity Test: Penalties
(Question No. 1676)
Mr Mossfield
asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:
(1) What penalties can be imposed for breaches of the Administrative and Activity Test.
(2) Are penalties imposed as a deterrent in such a way as to avoid disadvantaging clients or creating long term poverty.
(3) Are there investigative or counselling procedures applied when a test is breached on more than three occasions.
(4)Will the Minister's Department amend or improve the way in which it handles those who may have breached the test.
(5) How many breaches were determined by the Minister's Department since May 1996 and what penalties were imposed.
Mr Ruddock
—The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) For activity test breaches, customers incur a non‐payment of allowance for a prescribed period. The length of the non‐payment period increases with the duration the customer has been in receipt of allowance and also where there have been prior activity test breaches in a 3 year period. The minimum non‐payment period is 2 weeks.
The table below outlines the current activity test breach periods:
Unemployment Duration
First Breach
Second or subsequent breach
less than 12 months
2 weeks
previous breach period plus 6 weeks
12 to 18 months
4 weeks
previous breach period plus 6 weeks
more than 18 months
6 weeks
previous breach period plus 6 weeks
For administrative breaches a customer's payment is reduced by 16 per cent for a set period of 13 weeks. Prior breaches and the duration of receipt of allowance have no relevance to the application of penalties for administrative breaches. Rate reduction for administrative breaches, rather than a non‐payment penalty, came into effect in March 1997.
The `Activity Test Penalty Periods' Bill currently before Parliament introduces a series of rate reductions for activity test breach penalties.
(2) Yes. Current administrative breach penalties and the penalties in the Activity Test Penalty Periods Bill meet the concerns of community organisations as appropriate penalties, both to provide deterrence and to ensure some level of continuing income support.
Customers are regularly advised of their obligations and the penalties that exist.
(3) Customers are interviewed in the majority of cases where an activity test breach decision is being contemplated. This interview ensures that all
circumstances are considered. In appropriate cases customers are referred to Departmental social workers for guidance and assistance.
Where a customer subsequently is cancelled due to a breach, they are notified in writing of the cancellation and the reasons for that cancellation. That advice includes information about review and appeal rights and payment pending review.
(4) The Department is constantly seeking to improve its practices. The application of the breaches has recently been reviewed to ensure that the deterrent effect of penalties is reasonably retained.
(5) Indicative data shows a total of 90,000 breach penalties were imposed by the Department for the period July 1996 to April 1997. Of these, 38,500 were for activity test breaches and 51,500 were for administrative breaches.
Precise data on the actual penalties imposed during this period is unavailable. However, historically, the average length of activity test breach penalty is 3.7 weeks, while an administrative breach is 2.3 weeks.
Canberra: Nara Park
(Question No. 1690)
Mrs Crosio
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:
(1) Did he or a member of his staff contact the Chief Minister of the ACT or the Chief Minister's staff, to convey his objections over the use of the word "peace" in the title of a Canberra park intended to be named "The Canberra‐Nara Peace Park".
(2) If so, did he insist that the removal of the word "peace" from the intended title of the park was a prerequisite before the Commonwealth approved the use of its land by the ACT Government in recognition of the friendship between the "sister cities" of Canberra and Nara.
(3) What were his reasons for objecting to the use of the word "peace" in the intended title of the Canberra‐Nara Peace Park.
(4) What is the Government's position on Japan and that country's acceptance of its guilt for its role in atrocities carried out by its armed forces and its government during World War II.
(5) Does the Government consider that past and present governments and leaders of Japan in the period since hostilities ended on 15 August 1945 have expressed (a) adequate remorse or (b) an adequate apology, for that country's actions during World War II.
(6) What conditions would have to be present for him to consider it appropriate for a park which recognises the firm and ongoing friendship between Australian and Japanese "sister cities" to have the word "peace" included in a park's title.
Mr Howard
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1)‐(6) Australia and Japan have built a remarkably strong and friendly partnership in the fifty years since the end of the war. This has been the result of efforts by successive governments in both countries and is reflected in our increasingly close business and people‐to‐people links.
The war is an important part of the history of both countries and many in our community were directly affected by it. The government's position with regard to the Canberra‐Nara park was that their sensitivities should have been taken into account through consultation with the appropriate representative body.
Discussions which took place with the Chief Minister of the ACT and her office were based on this view.
Pastoral Leases
(Question No. 1704)
Mr Kelvin Thomson
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 May 1997:
(1) How many pastoral leases operating in Australia involve Crown land.
(2) What proportion of pastoral leasehold area is held by Australian (a) citizens and (b) corporations.
(3) Is he able to say what proportion of Australian primary exports originate from leasehold land.
Mr Howard
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) All pastoral leases are leases of Crown land.
(2) Most leases are administered by the states and territories. Information held by the states and territories is not sufficient to enable individual leaseholders to be confidently distinguished from corporate leaseholders. However, data from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) farm survey provides some indication of the ownership of pastoral properties. ABARE estimates that in the pastoral zone in 1994‐95, 66 percent of the area operated in the zone were operated by families and 34 percent were operated by corporate organisations. ABARE also estimates that in the same year, 3,762 properties in the zone were family‐owned and that 259 were corporately-owned
(3) No. Australian export statistics are not linked to land title.

Ms Ellis
asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice,
on 14 May 1997:
(1) What sums were granted (a) in 1990‐91, (b) in 1991‐92, (c) in 1992‐93, (d) in 1993‐94, (e) in 1994‐95, (f) in 1995‐96 and (h) between 1 July 1996 and 1 May 1997 to (i) government and (ii) non‐government schools in the electoral division of Namadgi.
(2) With respect to each grant referred to in part (1), what (a) sum was granted, (b) was the location of the recipient and (c) was the purpose for which the grant was made.
Dr Kemp
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) Commonwealth assistance is provided on a calendar year basis and the following are the
identifiable grants to schools in the electorates since 1990.
Details of General Recurrent, Capital and National Equity Programme grants to non‐government schools in the electoral division of Namadgi follow,

Unemployment
(Question No. 1757)
Mr Kelvin Thomson
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 May 1997:
Is it a fact that unemployment and its social, human and economic impacts is the most important issue for all Australians; if so, why.
Mr Howard
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Yes, unemployment is the most important issue for all Australians. The government has recognised this and is addressing unemployment through:
.
an integrated strategy to provide increased employment opportunities for all Australians through policies aimed at fostering strong and sustained economic and employment growth: in particular fiscal consolidation, workplace relations reform and a package of measures to assist small business;
.
the reforms to employment assistance which will provide a simpler and more effective system of assistance for those unemployed people who are most in need;
.
the pilot work for the dole projects which will assist to integrate unemployed young people into the community; and
.
its reform agenda in schools, vocational education and apprenticeships and traineeships,
which will better prepare young people for real quality jobs.
Reconciliation Convention
(Question No. 1763)
Mr Campbell
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 May 1997:
(1) What were the prices of tickets to attend the Reconciliation Conference in Melbourne.
(2) How many tickets were paid for (a) directly and (b) indirectly by the Government.
Mr Howard
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The prices of tickets to attend the Australian Reconciliation Convention were as follows:
$
Early registration (before 11 April) (Includes Awards dinner)
400
Standard registration (after 11 April) (does not include Awards dinner)
400
Awards dinner
50
Students/Pensioners/Unemployed (Includes Awards dinner if paid before 11 April)
250
Day registration (does not include Awards dinner)
175
(2) More than 1800 people attended the Australian Reconciliation Convention from the 26‐28 May 1997. The majority of participants were fully paid, either personally or through their organisation or employer. It is not possible to determine from registration records which of these participants were funded, directly or indirectly, from Government sources.
Complimentary registration was extended to current and former Council members (25), Australians for Reconciliation Coordinators (20), State Reconciliation Committee representatives from each State and Territory (20), invited speakers and chairpersons (for plenary and seminar sessions—158), ceremony guests (54), Australian Reconciliation Awards finalists (30) and sponsors (28).
In addition, approximately 130 media representatives were accredited for the convention and, as is normal practice, did not pay registration fees.
Council agreed to provide some assistance to participants in need, particularly people from remote or rural areas or from sectors which appeared to be poorly represented. These costs were largely met from sponsorship monies received for the convention. The number of participants who received assistance with registration was approximately 110.
These numbers have been calculated from interim convention statistics reports while the final convention attendance statistics and financial records are being completed.
Official Establishment
(Question No. 1767)
Mr Latham
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 May 1997:
What use has been, or will be, made of the $1.1m discretionary fund established in 1996 for the Official Establishments.
Mr Howard
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Within the 1996‐97 budget for the Official Establishments Program an amount of $1.1m was set aside for possible capital works required at the residences. No expenditure has been, or will be, incurred against this item in the 1996‐97 financial year.
Sydney 2000 Olympic Games
(Question No. 1779)
Mr McClelland
asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games, upon notice, on 29 May 1997:
How many, and which, countries have expressed an intention to participate in the Sydney 2000 Olympics, as at 29 May 1997.
Mr Warwick Smith
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I am unable to supply the information requested by the honourable member at this time. The Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) is required, on the advice of the International Olympic Committee (IOC), to issue invitations to all recognised National Olympic Committees one year prior to the staging of Sydney's Olympic Games—ie those invitations will be posted from Lausanne, Switzerland on 15 September 1999. National Olympic Committees in receipt of invitations have four months after the date on which the invitations were sent to notify the IOC of their participation.
At this stage, SOCOG can only rely on the number of National Olympic Committees who participated in the Atlanta Olympics in 1996—which was 197.
Before existing as a National Olympic Committee and acquiring the rights to be designated as such, the organisation must be recognised by the IOC. This recognition can only be granted to an organisation, the jurisdiction of which coincides with the limits of the country in which it is established and has its headquarters.
If more National Olympic Committees are recognised by the IOC, then those Committees would also be included in the invitation list to attend the Sydney Games.
